[19:00:00.0000] <mpilgrim>

[19:02:00.0000] <mpilgrim>

[19:02:01.0000] <boblet>

[19:02:02.0000] <mpilgrim>

[19:02:03.0000] <mpilgrim>
UNLESS

[19:02:04.0000] <mpilgrim>
you install the non-free codecs

[19:03:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
this is packaged in the ubuntu PPA as chromium-codecs-ffmpeg-nonfree.deb

[19:03:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
then chromium will supports exactly what chrome supports

[19:03:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
but i'm not exactly sure what that is

[19:03:03.0000] <mpilgrim>
it includes H.264/AAC in an MP4 container

[19:03:04.0000] <mpilgrim>
for <video>

[19:04:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
it also includes MP3 for <audio>

[19:04:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
i believe chrome also supports MP3 tracks in a video

[19:04:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
but i will double-check that

[19:05:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
and since it's based on ffmpeg, i *think* it supports up to and including High Profile H.264, all profiles of AAC, etc.

[19:05:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
but i will double-check that too

[19:07:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
i have no information on if, when, or whether chrome will add support for VP8 or any of the other On2 codecs that we just acquired

[19:10:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
neither chromium nor chrome use gstreamer, directshow, quicktime, or any other media backends

[19:10:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
we built our own, some details are here: http://dev.chromium.org/developers/design-documents/video

[19:11:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
there is a bug asking us to rip that out and use gstreamer instead: http://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=32861

[19:13:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
it's marked "WONTFIX"

[18:35:00.0000] <othermaciej>
even though it is an arbitrary milestone, I am for some reason very excited about publishing

[18:39:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: I think the biggest positive effect of WD publication is that it gets documents a lot wider attention than just editor's-draft publication does

[18:40:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
at least as far as W3C publication goes

[18:40:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
and for a certain period of time, at least

[18:40:02.0000] <othermaciej>
in the context of HTML5, I have not seen it result in a higher level of technical review

[18:40:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah

[18:40:04.0000] <othermaciej>
though it does get some sort of attention in the tech press

[18:42:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: yeah, the downside of that is that one of the first questions all the media people seem to ask every time W3C publishes and HTML5 WD is that, "OK, so when will HTML5 be done?" question

[18:43:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
to which it seems to me the only proper response is to try to get them to see that they're asking the wrong question

[18:43:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
but that's not usually successfull

[18:43:02.0000] <othermaciej>
then we can just point to the charter and indicate that the next milestone is Last Call

[18:43:03.0000] <othermaciej>
which is on schedule, so long as we can invent time travel technology in the next few months

[18:43:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
heh

[18:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
the ietf guys argued that websocket would get wider review if we went through the ietf, but so far all the useful feedback i've received has been either off-list or on the whatwg list

[18:46:00.0000] <Hixie>
similar to how it was argued that html5 would get more review if we went through the w3c

[18:46:01.0000] <Hixie>
looks to me like the standards organisations are out of date in terms of what gets wider useful feedback :-)

[18:47:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: I sent useful feedback on the ietf list... I think

[18:48:00.0000] <Hixie>
i think everything you said on the list you first said on the adam/you/me thread we had

[18:48:01.0000] <Hixie>
and adam and you would have reviewed the spec anyway, regardless of whether we went w3c, whatwg, or ietf

[18:48:02.0000] <othermaciej>
nah, I pointed out the reverse cross-protocol problem on the list first, then discussed it with you on IRC, then on the email thread with Adam

[18:48:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I would like to say I would have given that feedback anyway but I only thought of it due to people questioning the handshake

[18:49:00.0000] <Hixie>
fair enough

[18:49:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: standards organizations are out of date in a lot of ways.. I guess until we actually work on coming up with viable alternative, we are stuck with what we got, and hopefully at least we can (or have) managed to get some improvements made

[18:49:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I mean, I might have still had the thought

[18:50:00.0000] <Hixie>
MikeSmith: my most successful standard i think has been pingback, which didn't involve a standards organisation at all

[18:50:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it's not clear to me how to make a good standards org

[18:50:02.0000] <Hixie>
MikeSmith: so it's not clear to me that we _need_ an alternative

[18:50:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
I think the existence of the Web Sockets discussion at IETF has helped to changed the IETF culture for the better

[18:50:04.0000] <othermaciej>
all the existing ones either come down to pay-to-play voting or dictatorship by an elite oligarchy, if you push hard enough

[18:51:00.0000] <Hixie>
really? how so?

[18:51:01.0000] <Hixie>
er, that was to mike

[18:51:02.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: i think the oligarchy mechanism is the only one that truly works, but it only works so long as the oligarchy has the respect of the implementors

[18:52:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: and i think it pretty much stops having the respect as soon as there's a process in place, because a process forcibly distances the oligarchy from the implementors

[18:52:01.0000] <Hixie>
part of the problem the w3c and ietf both have is that they try to solve too many problems at once

[18:52:02.0000] <Hixie>
having multiple focus areas is a huge red flag for a std org imho

[18:52:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: I think the implementors issue is something that the Web Sockets work has helped to raise awareness about in the IETF

[18:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
oligarchy can work with the right oligarchs

[18:53:01.0000] <othermaciej>
and so long as it does not get overwhelmed with legitimacy disputes

[18:53:02.0000] <Hixie>
legitimacy disputes = lack of respect

[18:54:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: the awareness being that it is risky to develop a spec without also working hard to get implementor buy-in during the spec-development process

[18:54:01.0000] <othermaciej>
IETF and W3C try to have consensus/voting as the front line decision-making tool, with escalation to a dictator/oligarchy

[18:54:02.0000] <othermaciej>
sometimes I wonder if the other way around would work better

[18:54:03.0000] <othermaciej>
of course, in the HTML WG we kinda have a sandwich

[18:54:04.0000] <Hixie>

[23:29:01.0000] <othermaciej>
what's the actual blocker?

[23:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I wondered if maybe there was some idea that a format spec had to be at REC before it could be used, but I notices that even Working Drafts of XHTML1 were published as XHTML1, not as HTML4

[23:30:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
the blocker is that the team doesn't believe it's appropriate yet to be publishing documents that use features from HTML5 that are not at least in a PR draft

[23:30:02.0000] <othermaciej>
so it doesn't seem like there is a hard and fast rule

[23:30:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
as far as XHTML1 and HTML4, that was then, this is now

[23:31:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
there were a whole lot of corners cut in publishing HTML4 and XHTML1

[23:31:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
I would suggest that we don't want to use their publication approach as a precedent

[23:31:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it just seems like an embarrassment to me that we can't publish HTML5 as HTML5

[23:31:03.0000] <othermaciej>
but from what you say, it sounds like it would be a waste of time to pursue it

[23:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's an embarassment to the w3c

[23:32:01.0000] <Hixie>
html5 has been published as html5 for years

[23:32:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
fwiw, I have argued that simply using <!doctype html> as the doctype on a document does not constitute publishing it as HTML5

[23:32:03.0000] <othermaciej>
it's an embarrassment to the HTML WG, even though it is not up to us

[23:34:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[23:35:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[23:35:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[01:58:00.0000] <annevk>
asmodai, ah

[01:58:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I could understand arguing they are needed for compat, I was surprised at the argument that it's actually a good default

[02:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
there's a request that we report whether a websocket connection closed gracefully or not

[02:17:01.0000] <Hixie>
i see two ways to do this:

[02:17:02.0000] <Hixie>
1. add some state data to the 'close' event

[02:17:03.0000] <Hixie>
2. add a new event

[02:17:04.0000] <Hixie>
if we go with 2, does anybody have any suggestions for what the two events should be?

[02:17:05.0000] <Hixie>
onclose and onerrorclose?

[02:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
(onerror is going to be used for when an unexpected frame type is received)

[02:20:00.0000] <jgraham>
I think I prefer 1). Having to register two different event handlers in the case that you don't care about the error seems unweildy

[02:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
Are people usually going to want to perform the same processing in response to both types of closing?

[02:21:01.0000] <jgraham>
Plus the state seems needed anyway if there is more than one possible type of error

[02:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
k

[02:21:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: are there any non-fatal errors?

[02:21:04.0000] <othermaciej>
I would say "close" and "error" if there were two events

[02:21:05.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: yeah, receiving a frame of an unexpected type

[02:21:06.0000] <othermaciej>
I also think extra info in the "close" event is good

[02:21:07.0000] <Hixie>
k

[02:22:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it would be nice if the close event could tell you the last message known to be delivered, but that requires more than clean close I think

[02:24:00.0000] <Hixie>
v2.

[02:24:01.0000] <Hixie>
actually you couldn't do that in the close event anyway

[02:24:02.0000] <Hixie>
you need to reconnect to find that information

[02:25:00.0000] <annevk>
can't we use a different event for a frame of an unexpected type

[02:25:01.0000] <annevk>
the error event has always been used for network errors

[02:25:02.0000] <Hixie>
we can use whatever event you want

[02:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
what would you like

[02:28:00.0000] <annevk>
messageerror?

[02:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
done

[02:29:00.0000] <annevk>
http://isgeolocationpartofhtml5.com/ sweet

[02:29:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: last message *known* to be delivered - it would be a pessimistic estimate in the error case, and exact in the clean close case

[02:29:02.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: would not require reconnectin

[02:29:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: but it would require some form of per-message acks

[02:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: definitely v2.

[02:30:01.0000] <othermaciej>
not saying this is essential, just theorizing

[02:30:02.0000] <othermaciej>
annevk: a lot of people would disagree with that site

[02:30:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: I don't know if it has to be v-anything

[02:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
there is a tension in designing this protocol

[02:31:01.0000] <othermaciej>
on the one hand, it would be hugely valuable to have practical experience before adding a lot of stuff

[02:31:02.0000] <othermaciej>
on the other hand, you really don't want to accidentally lock in a flawed design prematurely

[02:31:03.0000] <othermaciej>
that seems like a weakness in Roy's proposed "deploy first, then standardize" model

[02:33:00.0000] <Hixie>
specs have to be written while implementations grow

[02:33:01.0000] <Hixie>
there's no magical solution, you just have to be careful

[02:33:02.0000] <Hixie>
anyway, what should this event attribute be. event.closeError?

[02:34:00.0000] <Hixie>
(boolean)

[02:35:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I like booleans to start with something like "has" or "is" but that's hard to do in this case

[02:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
event.wasClean?

[02:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
what's the opposite of a clean close

[02:37:01.0000] <Hixie>
abrupt?

[02:37:02.0000] <Hixie>
terminated?

[02:37:03.0000] <annevk>
why do we need an event attribute if you have error/close?

[02:37:04.0000] <Hixie>
annevk: it was argued that we should have only one event

[02:37:05.0000] <annevk>
that's not really consistent with <img>, XHR, etc.

[02:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
since in most cases you won't care

[02:38:01.0000] <Hixie>
well on those this event is called "load"

[02:38:02.0000] <annevk>
you can just do socket.onerror = x; socket.onclose = x;

[02:38:03.0000] <Hixie>
(which isn't really especially meaningful here)

[02:38:04.0000] <Hixie>
annevk: yeah but that means the simple case is harder

[02:38:05.0000] <Hixie>
which is bad API design

[02:39:00.0000] <annevk>

[02:39:01.0000] <annevk>

[02:39:02.0000] <annevk>

[03:09:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
zcorpan: how about "A void element is an element whose content model never allows it to have contents under any circumstances." ?

[03:09:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
that would seem to exclude the <colgroup span> case

[03:10:00.0000] <Hixie>
an element being void or not has nothing to do with its content model, in theory

[03:10:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: so what does it have to do with?

[03:10:02.0000] <Hixie>
(though of course in practice there's a relationship)

[03:10:03.0000] <Hixie>
it's just a syntax thing

[03:10:04.0000] <Hixie>
there's a list of elements that are void

[03:10:05.0000] <Hixie>
they are the ones that never have an end tag

[03:11:00.0000] <Hixie>
that's all there is to it

[03:11:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
so you are not defining them as "void" in the XML syntax?

[03:11:02.0000] <Hixie>
"void" is a text/html syntax feature, it has no equivalent in XML

[03:12:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's similar to optional tags

[03:12:01.0000] <Hixie>
or RCDATA elements

[03:13:00.0000] <asmodai>
hahaha

[03:13:01.0000] <asmodai>
http://i.imgur.com/Zdk4B.jpg

[03:13:02.0000] <asmodai>

[03:16:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[03:16:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[03:16:02.0000] <Hixie>
zcorpan: anne asked for it, see about an hour ago in the irc logs

[03:16:03.0000] <Hixie>
zcorpan: i'd rather have error, so if you convince him to change his mind, i'll change it :-)

[03:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
MikeSmith: the concept of "void" is a syntax thing, it has nothing to do with the abstract language

[03:17:01.0000] <zcorpan>

[03:21:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[03:21:01.0000] <zcorpan>

[11:59:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[12:00:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[12:00:01.0000] <roc>

[12:12:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
"Opera requires that your video file is served as video/ogg for it to play."  Why?

[12:12:01.0000] <zcorpan>
that's not entirely accurate; we also accept application/ogg and audio/ogg and audio/wav etc

[12:12:02.0000] <zcorpan>
but text/plain and text/html etc are rejected

[12:12:03.0000] <zcorpan>
because the spec says so

[12:13:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Oh, feh.

[12:13:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Why does the spec say so?  These aren't script, are there security problems?

[12:14:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Apache seems to serve application/ogg by default for Ogg, or at least a rule in /etc/apache2/magic seems to say so.

[12:14:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Still not sure why this is necessary.

[12:15:00.0000] <zcorpan>
it's just to avoid mislabeled content

[12:15:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Which will fail anyway when you feed it to GStreamer, no?

[12:16:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
The server might mislabel, the video player will know for sure whether it can play the file.

[12:16:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Server-set MIME types should be treated as hints of intent, not an actual description of what the content is, because how should the server know that?  But maybe there's a good reason here.

[12:17:00.0000] <zcorpan>
sure, but if we play text/plain videos, then we need to sniff for video for text/plain if we want to be able to play mislabeled videos when loaded directly

[12:17:01.0000] <zcorpan>
plus, we want to reject video/mp4 if we can't play mpeg-4

[12:17:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, I assume you already do other types of sniffing there anyway, so why not?

[12:18:00.0000] <zcorpan>
so it's not much effort to also reject text/plain

[12:18:01.0000] <zcorpan>
because we don't know what gstreamer supports so we don't know what to sniff for

[12:18:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me doesn't get what the benefit is to users or authors that outweighs the annoyance of authors potentially having to configure their servers.

[12:18:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
So let GStreamer sniff.  It presumably returns an error graciously if it can't play it, right?

[12:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
GStreamer is the only part of the system that knows for sure what can be played.

[12:19:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Once you've already received the HTTP headers, you've received the start of the content too, so just feed that to GStreamer and that will be a lot more reliable than guessing based on header.

[12:19:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Of course, it makes sense to sniff based on MIME type in the HTML, because that way you can avoid unnecessary requests.

[12:27:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[14:11:04.0000] <mpilgrim>
i serve my embedded TTF fonts gzipped already

[14:13:00.0000] <roc>
WOFF reorders the tables and compresses them independently, which could be helpful if you want to analyze just the CMAP

[14:15:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
could i not do that with a TTF file directly? (non-rhetorical question)

[14:18:00.0000] <roc>
you could reorder the tables and gzip the whole thing. Then the browser could read the CMAP quicker, but when you wanted the other tables you'd have to re-uncompress the whole file from scratch, unless you saved the gzip state. It's considerably more complex.

[14:19:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Sigh.  Why do tables have to act so weird?  Specifically with respect to floating and positioned descendants.

[15:13:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[21:31:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hmm, I don't think Jonas's assertion that "Validation only checks for a certain, very limited, types of errors." is entirely accurate

[21:32:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it only checks for syntax errors

[21:32:01.0000] <othermaciej>
not other kinds of errors

[21:34:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I would not classify syntax errors as "very limited types of errors"

[21:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Jonas is probably speaking from the programmer's perspective

[21:34:02.0000] <othermaciej>
the errors we spend most of our time dealing with are not syntax errors

[21:35:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
right, I understand that

[21:35:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
but a markup validator is essentially a lint checker

[21:35:02.0000] <othermaciej>
right

[21:35:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
a static checker

[21:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think static checkers, lint-like tools, and validators are all awesome things

[21:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>
yet I agree with Jonas that the errors they can find are but a subset of the possible interesting errors

[21:36:02.0000] <othermaciej>
though, for document-like content it's probably a higher fraction of errors you may care about

[21:37:00.0000] <othermaciej>
than for app-type content

[21:37:01.0000] <othermaciej>
we compile WebKit at a crazy high warning level

[21:37:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah, agreed

[21:39:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
checking/validating the initial markup of some particular a Web app that changes state is of limited usefulness 

[21:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
our warning flags: -Werror -Wmissing-prototypes -Wnon-virtual-dtor -Wnewline-eof -Wall -Wextra -Wcast-align -Wcast-qual -Wchar-subscripts -Wextra-tokens -Wformat=2 -Winit-self -Wmissing-format-attribute -Wmissing-noreturn -Wpacked -Wpointer-arith -Wredundant-decls -Wundef -Wwrite-strings -Wno-trigraphs

[21:53:01.0000] <othermaciej>
(-Werror makes the build break if someone violates one of these)

[05:10:03.0000] <mut>
but im using .translate(), i just wondered how do you reset the origin to 0,0 and clear the canvas? 

[05:14:00.0000] <mut>
like im drawing something based on user interaction based on a form, but when they select something, i wanna clear the canvas, and start again

[05:16:00.0000] <mut>
ah if i change/reset the width/height of the canvas it "resets" the canvas... :)

[05:18:00.0000] <Philip`>
mut: Usually you should use save()/restore() to reset the origin

[05:18:01.0000] <Philip`>
and clearRect to clear the bitmap

[05:18:02.0000] <Philip`>
though if you really want to reset the entire canvas then changing size will work too

[05:21:00.0000] <mut>
oh

[05:21:01.0000] <mut>
save() restore()

[05:21:02.0000] <mut>
hmm ill take a look

[05:22:00.0000] <mut>
so i save() when the canvas is clear, and then do restore()?

[05:24:00.0000] <Philip`>
They don't affect the canvas bitmap at all

[05:24:01.0000] <Philip`>
save() just remembers the current origin transformations, fill styles, etc

[05:24:02.0000] <Philip`>
and restore() resets them back to the last saved values

[05:24:03.0000] <Philip`>
Oh, wait

[05:24:04.0000] <Philip`>
That's what you said

[05:24:05.0000] <Dashiva>
Wow, Jobs actually called animating an object "original technology"?

[05:25:00.0000] <mut>
ok

[05:25:01.0000] <Philip`>
so, yes :-)

[05:25:02.0000] <mut>
errm but when i try that, the canvas dosent clear

[05:25:03.0000] <mut>
oh i nead to clearrect toto

[05:25:04.0000] <mut>
too

[05:25:05.0000] <mut>
heh

[05:25:06.0000] <Dashiva>
Is clearrect cheaper than .width = .width?

[05:26:00.0000] <Philip`>
Dashiva: Yes, in theory, because it has to do less work

[05:26:01.0000] <Philip`>
(although implementations might be suboptimal and do more work in the common case, in order to handle more general cases)

[05:27:00.0000] <mut>

[05:27:01.0000] <mut>

[05:27:02.0000] <Philip`>

[05:28:01.0000] <mut>

[05:28:02.0000] <mut>

[05:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
It's probably best to not call ctx.save in init(), and instead make the drawStairs function do "ctx.clearRect(...); ctx.save(); ...do all the drawing...; ctx.restore()"

[05:31:01.0000] <mut>
ok

[05:33:00.0000] <Philip`>
That way the canvas would always be in a 'normal' state, except temporarily while it's inside the drawing function (where it'll mess around with the state but it'll restore everything at the end)

[05:34:00.0000] <mut>
ok thats almost there  :) cheers

[05:35:00.0000] <mut>

You can always insert a literal U+00A0 character. That would be less ugly, but possibly also harder to maintain

[06:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
mut: Not sure if this is the problem, but I think you need to call beginPath more

[06:29:00.0000] <Philip`>
Typically you should always do "beginPath(); moveTo and lineTo etc to set up the path; fill() or stroke();"

[06:29:01.0000] <mut>
oh ok

[06:29:02.0000] <Philip`>
because fill/stroke don't reset the current path, so it will continue to exist for your next path-drawing operation

[06:29:03.0000] <Philip`>
and so you'll keep building up a longer and longer path, and keep refilling/restroking the early parts lots of times

[06:30:00.0000] <Philip`>
e.g. in the drawStairRun loop

[06:30:01.0000] <Philip`>
and it looks like that'll also be drawing the bits of path left over from the end of the previous time you redrew the screen

[06:30:02.0000] <mut>
Ok, ill go and have a look (only found canvas this morning! so Im on the bottom of the learning curve) ill go and sort out the beginpath stuff out first and see if that helps

[06:30:03.0000] <Philip`>
so beginPath should help :-)

[12:08:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
MikeSmith, what exactly is the relationship between validator.nu and validator.w3.org?  Could my problem be fixed in validator.nu and it would also work on the W3C validator?  The latter is the one that most people use.

[12:13:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
AryehGregor: the current W3C validator is essentially a Perl script that wraps around James Clark's old C-based "sp" validation engine, which is an SGML tool that does DTD-based validation. if it either encounters a <!doctype html> doctype or is manually told to check a doc as HTM5, what that perl script does is, it uses the validator.nu REST API to validate the document, then processes the results of that and reports them

[12:14:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Oh, so it's literally requesting results from validator.nu, not just running the same software?  Interesting.

[12:15:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
AryehGregor: no, actually, to be precise, it's usually a locally-installed headless instance of the validator.nu backend

[12:15:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Ah.

[12:15:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
It seems like I'd want 1) validator.nu to say it's valid HTML5 if it is, even with a confusing doctype, and 2) the Perl script to try passing things to validator.nu if it has an obsolete but conforming doctype but doesn't validate according to that doctype.

[12:15:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Does that sound right?

[12:16:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
AryehGregor: yeah

[12:16:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Okay, thanks.

[12:17:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
but I would not recommend calling those doctypes "obsolete but conforming" in discussions on the qa-dev and www-validator lists

[12:18:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
you would likely just get people taking issue with that wording rather than listening to what you're proposing

[12:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Er, okay.

[12:19:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's the term the HTML5 spec uses, right?

[12:19:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
right, but even the intent of that is the specific context of HTML4

[12:19:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
*HTML5

[12:20:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
there are lot of people who don't care about validating their documents as HTML5 at this point and who may never want to change or update their content to get it validate against HTML5, if it's already valid HTML4 or XHTML1

[12:20:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
which is fine

[12:21:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Right.  I'd say only kick it to validator.nu if it fails validation under the given doctype.

[12:22:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
even in that case, I don't think you will get a warm reception if you propose that it does that automatically, or especially if it does it without reporting their errors against whatever doctype the document actually uses

[12:23:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
for one thing, it would mean validation of every invalid document would take longer, because it would get automatically checked twice

[12:25:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Maybe we could use a secret code, like adding <!-- html5 --> right after the doctype to trigger HTML5 validation mode?

[12:25:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hacky, but it would be a lot simpler, I imagine.

[12:25:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
icky indeed

[12:26:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I don't know what the target users would be who would take the time to do that

[12:26:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or could the HTML5 obsolete-but-conforming doctypes be modified so that they specify the same DTD/entities, but are not actually conforming HTML4 or whatever?

[12:26:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Take the time to do what?

[12:26:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'd do it in MediaWiki, that's my concern here.  The current setup has MediaWiki not validating even if it's valid HTML5, if in well-formed XML mode.

[12:27:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I meant, take the time to add a special-purpose comment like that

[12:27:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
but I think you'd get a warmer reception if the suggestion were for an opt-in mechanism that prompts users to choose whether they want to re-validate the doc at HTML5 or not

[12:27:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I meant, I'll add the comment to MediaWiki if it's the only way to validate.

[12:27:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
I see

[12:27:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'm concerned about people sticking the page in the validator and getting a "This document is invalid!"

[12:28:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Nobody's going to notice a revalidate button unless it's unreasonably prominent.

[12:28:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
(since most such documents will not be valid HTML5 either)

[12:28:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't know much about doctypes -- is there some way to make the doctype invalid HTML4/XHTML1 while still keeping the same behavior in browsers and other XML processors?

[12:29:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or is every part that's specified essential?

[12:29:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
I don't think there's any way to do that, no

[12:29:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me thinks it all looks essential, although he doesn't understand all of it.

[12:30:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
only thing I can think of is that SGML does not require the system ID

[12:31:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
that is, the URI part  in the doctype

[12:31:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
the second quoted string

[12:31:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
it only needs to first

[12:31:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's necessary for XML validators to figure out the entities, though.

[12:31:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
leaving off the system ID makes it invalid XML

[12:31:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hmm.

[12:31:06.0000] <MikeSmith>
actually, non-well-formed XML, I gues

[12:31:07.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, a comment would be hacky, but I had actually thought of it earlier anyway, because it will also serve to inform human readers that the document is actually HTML5.

[12:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Lest they get confused.

[12:32:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Do you think that would stand a chance of getting approved?

[12:32:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
I very much doubt it

[12:32:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Bleh.

[12:32:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
I think most people consider specialized comments of that kind to be an anti-pattern

[12:33:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
that's the kind of thing that SGML/XML processing instructions are meant for

[12:33:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
but such processing instructions are not valid in HTML5, for good reasons

[12:33:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Can you think of anything else that might possibly get approved?  Maybe I should just explain the problem and outline the pros and cons I see with each possible solution and hope someone finds something acceptable beyond "call it invalid"?

[12:34:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
AryehGregor: explaining the problem first would be good, yeah

[12:34:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, I was planning on doing that anyway.  :)

[12:34:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'll give that a shot when I have the time.

[12:35:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Thanks.

[12:35:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
OK. proposing specific solutions is fine, too, but the risk is always that people then get hung up on arguing about the merits or faults of the proposed solution rather than thinking about the problem

[12:36:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Right.

[12:36:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Got to go now, I'll post a message to one of those lists soon.

[12:51:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
<twitter!andymantell> @w3c Still don't get why there is no previous sibling combinator in CSS3, it'd be so so useful - any chance this could make it in one day?

[12:55:00.0000] <Dashiva>
That would lead to possible cycles

[12:57:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
MikeSmith: I can answer that.  Gimme a sec; busy right now, then I'll give you a details response.

[12:57:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
TabAtkins: thanks

[12:58:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
or feel free to reply directly to him on twitter if you want 

[12:58:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Dashiva: performance issue?

[13:03:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I'm not sure if it's only performance or if it could lead to loops in the layout as well

[13:04:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
No, just within selectors you can't get cycles.

[13:04:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's performance reasons, though previous-sibling and parent combinators are okay enough that implementors are all right with doing them.

[13:04:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Oh, my bad then

[13:04:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
We just haven't started writing Selectors 4 yet.

[13:05:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
They're pretty much certain to be in there.

[13:06:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Basically browsers have a somewhat unintuitive performance profile that makes all the reverse-versions of the current 4 combinators pretty inefficient, even though they can be done fairly easily in selectors engines like Sizzle.

[13:07:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's because nearly all selectors matching in browsers happens on an incomplete DOM as a page is being loaded, while js-based selectors engines operate on complete doms.

[13:09:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
And the existing combinators happen to work great with that, as they only need information that is guaranteed to already be in the DOM.

[13:09:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
If you are trying to match div > span, when a span appears you are guaranteed that, if it has a div parent, you'll have already seen it and know about it because of the way HTML's structure works.

[13:10:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
While "span < div" doesn't offer the same promise - when you see a div, you then have to wait until all its children have been loaded before you can be sure if it has a span child.

[13:13:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
MikeSmith: So there you go.  Try condensing that down to 140 characters.  ^_^

[13:14:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I want :has-child() *so bad*, but I understand why it hasn't appeared so far.  It will appear in the future, though.

[13:14:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
/me mainly wants it so he can do "label:has-child(:checked)".

[13:18:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
TabAtkins: thanks

[13:23:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
TabAtkins: you mentioned that implementors are OK with doing previous-sibling and parent combinators

[13:30:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Hixie: I need some help in getting the Microdata draft through pubrules

[13:31:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
TabAtkins: so you are saying that implementors are planning to add support for previous-sibling?

[14:48:01.0000] <TabAtkins>

[00:04:03.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:04:04.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:05:00.0000] <danbri>

[00:05:01.0000] <danbri>

[00:05:02.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:05:03.0000] <danbri>

[00:05:04.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:05:05.0000] <danbri>

[00:05:06.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:05:07.0000] <foolip>

[00:06:00.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:06:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:07:00.0000] <knowtheory>
the thing w/ SMIL is that it can provide basic timing semantics, which is handy for a variety of tasks, and is particularly useful when coordinating multiple pieces of content

[00:07:01.0000] <knowtheory>
i can give you examples of what the company i work for has been doing, and is pushing to continue to do

[00:07:02.0000] <knowtheory>
if people are interested

[00:07:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:07:04.0000] <knowtheory>
othermaciej: that's sort of true, and sort of not.  My biggest complaint about SMIL right now is that the layout tools feel really clunky

[00:07:05.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:07:06.0000] <foolip>

[00:08:00.0000] <knowtheory>
which is why i'm getting interested in the possibility of integrating SMIL timing semantics into something with a more mature layout model, like XHTML

[00:08:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:08:02.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:08:03.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:08:04.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:09:00.0000] <foolip>
but HTML has no namespaces, so we'd just be copying the element names

[00:09:01.0000] <othermaciej>
picking and choosing what components to support leads to fragmentation and lack of interoperability

[00:09:02.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:10:00.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:10:02.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:10:03.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:11:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:12:00.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:12:01.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:12:02.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:13:00.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:14:01.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:15:00.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:15:01.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:16:00.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:16:01.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:17:00.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:17:01.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:36:06.0000] <danski>

[00:37:00.0000] <foolip>

[00:38:00.0000] <danski>

[00:40:00.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:42:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[00:43:00.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:45:00.0000] <hsivonen>
knowtheory: it's not a given that mixing SMIL syntax into text/html is a good idea even if SMIL turned out to have some desirable features

[00:45:01.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:46:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[00:46:01.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:46:02.0000] <knowtheory>
supports nameespaces and all that fun stuff then right?

[00:46:03.0000] <knowtheory>
so XHTML5 should support imbedding SVG

[00:46:04.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:46:05.0000] <hsivonen>

[00:46:06.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:46:07.0000] <knowtheory>

[00:47:00.0000] <foolip>

[00:47:01.0000] <annevk>
why do we care about SMIL?

[00:47:02.0000] <knowtheory>
Because HTML5 is converging on the media space, which is what SMIL was made for

[00:47:03.0000] <knowtheory>
and because SMIL does things like provide timing semantics which don't really exist in other standards

[00:48:00.0000] <danski>
timing semantics. in this specific example, the synching of captions to video, but there are many other applications.

[00:48:01.0000] <knowtheory>
and because SMIL is already integrated into other standards, like SVG

[00:48:02.0000] <knowtheory>
I'm not saying that HTML5 has to support it, but i'd like to try to make a case

[00:48:03.0000] <knowtheory>
that it might be useful/cool if it did

[00:49:00.0000] <knowtheory>
And i'm not suggesting that HTML5 should contain SMIL :P

[00:49:01.0000] <knowtheory>
I was just curious whether there was a possibility for interoperability given this issue: http://www.w3.org/html/wg/tracker/issues/10

[00:49:02.0000] <zcorpan__>
SVG uses a forked subset of SMIL, not SMIL proper

[00:50:00.0000] <knowtheory>
Yes, there's a common functional base though

[05:55:00.0000] <davidhund__>
would this be a good time (and place) to ask the Swedish Heavy Metal Gods a question re: alt attribute on images in a <figure>?

[05:56:00.0000] <davidhund__>
I was just wondering, from a usability p.o.v., would it be correct to state that an image in a <figure> should always have alternative text (in the 'alt' attribute)?

[05:56:01.0000] <boblet>
if someone could programmatically turn emotions in email into noise, you wouldn’t even need to write any music; just point it at public-html and press rec

[06:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
davidhund__: The spec explicitly allows alt to be omitted if you're in a <figure> with a <figcaption>

[06:00:01.0000] <davidhund__>
But, this means that the figcaption could describe content that's 'not there', right?

[06:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
and indicates it's the appropriate thing to do when you don't have a real textual alternative to the image (e.g. you don't know what's in the image) but you do have some other text that's related to the image (e.g. a title)

[06:02:00.0000] <Philip`>
An <img> with no alt isn't 'not there'

[06:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
<img alt=""> is not there, but just <img> is unknown and dependent on context

[06:03:01.0000] <Philip`>
(as I understand it)

[06:03:02.0000] <davidhund__>
hrm

[06:05:00.0000] <Philip`>
I think the idea is that if you can replace the image with equivalent text, then that text goes in alt; otherwise you shouldn't specify alt at all (and shouldn't put in text that's descriptive but not equivalent - that should go in a <figcaption> instead)

[06:05:01.0000] <davidhund__>
How would <figure><img ... [some chart] alt=""><figcaption>The latest trends in Foo</figcaption></figure> be helpful to people with screenreaders?

[06:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
Empty alt="" should only be used for decorative images or similar things where the image can be omitted entirely; you shouldn't use it in that example

[06:08:00.0000] <davidhund__>
exactly.

[06:08:01.0000] <davidhund__>
Hence my question: "Would it be correct to say that alt text is required on images in a <figure>"

[06:11:00.0000] <Philip`>
No, because there are other examples where alt should be omitted (when it's impossible to do anything that would be helpful to people with screenreaders, and putting bogus alt text would be worse than omitting it and having associated non-alt text in a figcaption etc)

[06:12:00.0000] <Philip`>
like the spec's example of a photo sharing site saying "<figure> <img src="1100670787_6a7c664aef.jpg"> <figcaption>Bubbles traveled everywhere with us.</figcaption> </figure>"

[06:13:00.0000] <Philip`>
(where the site knows nothing about the image, other than a description of it (which is not equivalent to the image itself))

[06:15:00.0000] <davidhund__>
sure, just wondering about the usefulness of the figcaption in that case then…

[06:15:01.0000] <davidhund__>
thanks Philip'

[06:15:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
Lachy: I think you should be the part of Loki in our assemblage of rock gods known as Mjöllnir

[06:15:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[06:16:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
gsnedders: you will be Baldr, the emo-God

[06:16:01.0000] <Philip`>
davidhund__: The usefulness is that UAs can automatically determine the text that's associated with the image, and announce it to the user, so the user has better than no idea about what the image is

[07:24:00.0000] <zcorpan__>
"Thus I don't think having normative dependencies on non-free specifications could be allowed."

Someone should complain about the [BEZIER] reference, because that appears to almost entirely not exist

[07:29:00.0000] <Philip`>

[07:29:01.0000] <Philip`>
(and it's a normative dependency)

[07:30:00.0000] <zcorpan>
Philip`: go ahead

[07:30:01.0000] <Philip`>
But the someone would have to come up with a better reference to use instead

[07:30:02.0000] <zcorpan>

[07:30:03.0000] <Philip`>
and I couldn't find any that didn't require payment so I can't tell if they actually define what's needed

[07:31:00.0000] <Philip`>

[07:31:01.0000] <jgraham>

[07:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
Almost but not quite

[07:32:01.0000] <jgraham>
Right, but to the extent that technically less correct, but free, references, should be preferred where possible

[07:33:00.0000] <jgraham>
and references to non-free documents only included if there is literally no other possibility

[07:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
The problem with the BEZIER one is it's not non-free, it's entirely unfindable

[07:58:00.0000] <annevk>
didn't the SVG WG write up the BEZIER math?

[07:58:01.0000] <annevk>
/me wonders how hard it would be for someone to write down the relevant math so we can just include it directly

[08:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
The maths is trivial, it's just like http://upload.wikimedia.org/math/5/e/3/5e32b674a98a9f70e492851f9ad92b61.png

[08:00:01.0000] <Philip`>
but Hixie seemingly wanted something as close to the 'original' source as possible

[08:03:00.0000] <annevk>
seems easier to spec the math and save everyone some time

[08:04:00.0000] <Philip`>
In practice, it's easier to not include a reference or definition at all (I don't see one in SVG) because everyone knows what it means and/or can look it up on Wikipedia

[11:01:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
was told to come here for html5 canvas inquires is that correct?

[11:02:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
LoneStar99, yes, this is one place you can ask about that.

[11:08:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
i have a drawing program that works, fine but since it is a mobile, app it broke.  noticed line 7 of the following makes the code fail http://pastebin.com/fvRpPFeu 

[11:11:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
need to figure out how to not use "context.beginPath();"  but lines are still anti-aliased

[11:11:01.0000] <Philip`>
LoneStar99: It's not clear what that code is meant to be doing

[11:12:00.0000] <Philip`>
It sounds like you're calling it each time the user clicks somewhere?

[11:12:01.0000] <Philip`>
If you don't call beginPath, then every time you call lineTo you're making the current path get longer and longer

[11:13:00.0000] <Philip`>
and each time you call stroke() you're re-drawing every line segment that's ever been added to that path

[11:13:01.0000] <zcorpan>
MikeSmith: am now

[11:13:02.0000] <LoneStar99>
yes it is based o this code: http://devfiles.myopera.com/articles/649/example1.js

[11:13:03.0000] <Philip`>
which might be what makes it look non-antialiased (because it's overdrawing the lines)

[11:13:04.0000] <Philip`>
What you probably want is to do beginPath, and then moveTo with the *previous* mouse coordinates, and then lineTo with the current mouse coordinates

[11:14:00.0000] <Philip`>
so that each time you're just drawing a single line between the previous and current mouse positions

[11:15:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hmm, that example seems to do it wrong (it never resets so it'll stroke longer and longer paths)

[11:16:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
the weird thing is that drawing works, without "context.beginPath();" but once uncommented, it fails to display

[11:16:01.0000] <Philip`>
If you just call beginPath and then lineTo, it's not drawing a line from somewhere to somewhere

[11:16:02.0000] <Philip`>
because you've only given it a single point

[11:16:03.0000] <Philip`>
which is why you first need to moveTo the previous point

[11:18:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
how would I moveTo previous point?

[11:19:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
was chatting with another developer, and he said he does not even use "context.beginPath();"  to draw lines... how would I be able to do that?

[11:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
You need to add some global variables and store ev._x and ev._y in them each time you draw, and then use those values in a moveTo the next time you draw (after beginPath and before lineTo)

[11:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
If you don't use beginPath then you'll never reset to an empty path, so you'll have the problem of repeatedly drawing over the early parts of the path

[11:21:01.0000] <Philip`>
(which is an easy mistake because it's hard to notice, but it eventually makes things go really slow and look ugly)

[11:21:02.0000] <LoneStar99>
simply need to anti-alias anything drawn...  what is the best way?

[11:23:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
this is the sample code working, but without anti-aliasing http://devfiles.myopera.com/articles/649/example1.html 

[11:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
It is antialiasing, but it's got this overdraw problem because it never resets the path

[11:25:01.0000] <Philip`>
so if you move mouse a hundred times then the first part of the line will have been stroked a hundred times

[11:25:02.0000] <Philip`>
and the antialiased grey gets drawn a hundred times and turns black

[11:26:00.0000] <Philip`>
which is why it looks aliased

[11:29:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
kinda confused...

[11:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
If you say: ctx.strokeStyle = 'red'; ctx.moveTo(0, 0); ctx.lineTo(100, 0); ctx.stroke(); ctx.strokeStyle = 'green'; ctx.lineTo(100, 100); ctx.stroke();

[11:31:01.0000] <Philip`>
then it will stroke the first line segment in red, and then it will stroke *both* line segments in green

[11:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
because they're both still part of the current path

[11:32:01.0000] <Philip`>
and that's what that example is doing (except it's a lot more than two line segments, and it's stroking them all in black)

[11:35:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
i need lines to look like this: http://caimansys.com/painter/index.html

[11:35:01.0000] <LoneStar99>
not generic looking...

/me goes away for a while

[12:50:02.0000] <Dashiva>

[12:50:03.0000] <Philip`>

[12:50:04.0000] <Philip`>
but there isn't

[12:50:05.0000] <Philip`>
because there's only one definition and everybody uses it

[14:28:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: how come "hide UA text" gets a colored border but "highlight UA text" does not?

[14:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: because it's obvious that text is highlighted, but not at all obvious that text is hidden

[14:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
othermaciej: and i needed a way to remind myself that text was hidden when i was in UA mode so i wouldn't spend hours looking for text that was hidden

[19:10:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[19:10:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

;>

[19:14:00.0000] <wirepair>

[19:14:01.0000] <wirepair>

[19:14:02.0000] <wirepair>
er disagrees

[19:14:03.0000] <wirepair>

[06:47:00.0000] <Lachy>

[06:47:01.0000] <gsnedders>

[06:48:00.0000] <Lachy>

[06:48:01.0000] <jgraham>

[09:50:00.0000] <tantek>
Hixie, does microdata itemref permit referencing an id of an ancestor?

[09:50:01.0000] <tantek>
e.g. <span itemscope id=a><span itemprop=turtle itemscope id=b itemref=a></span></span>

[09:51:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
It might run afoul of the cycle-breaking algo, but there's no explicit restriction against such a thing.

[09:51:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I haven't kept up with the cycle algo, though.

[09:51:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
foolip would have more info, I think.

[09:51:03.0000] <tantek>
TabAtkins - what cycle breaking algo? none specified here: http://www.w3.org/TR/microdata/#attr-itemref

[09:52:00.0000] <tantek>
it just says "a list of additional elements to crawl to find the name-value pairs of the item."

[09:53:00.0000] <tantek>
which in the example above, gives you infinitely nested items, each with a turtle property whose value is the next nested item with a turtle property etc.

[09:53:01.0000] <tantek>
turtles all the way down ;)

[09:53:02.0000] <tantek>
when do you stop crawling?

[09:53:03.0000] <LoneStar99>
Philip': i makes things look anti-aliasing

[09:54:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
tantek: http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/microdata.html#associating-names-with-items

[09:54:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Dunno if this is the latest version of the cycle-breaker.  You'd have to ask foolip, or get Hixie.

[09:55:00.0000] <tantek>
ah - ok: If root is in memory, then the algorithm fails; abort these steps.

[09:55:01.0000] <tantek>
therefore microdata effectively makes referencing an id of an ancestor a NOP

[09:56:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
If the ancestor is already part of the item, yes.

[09:56:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
If it's an ancestor in the DOM, higher up than the start of the item, though, then should be okay.

[09:56:02.0000] <tantek>
sure

[09:56:03.0000] <tantek>
microformats include-pattern has the same restriction

[09:57:00.0000] <tantek>
but I didn't see it in the W3C microdata draft

[09:57:01.0000] <tantek>
so I wondered if Ian had somehow permitted itemref inclusion of ancestors

[09:57:02.0000] <tantek>
apparently not

[09:57:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Is that algo in the w3c draft, or are the two versions differeing significantly?

[09:58:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
Philip': Maybe not, the drawImage stuff does nothing from i can see

[09:59:00.0000] <tantek>
TabAtkins - the w3c draft says the same: http://www.w3.org/TR/microdata/#associating-names-with-items

[09:59:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
kk.

[09:59:02.0000] <tantek>
I just didn't find it because it doesn't reference itemref explicitly

[09:59:03.0000] <tantek>
itemref on an ancestor being a NOP is a side effect you have to figure out from the algo

[09:59:04.0000] <tantek>
rather than being explicit

[09:59:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes.

[09:59:06.0000] <tantek>
which is going to confuse authors

[10:00:00.0000] <tantek>
when they ask why doesn't this work

[10:00:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
The simple and obvious answer would be "because that would make an infinite loop, don't do that".

[10:00:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
You don't need to point them at the algo for that.

[10:02:00.0000] <tantek>
much better to describe it up front IMHO

[10:02:01.0000] <tantek>
e.g.

[10:02:02.0000] <tantek>
http://microformats.org/wiki/include-pattern#in_general

[10:02:03.0000] <tantek>
To prevent infinite loops, if a class="include" refers to itself or to an ancestor in the parse tree, then it is ignored and has no effect on the parser.

[10:02:04.0000] <LoneStar99>
are there any webOS developers here?

[10:03:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
tantek: But the situation is more subtle with microdata, because it permits reference to ancestors; it merely prevents such a reference from causing an infinite loop.

[10:03:01.0000] <tantek>
LoneStar99 try #webkit

[10:04:00.0000] <tantek>
TabAtkins - not true - the ancestor is already in memory from the parse in progress

[10:04:01.0000] <tantek>
thus the reference to ancestor immediately fails in step 1

[10:04:02.0000] <tantek>
assuming you're parsing microdata from the root of document downward

[10:05:00.0000] <tantek>
which all the "converting to ..." (insert format here) algorithms do

[10:05:01.0000] <LoneStar99>
tantek: there is a webos channel, but wanted to see if someone could see the issues i see with my code... but anyways time for lunch! thanks for all the help be back later

[10:05:02.0000] <tantek>
LoneStar99 - good to know!

[10:08:00.0000] <tantek>
btw - given that itemref causes an actual crawl of the targets of the itemref it is not really a "ref" (like href), it is more like a "src" (like <img src>)

[10:08:01.0000] <tantek>
itemsrc would more accurately convey what itemref does

[10:08:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
tantek: I believe that that algo starts by assuming the root is an item, that is, it has @itemscope.

[10:09:00.0000] <tantek>
TabAtkins - sure - but that makes no difference to the breaking of recursion

[10:09:01.0000] <tantek>
or ancestral reference

[10:09:02.0000] <tantek>
alternatively, iteminclude would also better convey what itemref does

[10:10:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
<div id=foo itemprop=foo>foo <div itemscope itemref=foo></div></div> would affect it, wouldn't it?

[10:13:00.0000] <tantek>
TabAtkins - yes - not a particularly useful case though

[10:13:01.0000] <tantek>
as typically you get a need in nested objects to refer to (include) a common parent object

[10:13:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
No, but that's the reason why Ian often forgoes prose descriptions of algos - they don't hit all cases.

[10:14:00.0000] <tantek>
sure, but then that makes it harder for authors

[10:14:01.0000] <tantek>
authors don't typically "get" the procedural descriptions of the algos

[10:14:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Indeed.

[10:15:00.0000] <tantek>
and one of the claims of microdata is that it is "easier" for authors

[10:15:01.0000] <tantek>
thus I would say that claim is refuted by this

[10:15:02.0000] <tantek>
TabAtkins - if you want to see a discussion of a real world example of nested objects referring to a parent object, /join #microformats

[10:16:00.0000] <tantek>
we're discussing hProduct + hReview there now

[10:16:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Oh, I don't doubt the use-case.  I use circularly-nested data structures all the time.

[10:16:02.0000] <tantek>
all the time?

[10:16:03.0000] <tantek>
or are you being facetious ;)

[10:16:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
No, I really do use them a lot.

[10:17:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
It's very useful to embed a reference to the parent in a child.

[10:18:00.0000] <tantek>
a reference yes. but an include no. and itemref is an include, not a reference. hence my point about terminology.

[10:18:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's valid.

[10:19:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Then suggest some accurate prose, or suggest a change to the algo to reflect the simpler prose.

[10:19:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Such as disallowing all ancestor references.

[10:19:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
/me goes to lunch.

[14:44:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
can i declare a specific URL in the explicit section that would also match a fallback namespace?

[14:44:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
like

[14:44:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
CACHE MANIFEST

[14:44:03.0000] <mpilgrim>
CACHE:

[14:44:04.0000] <mpilgrim>
images/cat.jpg

[14:45:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
FALLBACK:

[14:45:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
images/ missing.jpg

[14:45:02.0000] <Hixie>
what do you mean by "can i" exactly?

[14:46:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
will the browser cache images/cat.jpg and use it when i say <img src="images/cat.jpg"> ?

[14:46:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
the URL matches a resource listed in the explicit section, and also a fallback namespace listed in the fallback section

[14:46:02.0000] <mpilgrim>
which one wins?

[14:46:03.0000] <Hixie>
yes

[14:46:04.0000] <Hixie>
If a resource is listed in the explicit section or as a fallback entry in the fallback section, the resource will always be taken from the cache, regardless of any other matching entries in the fallback namespaces or online whitelist namespaces.

[15:04:00.0000] <Hixie>

[15:05:00.0000] <mpilgrim>

[15:08:01.0000] <Hixie>

[15:09:00.0000] <Hixie>

[15:09:01.0000] <Hixie>

[15:09:02.0000] <mpilgrim>

[15:09:03.0000] <Hixie>

[15:09:04.0000] <Hixie>

[15:09:05.0000] <Hixie>
it's basically no different than an HTTP cache

[15:10:00.0000] <mpilgrim>

[15:10:01.0000] <Hixie>

[15:10:02.0000] <Hixie>

[15:47:00.0000] <franksalim>
oh yes, i meant subprotocol. i see you were talking about http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2010-February/025280.html

[15:49:00.0000] <annevk>
well, I think the idea is that the subprotocol indicates how the data transmitted in the frame types is supposed to be processed, but I don't think the idea is that you can simply use all the frame types if you have a custom subprotocol

[15:50:00.0000] <franksalim>
I think that is correct

[15:51:00.0000] <franksalim>
Ports usually indicate the protocol, but because ws:// does not use host/port addressing, 'subprotocol' indicates the protocol instead

[15:52:00.0000] <franksalim>
Either new protocols or existing TCP protocols bound to ws

[15:52:01.0000] <annevk>
i.e. I am pretty certain we end up having distinct frame types for ByteArray and Stream and that a subprotocol cannot change the meaning of that

[15:53:00.0000] <franksalim>
annevk, so you're pretty sure we need frame types and not just a bidirectional byte stream like TCP?

[15:54:00.0000] <annevk>
yeah, exposing TCP to JavaScript directly won't fly

[15:55:00.0000] <franksalim>
for technical reasons or other reasons?

[15:58:00.0000] <annevk>
security, mostly

[15:58:01.0000] <franksalim>
I would be perfectly happy with TCP in JavaScript after the WebSocket handshake

[15:58:02.0000] <annevk>
oh I see

[15:58:03.0000] <annevk>
interesting thought

[15:59:00.0000] <annevk>

[15:59:01.0000] <annevk>

[15:59:02.0000] <annevk>

2010-03-06
[16:02:00.0000] <Hixie>

[16:02:01.0000] <franksalim>
annevk, ok. fwiw, JavaScript events and TCP work fine together

[16:02:02.0000] <Hixie>

[16:03:00.0000] <franksalim>

[16:03:01.0000] <Hixie>
annevk: btw i think the main source of argument on this topic is that many of the people on hybi for some reason want to use websockets for something other than browser-to-server communication

[16:03:02.0000] <Hixie>
franksalim: why?

[16:04:00.0000] <franksalim>
Hixie, how do you later XMPP over WebSocket?

[16:05:00.0000] <franksalim>
Hixie, align each XMPP stanza to a ws frame, or ignore ws frames and just send XMPP as strings?

[16:05:01.0000] <Hixie>
why would you layer XMPP over WebSocket?

[16:05:02.0000] <Hixie>
put your XMPP client on the server-side

[16:06:00.0000] <Hixie>
and then just speak an internal protocol to get the data the "last mile" from your server to the browser

[16:06:01.0000] <franksalim>
the internal protocol might as well be XMPP

[16:06:02.0000] <Hixie>
putting all the XMPP logic in the client seems like a lot of work for no reason

[16:07:00.0000] <franksalim>
it is the same amount of work as writing a new protocol that covers all of the XMPP semantics you want

[16:08:00.0000] <Hixie>
you hardly have to implement anything at all if you put the XMPP client on the WebSocket server

[16:08:01.0000] <franksalim>
and because XMPP is well known and widely interoperable, you have the option of connecting to other servers that are outside of your direct control

[16:08:02.0000] <Hixie>
wait you want your JS page to connect to arbitrary XMPP servers?!

[16:08:03.0000] <franksalim>
yes

[16:08:04.0000] <Hixie>
i suppose if you really wanted to you could do that

[16:08:05.0000] <Hixie>
dunno why you would though

[16:08:06.0000] <franksalim>
but for a moment let me pretend i am only concerned with first party servers

[16:08:07.0000] <franksalim>
and am willing to write my own protocol to go the last mile

[16:09:00.0000] <franksalim>

[16:09:01.0000] <Hixie>
no

[16:09:02.0000] <franksalim>

[16:10:00.0000] <Hixie>

[01:24:00.0000] <Lachy>
can anyone in here make any sense out of these examples? http://www.w3.org/TR/2010/WD-html-bidi-20100304/#basedirection

[01:25:00.0000] <Lachy>

[01:25:01.0000] <Lachy>
well, the 3rd one has all the letters reveresed and word order reversed, expect for "html" which has its letters in the usual order.

[01:26:00.0000] <Lachy>
but I also don't get how the second one can claim to be displayed LTR, and not just use normal english word and letter ordering.

[01:27:00.0000] <annevk>
I think there is a convention that uppercase means characters with RTL hinting or some such

[01:29:00.0000] <annevk>
and if you just have hinting it stops at word boundaries or some such instead of the entire sentence

[01:29:01.0000] <Lachy>
it would make more sense if they just used examle letters from actual RTL languages, instead of trying to confuse people with latin letters

[01:29:02.0000] <annevk>
in the bidi world the convention is pretty well established I think and it is much easier to use characters that fall within the ASCII range

[01:30:00.0000] <annevk>
also, by using characters in the ASCII range you do not get the problem that it might be displayed incorrectly because the bidi implementation is buggy

[01:30:01.0000] <annevk>
which seems important

[01:31:00.0000] <Lachy>
they could just give the examples using real RTL letters, and then provide an image with the intended rendering

[01:32:00.0000] <annevk>
it explains this even: http://www.w3.org/TR/2010/WD-html-bidi-20100304/#notation

[04:54:00.0000] <mut>

[04:57:00.0000] <Philip`>
mut: Looks like the problem is you're mixing translate and rotate in there

[04:58:00.0000] <Philip`>
If you do e.g. "translate(10, 0); rotate(180 degrees); translate(10, 0)" then the second translation is relative to the rotated origin, so you end up back where you started

[04:58:01.0000] <mut>
oh

[04:58:02.0000] <Philip`>
and it's not equivalent to "rotate(180 degrees); translate(20, 0)" which is what you get if you just accumulate all the translations

[04:58:03.0000] <mut>
errm

[04:58:04.0000] <mut>
ok think im with you

[04:59:00.0000] <mut>
oh right, so if i shift the rotates beyond the last translate

[04:59:01.0000] <mut>
gotcha

[04:59:02.0000] <mut>
:)

[05:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
Hmm, maybe you're not actually doing translate-rotate-translate but you seem to be switching between translate-rotate (in the original code) and rotate-translate (in the run2Origin code) and they're not equivalent

[05:00:01.0000] <mut>
yea im with you

[05:00:02.0000] <Philip`>
Should be okay if you're consistent about the order of operations

[05:00:03.0000] <mut>
sorted

[05:00:04.0000] <mut>
:)

[05:01:00.0000] <mut>
yea sorted that, ill just expand and make sure it works across everything

[05:02:00.0000] <mut>
thanks a lot Philip` 

[05:02:01.0000] <mut>
heh

[05:02:02.0000] <mut>
saved my bacon

2010-03-07
[04:26:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
AryehGregor: if you around, I wanted to ask if/how template pages can be created in mediawiki

[04:27:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
oh, just Template*, I guess?

[08:53:00.0000] <webben>
Magical1: http://www.w3.org/WAI/PF/aria-practices/#docmgt

[09:38:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
MikeSmith, any page can be used as a template in MediaWiki.  If you say {{Foo:Bar}}, it will transclude the page "Foo:Bar".  The only way templates are different is that if you don't state a namespace, Template: is assumed, so {{Bar}} is the same as {{Template:Bar}}.  (You can get main-namespace pages with an explicit empty namespace, e.g., {{:Bar}}.)

[15:22:00.0000] <Bolkonskij>
hi

[07:14:01.0000] <mr_danie1>
is the following sentence in the book 'div into html5' (http://diveintohtml5.org/) book really true:

[07:14:02.0000] <mr_danie1>
...The HTTP header is the preferred method, and it overrides the <meta> tag if present....

[07:15:00.0000] <mr_danie1>
you can find it in this page: http://diveintohtml5.org/semantics.html#encoding

[07:15:01.0000] <mr_danie1>
I thought the reason why the <meta charset=...> tag is available is because most authores CANNOT set the http content-type header

[07:16:00.0000] <mr_danie1>
but when the http content-type header, which could be wrong', overwrites any authors attempt to alter the charset, the <meta charset=...> wouldn't make sense

[07:17:00.0000] <boblet>
Philip`: aah nice, thanks

[07:17:01.0000] <mr_danie1>
I think this must be a typo in the book. can someone confirm this?

[07:17:02.0000] <boblet>
mr_danie1: I was under the impression that http header > meta charset

[07:18:00.0000] <workmad3>
mr_danie1: I think the book is correct

[07:18:01.0000] <workmad3>
http header outranks the meta charset

[07:18:02.0000] <Philip`>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/parsing.html#determining-the-character-encoding

[07:18:03.0000] <boblet>
mr_danie1: http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-validator/2008Mar/0024.html

[07:18:04.0000] <boblet>
heh

[07:18:05.0000] <Philip`>
"1. If the transport layer specifies an encoding, and it is supported, return that encoding with the confidence certain, and abort these steps."

[07:19:00.0000] <Philip`>
(where HTTP is a transport layer, and specifies encodings via Content-Type)

[07:23:00.0000] <workmad3>
mr_danie1: in the case where the server is serving data that it doesn't know the content type for, it should omit the content-type header completely I believe

[07:23:01.0000] <workmad3>
rather than send a false type that will be taken as exact

[07:24:00.0000] <mr_danie1>
I think  meta charset > http header would be better, for example: the server sets content-type:charset=utf-8, but the author sets <meta charset=iso-...

[07:24:01.0000] <mr_danie1>
and when the http header, the content will be displayed wrong, because the content is iso-...

[07:25:00.0000] <mr_danie1>
...http header WIN, the...

[07:25:01.0000] <Philip`>
mr_danie1: Can't do that because it would be incompatible with all current browsers

[07:25:02.0000] <workmad3>
mr_danie1: if the server is sending an incorrect content type, the server has a bug

[07:25:03.0000] <Philip`>
and probably incompatible with lots of current pages

[07:26:00.0000] <workmad3>
or is configured incorrectly... either way, it's not a problem with the standard

[07:26:01.0000] <Philip`>
You should always use UTF-8 anyway :-)

[07:26:02.0000] <mr_danie1>
ok, so html5 must use this policy because of its 'incremental html improvement' approach not to break the current web

[07:26:03.0000] <mr_danie1>
workmad3: true, then the server has a problem

[07:27:00.0000] <workmad3>
also, I believe in a lot of cases, it's the <meta charset= that is incorrect, because it was set on old content that has since been re-encoded

[07:27:01.0000] <mr_danie1>
Philip`: true, utf-8 is my favourite; it hate encoding issues, especially when I work in a team with lot of people

[07:27:02.0000] <Philip`>
mr_danie1: Yes, and also because it's probably better for the server to be authoritative

[07:28:00.0000] <workmad3>
and (checking the wiki page on http encodings) it looks like <meta> content types should be used by the server, not the browser

[07:28:01.0000] <Philip`>
You already have to trust the server to tell you the content is text/html rather than image/png or whatever, so it'd be odd if you trusted it to say the "content-type: text/html" part but not the "; charset=utf-8" part

[07:29:00.0000] <Philip`>
workmad3: ?

[07:29:01.0000] <Philip`>
Servers shouldn't be parsing HTML

[07:29:02.0000] <workmad3>
'A known misconception about <meta http-equiv="Content-Type">  is that meta element is intended to be interpreted directly by a browser, like an ordinary HTML tag. According to WWW Consortium, it helps HTTP server[1]  to generate some headers when it serves the document.'

[07:30:00.0000] <workmad3>
that said, it's a wiki page... it could easily be incorrect :)

[07:30:01.0000] <Philip`>
I assume that was the original intention, hence it being called "http-equiv" and being equivalent to HTTP headers, but that's crazy and not how it works today

[07:31:00.0000] <workmad3>
it does seem to gel with the description here as well though: http://www.w3.org/TR/html401/struct/global.html#edef-META

[07:31:01.0000] <Philip`>
Indeed, but HTML4 is crazy and doesn't reflect reality either

[07:32:00.0000] <workmad3>
heh :)

[07:37:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Imagine how fun it would be if every web server had its own HTML parser

[07:38:00.0000] <workmad3>
Dashiva: how about if web servers sniffed the browser types and rewrote the HTML they were serving to be compatible? :D

[07:39:00.0000] <Philip`>
Most web pages are generated dynamically and all the headers are output before any content, so it wouldn't even be possible to parse it and add headers

[07:41:00.0000] <asmodai>
annevk: Can you elaborate why it was a deliberate decision btw? (complex ruby)

[07:41:01.0000] <workmad3>
it's all just crazy anyway... encoding issues only exist because people were insane, and they turn sane people into insane people even now

[07:45:00.0000] <annevk>
asmodai, I believe that nobody really requested more than what IE already supported

[07:48:00.0000] <Philip`>
workmad3: I don't think it's because people were insane - it was logical and sensible to invent all sorts of 8-bit encodings when computers rarely communicated with each other (and especially not internationally), to suit their particular needs

[07:48:01.0000] <Philip`>
and then it was necessary to continue supporting them for legacy compatibility

[07:49:00.0000] <Philip`>
which results in all these encoding issues

[07:50:00.0000] <workmad3>
Philip`: maybe... I'll stick with my 'people are insane' view though, it justifies me cursing encodings more ;)

[07:50:01.0000] <Philip`>
I'm not saying people aren't insane, just saying that there's other reasons for this situation :-)

[07:51:00.0000] <asmodai>
annevk: ah ok

[07:51:01.0000] <Philip`>
and insanity seems a reasonable explanation for why people continue to expose themselves to encoding issues even if they can avoid it (like when inventing new formats and languages), instead of sticking with Unicode internally and UTF-8 externally and not having to worry about it

[07:51:02.0000] <asmodai>
annevk: I now feel like a proxy XD

[09:31:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
anybody remember what as the rationale for not making the <rb> element conforming?

[09:31:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
just for simplification?

[09:32:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
if there is existing content that uses <rb> and that works as expected in IE, it would seem counter-productive to make such content invalid in HTML5

[09:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
MikeSmith: I believe it's not supported in IE

[09:39:00.0000] <Philip`>
(or it's no more supported than the <thisdoesnotexist> tag)

[09:39:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[09:39:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
I guess the issue is that IE does not object to it

[09:39:03.0000] <Philip`>

[09:39:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
I see

[09:40:00.0000] <Philip`>
http://philip.html5.org/demos/html/ruby/wild-examples.html

[09:40:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
/me looks now

[09:42:00.0000] <Philip`>
I'd guess the reason for excluding is simplification - there's no point requiring people to do something that's unnecessary, and making it optional is adding needless complexity for authors

[09:42:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Philip`: I see

[09:43:00.0000] <Philip`>
though I don't see any explicit rationale in the mailing lists, other than stating it's unnecessary and IE doesn't support it

[09:43:01.0000] <Philip`>
Also it doesn't seem a very widely used feature so it doesn't hurt too much to make current uses non-conforming

[09:44:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
that's always a judgement call, I guess

[09:44:01.0000] <Philip`>
(Apparently I saw it on 0.3% of .jp sites in dmoz.org)

[09:45:00.0000] <Philip`>
It's nowhere near as numerically significant as making e.g. <br/> conforming

[09:45:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
I see enough instances of <rb> in that sample at least that I am inclined to think that by prohibiting we are going to risk frustrating and confuseing a significant number sites that are already using it

[09:45:02.0000] <Philip`>
and people still argued for keeping the syntax simpler in that case

[09:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
MikeSmith: I expect confusion could be alleviated by validators printing a message saying "the <rb> tag is unnecessary and not permitted in HTML5 - remove the tags and your page will work just fine" rather than just "invalid element <rb>"

[09:52:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Philip`: yeah, that we can do

[09:53:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and our contract is with users is not that we are guaranteeing that everything that was valid in HTML4 or XHTML1 will continue to be valid in HTML5

[12:23:00.0000] <Hixie>
MikeSmithX: .3% iirc is almost as low as the number of pages that use <image>, and we're not making _that_ conforming :-P

[14:59:00.0000] <Hixie>
i'm looking at the empty attribute thread

[14:59:01.0000] <sicking>

[14:59:02.0000] <Hixie>
the one talking about not fetching things for <Script src="">, etc

[14:59:03.0000] <sicking>
ah

[14:59:04.0000] <knowtheory>
thanks Hixie

[14:59:05.0000] <sicking>
