[14:59:06.0000] <Hixie>
if we make <script src=""> not fetch anything, should we also make it non-conforming?

[14:59:07.0000] <Hixie>
and does that mean <script src=""> and <script src=" "> would be different from each other?

[15:00:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: i don't feel strongly on conforming vs. non-conforming

[15:00:01.0000] <Hixie>
(<script src=" "> is non-conforming currently)

[15:00:02.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: is whitespace generally trimmed from these attributes?

[15:00:03.0000] <Hixie>
(but it does result in a fetch, which would make it different)

[15:00:04.0000] <Hixie>
well when resolving the url it is

[15:00:05.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: i.e. what does " " do currently?

[15:00:06.0000] <Hixie>
not sure what you mean by "generally"

[15:01:00.0000] <Hixie>
" " resolves to the base URL

[15:01:01.0000] <knowtheory>
do CSS Animations actually have a formal relationship to the HTML5 spec?  Or is it a detail of browser implementation, that CSS Animations would be included w/ HTML5?

[15:01:02.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: why does it resolve to the baseurl?

[15:01:03.0000] <Hixie>
knowtheory: CSS animations are part of CSS, nothing to do with HTML

[15:01:04.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: wouldn't it convert to "%20" which is appended to the base?

[15:01:05.0000] <Hixie>
sicking: spaces get trimmed first

[15:01:06.0000] <knowtheory>
Hixie: cool, just wanted to make sure i wasn't like way off base.

[15:02:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: ah, for relative urls? Or for all values of the attribute?

[15:02:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'm loathe to make "" invalid everywhere given that it's a valid URL, but making it invalid only in some places is a bit weird...

[15:02:02.0000] <Hixie>
all values

[15:02:03.0000] <sicking>
/me ponders

[15:02:04.0000] <Hixie>
the "web addresses" stuff, assuming larry gets around to fixing it properly, trims spaces before resolving urls

[15:03:00.0000] <Hixie>
seems like making <a href="">foo</a> invalid is a bit weird

[15:03:01.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: ok, from an implementation point of view, i'd prefer to just tread "" special. I.e. "" != " ". The former does nothing, the latter fetches the base url

[15:03:02.0000] <Hixie>
but making <script src=""> valid but not do anything is also weird...

[15:03:03.0000] <Hixie>
oh i agree that "" should be special, not in any way suggesting we make " " be handled differently

[15:04:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's the conformance aspects of this i'm struggling with

[15:04:01.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: on the validity issue i don't feel strongly. I agree both options are weird in different ways

[15:05:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: one argument is that it might actually be convenient for authors to be able to use <script src="">

[15:05:01.0000] <Hixie>
if we make "" invalid for external-resource <link>s, <link rel="stylesheet index" href=""> would be simultaneously valid and invalid, which is confusing as all hell

[15:06:00.0000] <Hixie>
but if we make it valid, then <link rel=stylesheet href=""> would be valid but would not have the effect it should have given the url ""

[15:06:01.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: as to avoid having to do <%if ($bar) {%><script src="<%$bar%>"></script><%}%>

[15:07:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: yeah, i agree with your argument too

[15:08:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: politically it might be easier to make it invalid

[15:08:01.0000] <Hixie>
i'm not worried about the politics

[15:08:02.0000] <othermaciej>
really? document validity tends to be more political than implementation conformance

[15:08:03.0000] <Hixie>
it's the usability of the language i'm worried about

[15:09:00.0000] <sicking>
then i would say don't make it invalid

[15:09:01.0000] <sicking>
to avoid forcing authors to use the complex syntax above

[15:09:02.0000] <Hixie>
having <link rel="stylesheet index" href=""> create just one link but <link rel="stylesheet index" href="#"> create two is very confusing

[15:09:03.0000] <Hixie>
imhio

[15:09:04.0000] <Hixie>
imho, even

[15:09:05.0000] <sicking>
though, i guess you could also argue that <script src=""> is likely a bug, and thus we'd help people by making it invalid so that the validator highlights the bug

[15:10:00.0000] <Hixie>
that was the argument for making it not fetch anything in the first palce

[15:10:01.0000] <Hixie>
place

[15:10:02.0000] <Hixie>
that it was always a bug

[15:10:03.0000] <sicking>
true

[15:10:04.0000] <sicking>
ok, make it invalid then :)

[15:10:05.0000] <Hixie>
is <a href="">foo</a> always a bug? maybe i should just make all empty URLs invalid

[15:11:00.0000] <sicking>
good question

[15:11:01.0000] <Hixie>
having some be invalid and some not is very poor form

[15:11:02.0000] <sicking>
well.. i don't think there are any good solutions here

[15:11:03.0000] <sicking>
so we'll have to pick one bad solution

[15:12:00.0000] <Hixie>
if we're picking bad solutions, it seems like making "" actually fetch the local page is the least bad solution from a usability perspective

[15:12:01.0000] <sicking>
why?

[15:12:02.0000] <Hixie>
it makes the language self-consistent and predictable

[15:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
we could say that if you refer to the local page that the UA must use the cached copy always

[15:13:01.0000] <sicking>
that seems like picking language purity over author friendlyness

[15:13:02.0000] <Hixie>
"purity"?

[15:13:03.0000] <Hixie>
it's picking author friendliness over server load friendliness

[15:13:04.0000] <sicking>
authors are generally in charge of server load. so the distinction doesn't make sense IMHO

[15:13:05.0000] <Hixie>
if we say that if you refer to the local page that the UA must use the cached copy always, it doesn't even affect the load, which would be good

[15:14:00.0000] <sicking>
i.e. you'd be hurting the same guy as you're helping

[15:14:01.0000] <Hixie>
granted

[15:14:02.0000] <sicking>
and probably hurting him more than helping

[15:14:03.0000] <Hixie>
but if we use the cache we're not hurting at all

[15:14:04.0000] <Hixie>
while still being predictable

[15:14:05.0000] <sicking>
there isn't always a cache around

[15:14:06.0000] <Hixie>
well, in those cases we can hurt, i guess

[15:14:07.0000] <Hixie>
there usually is

[15:15:00.0000] <sicking>
that doesn't seem to be true for <img src="">

[15:15:01.0000] <sicking>
given that many browsers gave that special treatment

[15:15:02.0000] <Hixie>
what isn't true?

[15:15:03.0000] <sicking>
that there is a cached copy around

[15:15:04.0000] <Hixie>
i don't see why the browser behaviour indicates that one way or the other

[15:16:00.0000] <Hixie>
it's just easier to implement "do nothing" than "fetch from the cache and then do nothing because HTML isn't an image format"

[15:16:01.0000] <sicking>
browsers implemented an exception because there was a detectable difference

[15:16:02.0000] <Hixie>
by "browsers" you mean FF and Opera

[15:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
all the other browsers fetch the image, according to the data collected in this thread

[15:17:01.0000] <sicking>
ah, thought it was more

[15:17:02.0000] <Hixie>
in fact it's one of the few cases where IE does fetch the URL -- most of hte time it doesn't if it's ""

[15:18:00.0000] <sicking>
i still don't see how we're helping anyone by saying it should be fetched from cache

[15:18:01.0000] <sicking>
also, how is "should fetch from cache" different than not saying so? No browsers that i know of fetch from the network for the heck of it

[15:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
well if fetching from the cache doesn't reduce the load, it's not clear to me why there's a problem here

[15:19:01.0000] <sicking>
so staying silent on the issue would result in the same browser behavior as far as i can see

[15:19:02.0000] <sicking>
huh?

[15:19:03.0000] <sicking>
fetching from the cache would reduce the load

[15:19:04.0000] <Hixie>
right now, many browsers fetch something in these "" cases. I'm saying we should make it not fetch anything new but just use the available data instead. That seems like it would reduce the load, which is the stated problem.

[15:20:00.0000] <sicking>
but obviously at least firefox, opera and yahoo felt that the cache didn't reduce the load enough

[15:20:01.0000] <daedb_>
Why would any author want to use empty src/href? That does not look sane to me :)

[15:20:02.0000] <Hixie>
i dunno about "obviously"

[15:20:03.0000] <sicking>
firefox and opera obviously since they implemented it

[15:21:00.0000] <sicking>
yahoo in general i agree. This guy from yahoo obviously since he spent a lot of time figuring this out while developing the site

[15:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
i think you're drawing conclusions from the data that aren't warranted -- e.g. opera's behaviour could be a random bug.

[15:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
anyway, let's start from the beginning

[15:22:00.0000] <Hixie>
the problem is that authors say src="", data="", etc, but don't mean to

[15:22:01.0000] <Hixie>
yet they (presumably) say <a href=""> and _do_ mean to

[15:22:02.0000] <Hixie>
we ideally would want to catch the errors but not flag the intentional cases

[15:22:03.0000] <Hixie>
we ideally would want to not fetch data from the network for the error cases

[15:23:00.0000] <Hixie>
we have certain language features where a single href="" can be in both situations at the same time, namely <link rel="stylesheet index" href="">

[15:23:01.0000] <sicking>
practically speaking though, when would that markup ever make sense?

[15:24:00.0000] <sicking>
given that i can't think of a case when it would, I don't care very much what the spec says about it

[15:24:01.0000] <sicking>
(i only care enough that i don't want to write a bunch of code to handle it, as that is effectively dead code)

[15:24:02.0000] <Hixie>
<link rel="prefetch next" href=""> might, especially with scripting involved

[15:25:00.0000] <sicking>
neither "prefetch" or "next" is on the list of suggested changes though, is it?

[15:25:01.0000] <Hixie>
"prefetch" is

[15:25:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's an external resource link

[15:26:00.0000] <sicking>
true

[15:26:01.0000] <Hixie>
and who knows what future external resource links might be invented

[15:26:02.0000] <sicking>
ok, so what is your point?

[15:27:00.0000] <Hixie>
no point, i was just describing the problem

[15:27:01.0000] <Hixie>
for daedb_'s benefit

[15:28:00.0000] <sicking>
it seems to me that everyone in that thread agreed on what UA behavior should be

[15:28:01.0000] <sicking>
so IMHO we should spec that behavior

[15:28:02.0000] <Hixie>
there's also the mildly interesting case of (XML) <img xml:base="...image..." src="" alt=.../>

[15:28:03.0000] <ap>
Hixie: <https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=30303>, if you want more opinions on the topic

[15:28:04.0000] <sicking>
the question of conformance has not been treated though

[15:28:05.0000] <sicking>
i don't have a strong opinion on that

[15:29:00.0000] <sicking>
though I think that in general things that are extremely likely to be bugs should be non-conforming

[15:29:01.0000] <Hixie>
ap: reading...

[15:29:02.0000] <sicking>
as a rule of thumb

[15:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
i guess we could make <a href="" rel=next> valid but <link href="" rel=next> invalid

[15:31:00.0000] <Hixie>
and most authors wouldn't run into it

[15:34:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: sounds ok to me

[15:36:00.0000] <Hixie>
should <script src=""></script> fire onload or onerror or neither?

[15:36:01.0000] <Hixie>
and if an event is fired, should it be fired synchronously or asynchronously when parsing?

[15:37:00.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: i'd say fire onerror. To keep the consistency that onload or onerror is always fired

[15:37:01.0000] <sicking>
Hixie: and fire asynch, to keep that consistency that all events are async

[15:37:02.0000] <sicking>
IMHO

[15:38:00.0000] <Hixie>
events with <script> aren't always async

[15:39:00.0000] <Hixie>
e.g. <script>document.write('<script onload="alert(1)">alert(0)<\/script>');alert(2);</script> per spec

[15:40:00.0000] <Hixie>
mind you either firefox nor safari fire that event at all as far as i can tell

[15:41:00.0000] <Hixie>
actually no browser seems to

[15:41:01.0000] <Hixie>
huh

[15:41:02.0000] <othermaciej>
spec bug?

[15:42:00.0000] <Hixie>
unclear

[15:42:01.0000] <Hixie>
i think firing onload in that case was an intentional addition

[15:42:02.0000] <Hixie>
not sure about the sync vs async

[15:47:00.0000] <Hixie>
ok i made it async in the internal case

[15:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
should <embed type="application/plugin" src=""> instantiate the plugin based on the type="" attribute, or not at all?

[15:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
i'll follow <object> and make <embed src=""> do nothing

[15:56:01.0000] <Hixie>
er, <embed src="" type="..."> that is

[00:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:35:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:35:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[00:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:10:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, could you say that if a URL resolves to the current resource, and the user agent knows that a text/html response will cause an error, it can decline to fetch the resource even if it's not actually in cache, on the assumption that it will be text/html?  (Similar for XML MIME types.)

[09:12:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
As for validation, surely something somewhere already says that script/stylesheet/etc. links must point to documents of the correct type.  E.g., if <script src=""></script> points to a text/html file, then that violates the sentence "If the language is not that described by "text/javascript", then the type attribute must be present, as described below."

[09:12:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
So a validator could recognize that "" is not a text/javascript resource and raise an error.

[09:15:00.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: Some people (like hsivonen, I think) don't like the validity of a document depending on external resources

[09:16:00.0000] <Philip`>
It makes it really hard to check that a document is valid and that it stays valid

[09:16:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
You can't check all validity requirements anyway.

[09:16:02.0000] <Philip`>
(and you'd get different results when copying-and-pasting into a text input box vs pointing at the URL)

[09:16:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hmm, true.

[09:16:04.0000] <Philip`>
That's not a reason to add more requirements that can't be checked

[09:17:00.0000] <Philip`>
particularly since it's a lot of complexity for something that nobody is going to do on purpose

[09:17:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
The requirement already exists, I'm not suggesting it be added.  :)

[09:17:02.0000] <Philip`>
s/particularly since/Also,/

[09:17:03.0000] <Philip`>
Oh, okay

[09:17:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Validators that don't want to depend on whether you copy-paste or point at the URL can implement only special cases of this check -- like saying it's an error only if the URL resolves to the current document, but HTML is the wrong type for the link.

[09:18:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Which is the current case.

[09:19:00.0000] <Philip`>
Actually, <script src=""> doesn't point to a text/html file

[09:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
because (per the spec) it doesn't resolve to anything

[09:20:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It doesn't?

[09:20:02.0000] <Philip`>
It hasn't done for at least 16 hours

[09:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
So I think that's not a problematic case, because it points at nothing and is clearly an error

[09:23:00.0000] <Philip`>
The problematic case was like <link rel="stylesheet index" href="">

[09:23:01.0000] <Philip`>
where the stylesheet link doesn't point to anything, while the index link points to the base URL

[09:24:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, I was making suggestions to Hixie based on the previous version of the spec.

[09:24:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
As an alternative fix.

[09:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
The previous version of the spec would download the current page again if you wrote <script src="">

[09:25:01.0000] <Philip`>
which was the problem

[09:25:02.0000] <Philip`>
so the fix would have to involve changing it to not download the current page again

[09:25:03.0000] <Philip`>
and so it couldn't then define validity in terms of the downloaded resource

[09:26:00.0000] <Philip`>
although I think I forgot to read what you actually said

[09:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Right.  My suggestion was that the spec say that if a URL is known to resolve to the current resource, then if that URL is used for something that's not supposed to be HTML, the UA can raise an error without bothering to actually retrieve the resource.

[09:27:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or just ignore it, or something.

[09:28:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
And validators can say it's an error if they know it resolves to the current resource.

[09:28:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I guess that's messier than just adding some special cases, but it seems less hackish.

[09:29:00.0000] <Philip`>
That seems like a lot of complexity for something that nobody is going to do on purpose

[09:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
It doesn't seem non-hackish to me, because it's still going to do weird things in hypothetical cases like a POST response page saying <script src=""> where the GET returns a different content-type

[09:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
and it'll be hard for authors to predict behaviour because it'll depend on whether the UA cached enough information about the page

[09:35:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I guess.

[00:44:00.0000] <zcorpan>
hmm, i was pondering about a potential security issue with the legacy encoding decl

[00:45:00.0000] <zcorpan>
consider a service that filters input but allows some text in a <meta name=description value=...> (or keywords)

[00:46:00.0000] <zcorpan>
attacker inserts text/html; charset=something

[00:46:01.0000] <zcorpan>
if that's after 512 bytes or 1024 bytes, it can cause scripts to execute twice

[00:47:00.0000] <zcorpan>
it can also cause the page to be interpreted in the wrong encoding, causing further problems

[00:48:00.0000] <zcorpan>
i wonder if we can kill re-navigation, and require http-equiv=content-type for the encoding decl

[00:50:00.0000] <annevk>
seems somewhat unlikely

[00:51:00.0000] <annevk>
the vulnerability is of the same level of complexity we expect people using srcdoc="" to handle just fine

[00:52:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
You guys hear about the html5 shiv problem with js?

[00:53:00.0000] <zcorpan>
annevk: i don't follow

[00:53:01.0000] <annevk>

[00:55:00.0000] <zcorpan>
annevk: the problem isn't with quoting

[00:56:00.0000] <zcorpan>
annevk: <zcorpan> attacker inserts text/html; charset=something

[00:57:00.0000] <zcorpan>
annevk: per spec, any meta is respected as an encoding decl, so it's easy to convert an innocent meta into an encoding decl without breaking out of the attribute value

[00:57:01.0000] <zcorpan>

[00:58:00.0000] <annevk>

[05:16:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[05:17:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
"A device lying flat on a horizontal surface with the top of the screen pointing West has the following orientation... theta: 90"

[05:17:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
why is that theta: -90 ?

[05:18:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
why is that not theta: -90 ?

[05:18:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
that is, why positive 90 and not negative 90?

[05:19:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
"C is perpendicular to the screen, positive out of the screen... rotate the device frame around its C axis by theta degrees, with theta in [0, 360)"

[05:20:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
MikeSmith: Because it's been rotated 90 degrees in the positive direction (CCW).

[05:20:01.0000] <annevk>
it follows from that it cannot be negative

[05:20:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
TabAtkins: CCW is positive?

[05:20:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Yes.

[05:20:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Always has been.

[05:20:05.0000] <MikeSmith>
oh.

[05:20:06.0000] <MikeSmith>
dint know that

[05:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Standard rules of angles is that CCW is positive, and the 0 angle is to the east.

[05:21:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
(When directionality is important, as well as simple magnitude of change.)

[05:21:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
damn I'm ig'nant

[05:22:00.0000] <annevk>

[05:22:01.0000] <annevk>

[05:22:02.0000] <annevk>

[05:23:00.0000] <annevk>

[05:24:00.0000] <Philip`>
TabAtkins: I'd be cautious in calling any geometry conventions a "standard" :-)

[05:24:01.0000] <Philip`>
People can't even decide which handedness to use for axes, or which way around to write matrices

[05:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
That orientation spec says "Positive rotation around an axis is defined as clockwise when viewed along the positive direction of the axis."

[05:26:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
oh, handedness... this is ringing a bell now, thumbs-up, positive is in direction of the way fingers curl

[05:26:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
so something like that

[05:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
MikeSmith: The spec says C is perpendicular to the screen and outwards, so if the screen is lying flat on its back then C is vertically upwards

[05:28:01.0000] <Philip`>
so you have to look along the upwards direction

[05:28:02.0000] <Philip`>
i.e. from beneath

[05:28:03.0000] <Philip`>
and then rotate clockwise (for positive angles)

[05:28:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
ah

[05:28:05.0000] <Philip`>
which is equivalent to anticlockwise when you're looking down on it

[05:29:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
I see

[05:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
(and you start with the screen lying flat on its back with the top pointing North)

[05:31:01.0000] <Philip`>
(and rotate around C first)

[05:31:02.0000] <Philip`>
(so that's the right way to turn it to make its top point West)

[05:31:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[08:58:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[09:00:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[09:00:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
after FPWD, WG members have 5 months to either disclose or default to licensing freely if not 

[09:01:00.0000] <othermaciej>
FPWD and LCWD trigger patent review and disclosure obligations

[09:02:00.0000] <annevk>
until REC they can still sue afaik

[09:02:01.0000] <annevk>
http://www.w3.org/Consortium/Patent-Policy-20040205/#sec-Requirements

[09:02:02.0000] <othermaciej>
technically I think the obligation to actually license is not until REC

[09:02:03.0000] <annevk>
indeed

[09:02:04.0000] <annevk>
which makes the policy somewhat incompatible with how specs are made

[09:03:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hmm, yeah

[09:03:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
or, rather, I should say, I can understand it being seen that way

[09:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the potentially problematic part is that we call for implementations at CR, but patents may not be licensed until REC

[10:02:00.0000] <gsnedders>
Challenge: teach me about pointers in C++.

[10:02:01.0000] <jgraham>
gsnedders: I'm not sure they're as complex as you think

[10:11:00.0000] <Philip`>
gsnedders: They're memory addresses

[10:11:01.0000] <Philip`>
That's all you need to know, and you can deduce the rest

[10:14:00.0000] <zcorpan>
Philip`: you think you could find pages that have a <meta> that could be interpreted as an encoding decl but doesn't have http-equiv=content-type?

[10:17:00.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: Presumably you also need to know that they are typed

[10:25:00.0000] <jgraham>
(unless you are using a weird language like IDL -- Interactive Data Language, not the other one -- of course. But the less said about that the better)

[10:25:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
gsnedders: What Philip` said, plus pointers are often used to gain pass-by-reference behavior when only pass-by-value is allowed.

[10:26:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
That is, passing a pointer as an argument to a function allows you to pass large data structures around without copying them, and allows you to modify them in functionally-impure ways.

[10:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: True - you need to know they're memory addresses, and (intptr_t)((T*)p+1) == (intptr_t)p+sizeof(T), and you can deduce the rest

[10:29:00.0000] <Philip`>
zcorpan: Maybe, but it depends on exactly what that means and whether it's easy to code

[10:31:00.0000] <gsnedders>
http://pastebin.com/NhuD82La

[10:31:01.0000] <gsnedders>
How does that crash?

[10:32:00.0000] <Philip`>
You should run it in Valgrind

[10:32:01.0000] <Philip`>
which tells you useful things about pointer errors

[10:32:02.0000] <Philip`>
In this case, p1 etc are uninitialised values

[10:33:00.0000] <Philip`>
so they contain random garbage (whatever happened to be on the stack)

[10:33:01.0000] <Philip`>
which is interpreted as a memory address (because pointers are memory addresses)

[10:33:02.0000] <Philip`>
and when you try to write something to the content of that memory address (*p1 = ...) it writes to a garbage location

[10:52:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Which most likely means the program tries writing to a page that's not in its page tables, so the CPU raises a fault, and the OS sees you're doing something crazy and decides to put you down for your own good.

[10:53:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
You need to ensure that p1 points to something first, like: p1 = malloc(sizeof p1); or something (my C isn't very good).

[10:53:01.0000] <Philip`>
That would allocate the size of the pointer, not the size of the pointee

[10:54:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Rats.

[10:54:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
p1 = malloc(sizeof int); then.

[10:54:02.0000] <Philip`>
Better to do int* p1 = new int;

[10:54:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
malloc() will pick a memory address on the heap where there's enough free space, note internally that the memory is being used, and return the address at the start of the allocated block.

[10:54:04.0000] <Philip`>
since this is C++

[10:54:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, if you're using C++.

[10:54:06.0000] <Philip`>
gsnedders said C++ :-)

[10:54:07.0000] <AryehGregor>
So he did.

[10:55:00.0000] <Philip`>
He could have been lying, though

[10:55:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyway, so do int *p1 = new int; int *p2 = new int; int *p3 = new int; or whatever, then you can use them largely as you expect as long as you put * before them whenever you use them.

[10:56:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Except that they're allocated on the heap, not the stack, so for instance, you can return the pointer from a function safely.

[10:56:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
And allocate very large things to them.  And if you don't delete them later, you've caused a memory leak.

[10:58:00.0000] <Philip`>
You can return ints from a function safely too :-p

[10:59:00.0000] <Philip`>
Oh, I guess you mean like "int* f() { int x = 25; int* y = &x; return y; }"

[10:59:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Well, you can return auto-generated copies of ints safely.

[11:00:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, yes.  I'm not entirely sure why you'd want a pointer to an int to begin with.  But they're essential for things like structs.

[11:01:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, returning a copy of an int costs less than returning a pointer to it, so it's not really a useful distinction in the case of ints.

[13:19:00.0000] <LoneStar99>

[13:20:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
want the box to drag along, so that a user knows where the cursor is....

[13:20:01.0000] <LoneStar99>
like a red box

[13:21:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Use mousemove to track the position of the cursor

[13:22:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Each frame, draw the content and then draw the square at the stored cursor position

[13:22:01.0000] <LoneStar99>
yeah got that, confused on if the "box" should be a drawing or "css" box...

[13:25:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
If you want it to be part of the <canvas>, should be a drawing.  If you're fine with it being a separate overlay, "css box".

[13:28:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
The "make an element overlay the <canvas>" approach has the advantage that you don't need to redraw the canvas just to make the box follow the mouse, but if you're redrawing the canvas anyway, it doesn't really matter.

[13:31:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
would I need two canvas elements one for the "drawing" as in http://devfiles.myopera.com/articles/649/example2.html  and the other for the "red box cursor?"  

[13:35:00.0000] <LoneStar99>
ok i think I need two canvas elements... one that draws the red box only once and the other that draws the dynamic drawing

[13:56:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
LoneStar99: You could do that, but it's not necessary.  The <canvas> is just a big box for you to draw everything in.  You have to handle ensuring that you draw the red box last, but you can certainly do so in the same canvas as your other drawing.

[13:57:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[13:58:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[13:58:01.0000] <LoneStar99>

[13:58:02.0000] <LoneStar99>
sorry canvas

[13:58:03.0000] <TabAtkins>

[13:58:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
LoneStar99: Sure, though you have to handle that yourself.  <canvas> does not have any native idea of 'layers'.

[13:58:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
(Though you can fake it with multiple <canvas>es put on top of each other, as you suggested.)

[13:59:00.0000] <LoneStar99>

[13:59:01.0000] <LoneStar99>
let me try that

[13:59:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Within a single <canvas>, though, you just have to keep track of drawing order by yourself, and ensure that things on higher "layers" get drawn after things on lower ones.

[23:30:01.0000] <othermaciej>
so nothing will be "implemented in html5"

[23:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if you're asking whether the WebGL spec will be incorporated into the HTML5 specification, rather than being published as a separate specification by a different standards body, I believe the answer is "no".

[23:31:02.0000] <Tripknotix>

[23:32:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[05:41:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[05:41:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[05:42:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[05:43:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[05:44:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[05:44:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[05:46:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[05:46:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[05:46:02.0000] <othermaciej>

2010-03-15
[17:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
It's also the sound of people rediscovering bugs they'd forgotten about and deciding they shouldn't be allowed to die quietly

[17:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me wonders what CCN is

[17:03:01.0000] <Philip`>
(in relation to http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/public-html-bugzilla/2010Mar/0764.html)

[17:04:00.0000] <Philip`>
Oh, I guess it's http://www.ccnx.org/

[17:05:00.0000] <Dashiva>
It refers to http://lists.w3.org/Archives/Public/www-tag/2009Sep/0055.html at least

[17:05:01.0000] <Philip`>
Hmm, I think I saw Van Jacobson talking about that but I can't remember anything about it :-/

[17:05:02.0000] <Dashiva>
"content-centric networking" sounds like a buzzword without much real substance

[17:06:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me should have paid more attention, if it's going to replace IP

[17:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
Since he's one of the main developers of TCP, I think he knows a bit about the substance of networking

[17:09:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Lots of failed projects were done by people with excellent technical skills

[17:10:00.0000] <Dashiva>
These use cases seem to focus on money and control, with a little attribution on the side

[17:11:00.0000] <Philip`>
I believe it's "content-centric" because you care more about the content than about where it comes from - e.g. instead of sending packets to an IP address, you send requests to a content identifier and it can be satisfied by any router that has cached that content, or else it'll be forwarded towards a more authoritative source for that data

[17:12:00.0000] <Dashiva>
"We expect that most organizations will have a way to intake GPL code." :)

[17:12:01.0000] <Dashiva>
They've made a custom binary encoding of XML...

[17:14:00.0000] <Philip`>
(and you route based on longest-prefix matches of the content identifier, so it can efficiently handle hierarchical naming schemes but isn't strictly constrainted to a hierarchy, so it still gives freedom to separate content from location)

[17:16:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I wonder how they plan to translate from user desires to interest messages

[17:18:00.0000] <Philip`>
Users click desirable links on web pages which link to the content name, I'd guess

[17:18:01.0000] <Philip`>
or programs generate them automatically

[17:18:02.0000] <Philip`>
just like they do with URLs today

[17:19:00.0000] <Philip`>
only without today's underlying layers that collapse the whole rich URL structure into a 4-byte address of a host that contains that content

[17:20:00.0000] <Dashiva>
It seems like they're pulling the search engines into the transport layer

[17:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
Why does it seem like that?

[17:21:01.0000] <Philip`>
/me sees it as more like routing on URLs (plus caches and security)

[17:22:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Well, if the search engines remain a necessary part of the system, what is gained from losing the location-dependency?

[17:22:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Search results already span different locations

[17:22:02.0000] <Philip`>
(going by the CoNEXT paper at least)

[17:22:03.0000] <Dashiva>
P2P networks handle distributed downloads too

[17:24:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I'm watching a video presentation, he says they're NOT Google. That they do the inverse. Google is "content to names", they are "names to content"

[17:24:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Seems 'content' is rather overloaded as a term here

[17:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
If you use some extra service like a search engine to map identifiers onto locations, then higher layers don't have to worry about locations and you've got an emulation of location-independence and that should work okay

[17:25:01.0000] <Philip`>
but it'd be awfully inefficient since it's layered on top of an internet that's fundamentally designed around locations

[17:26:00.0000] <Philip`>
and you'd have to do a lot more communication than if the underlying layers were designed to support that properly

[17:27:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Doing a near-broadcast interest message, and then all the possible responders have to manage to alert each other so only one (ideally) responds

[17:27:01.0000] <Philip`>
P2P works for some things, but it doesn't help distribute the front page of a news site or videos on YouTube

[17:27:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Well, if you remove the user uploading, you get a CDN

[17:27:03.0000] <Philip`>
I suppose FreeNode supports distributing web pages but it has the problem of being rubbish

[17:27:04.0000] <Philip`>
Uh

[17:27:05.0000] <Philip`>
FreeNet

[17:27:06.0000] <Philip`>
or whatever it is

[17:28:00.0000] <Dashiva>
How would this system handle spam

[17:28:01.0000] <Dashiva>
You could reply to any interest message with Cialis :)

[17:30:00.0000] <Philip`>
By cryptographically signing content messages so that they're tied to the content name

[17:30:01.0000] <Dashiva>
But the name is included in the request, so you'd know the name

[17:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
You map the namespace hierarchy onto a tree of public/private keys

[17:31:01.0000] <Philip`>
so that only people with the key for a particular name can sign content purporting to be from that name

[17:32:00.0000] <Dashiva>
How would the keys be distributed and authenticated?

[17:35:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I suppose you could use a DNS-like system

[17:36:00.0000] <Philip`>
You trust somebody (perhaps a centralised authority like with DNS) who asserts the validity of other keys, recursively

[17:36:01.0000] <Philip`>
and keys are just content so they're distributed like any other content (under some kind of naming convention)

[17:38:00.0000] <Dashiva>
"I tell the server to store _my_ pictures." "I tell the camera the pictures it takes are _mine_"

[17:39:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Seems like you'd need to tell the server about the camera (or the inverse), or you'd be pinging every machine everywhere for pictures

[17:52:00.0000] <Dashiva>
"Most communication isn't point to point anymore"

[17:55:00.0000] <Philip`>
I think one of my doubts was that I expect things are going to become more point-to-point, not less

[17:56:00.0000] <Philip`>
because everyone is a fan of personalisation and customisation

[17:56:01.0000] <Philip`>
When you visit a web site you're never going to get precisely the same content as anybody else, because you'll have logged in and it'll be tailored for you

[17:56:02.0000] <Philip`>
and YouTube will do on-the-fly encoding of targeted adverts into the videos you watch

[17:57:00.0000] <Dashiva>
This video presentation seems to focus on personal data, all the examples are gadget-related

[17:57:01.0000] <Philip`>
and the idea of caching content for multiple users will be obsolete

[17:57:02.0000] <Philip`>
and the idea of requesting the same piece of data twice will also be obsolete

[17:58:00.0000] <Philip`>
and people will care about services, not about content

[17:59:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Although perhaps non-personal content (audio, video media) might have big enough in volume to still matter

[18:04:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me sleeps

[18:05:00.0000] <Dashiva>
They sign the content, yes

[18:06:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[18:17:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[05:03:00.0000] <Philip`>
About ImageData: If the fastest possible unpremultiplying-image-copy code is still slow enough to be a problem, could browsers do higher-level optimisations like having getImageData do a direct copy of the image data and only perform the unpremultiplication if the user accesses .data?

[05:03:01.0000] <Philip`>
(and then putImageData could do a direct copy with no premultiplying if it knows the user didn't fiddle with .data at all)

[05:04:00.0000] <Philip`>
(so it can be used for blitting between regions on a canvas or between multiple canvases, doing nothing more computationally complex than memcpy)

[05:04:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think that would slow down doing poking at the contents of ImageData

[05:04:02.0000] <othermaciej>
by at least the branch to do the check for lazy un-premult

[05:05:00.0000] <othermaciej>
even then, it would be overall slower for cases where you actually do modify the ImageData

[05:05:01.0000] <hsivonen>
zcorpan: I guess window.location in Gecko is broken, then

[05:05:02.0000] <Philip`>
I presume anyone who cares about performance would do "var d = imagedata.data; d[i]..." rather than doing the .data lookup every time

[05:05:03.0000] <Philip`>
even if it's doing nothing more complex than a normal property lookup

[05:05:04.0000] <zcorpan>
hsivonen: i get 'about:blank' in gecko

[05:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Philip`: so you're assuming the lazy un-pre-multiply would be on accessing the data property?

[05:07:00.0000] <zcorpan>
hsivonen: or the document's url if it's known when the script runs

[05:07:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Philip`: it would still mean you have to do the original copy and un-premultiply as a second pass

[05:07:02.0000] <Philip`>
othermaciej: Yes, so it's fast if you don't look at the data at all, but if you do then it'll have a one-time conversion cost and then pixel access will be as fast as usual

[05:07:03.0000] <hsivonen>
zcorpan: oh. I get "" for window.location.href and "about:blank" for window.document.documentURI

[05:08:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Philip`: that one-time conversion cost is going to be a lot for a large image - comparable to the cost of getImageData now, but you have the original cost of the raw copy on top of that

[05:08:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Philip`: as it is, if you just want to pass image data around and *not* directly poke at pixels, you are better off passing a HTMLCanvasElement than an Image Data

[05:08:02.0000] <Philip`>
Is the raw copy significant in comparison to that?

[05:09:00.0000] <Philip`>

[04:13:00.0000] <annevk>
no_mind, we've yet to figure out styling form controls unfortunately

[04:14:00.0000] <annevk>
though what WebKit is doing for controls in combination with appearance and all seems quite nice, but nobody has written down all the details in a specification yet...

[04:14:01.0000] <no_mind>
hmm so that spec is yet to be written...

[04:15:00.0000] <annevk>
pretty much

[04:15:01.0000] <no_mind>
how one start writing such spec

[04:15:02.0000] <no_mind>
where ever I give html5 demo, all designers ask this question

[04:15:03.0000] <annevk>
usually by figuring out the fundamentals

[04:16:00.0000] <annevk>
e.g. how does form styling currently work across various platforms, what is the effect of setting various properties, etc.

[04:16:01.0000] <annevk>
then figuring out how appearance affects that, what pseudo-classes are supported, how they all work together

[04:17:00.0000] <annevk>
and while testing all that writing down implementation criteria for someone that tries to emulate it

[04:17:01.0000] <annevk>
once we know the fundamentals we can start poking holes and enable new stuff

[04:17:02.0000] <annevk>
that's pretty much how we're doing most new features that are somewhat based on old APIs

[04:18:00.0000] <no_mind>
ok

[04:18:01.0000] <no_mind>
that will mean we have to add new css controls or attributes ?

[04:19:00.0000] <annevk>
maybe

[04:19:01.0000] <annevk>
another idea is that appearance:none would disable all styling and you would create the entire control yourself using XBL

[04:20:00.0000] <annevk>
though we'd need some hooks from XBL into the form API to make that completely feasible

[04:20:01.0000] <annevk>
e.g. so you can declare a form control matches :out-of-range and things like that

[04:21:00.0000] <annevk>
anyway, as things stand today CSS is not defined for form controls

[04:21:01.0000] <annevk>
the CSS WG declared it out of scope and nobody volunteered to fix it

[04:24:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
XBL2 will save us

[04:31:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[04:32:00.0000] <no_mind>

[05:45:01.0000] <Philip`>
klevison: Browsers all have different levels of support for various features, and different sets of bugs, so none is unequivocally best, and you should test in as many as possible and focus on the ones that your users are most likely to use

[05:46:00.0000] <Philip`>
zcorpan: I recently remembered that I forgot to do http://philip.html5.org/data/entities-in-attribute-with-no-semicolon-or-alphanumeric.txt

[05:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
I changed your regexp a bit to exclude > from attribute 'values', because otherwise it seemed to pick up a lot of entities that were in content after an element with attributes

[05:47:01.0000] <klevison>
Philip`: Is there a ranking of most use browsers?

[05:47:02.0000] <zcorpan>
Philip`: sweet, thanks

[05:48:00.0000] <Philip`>

[05:49:00.0000] <Philip`>
klevison: There are lots of rankings, all slightly different

[05:49:01.0000] <Philip`>
and it depends a lot on target audience, and country, etc

[05:49:02.0000] <zcorpan>

[05:49:03.0000] <Philip`>
but http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Usage_share_of_web_browsers gives some indications

[05:50:00.0000] <Philip`>
klevison: The theory is that HTML5 applications ought to work the same in all browsers, so for main development work you should pick whichever one gives you the best development tools (debuggers and network monitors and all that stuff)

[07:55:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[07:55:01.0000] <annevk>

[07:55:02.0000] <annevk>
MikeSmith, well it does

[07:56:00.0000] <annevk>
MikeSmith, what I'm complaining about is that the link between object model, syntax, and processing, is missing

[07:56:01.0000] <annevk>
or links

[07:56:02.0000] <Philip`>
MikeSmith: You should think of it as analogous to HTML4 + DOM

[07:56:03.0000] <annevk>
currently we have some notion of syntax which is various CSS specs patched together

[07:56:04.0000] <Philip`>
which define documents, and a document object model, but don't bother with the chasm in the middle

[07:57:00.0000] <annevk>

[07:57:01.0000] <annevk>

[15:19:00.0000] <jgraham>
http://research.microsoft.com/en-us/um/people/cormac/papers/2009/SoLongAndNoThanks.pdf seems like it might be interesting

[15:21:00.0000] <jgraham>
/me notices the text of the license on that paper forbids "redistribution to lists", wonders what that means and whether posting a URL counts

[15:23:00.0000] <Philip`>
Summary: "Microsoft recommends leaving users ignorant to simple security vulnerabilities"

[15:24:00.0000] <Philip`>
although, in the interest of not entirely blatantly misrepresenting it, I suppose I should note that it ends with "this paper is not to be read as an encouragement to end-users to ignore security policies or advice. The opinions expressed are those of the author."

[15:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
(Also that was my summary, not a direct quote)

[15:25:01.0000] <jgraham>
Philip`: I haven't read it all yet but it doesn't seem to say that, really

[15:26:00.0000] <jgraham>
It notes that it is somewhat rational to ignore security advice if the cost of understanding and following that advice is greater than the expected loss from not following that advice

[15:26:01.0000] <Philip`>
Sure, but worrying about what it really says is not the way to write headlines on tech news sites

[15:27:00.0000] <jgraham>
Which seems like a major over simplification since you need to look not just at the expected loss but at the distribution of possible losses

[15:27:01.0000] <Philip`>
and for most people the cost of reading the actual paper is less than the benefit they gain from doing so

[15:27:02.0000] <jgraham>
e.g. if you can have all your money stolen that is really bad even if there is only a 1 in a million chance it happens to you and so the expected loss is < $1

[15:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
Why is that really bad?

[15:28:01.0000] <Philip`>
Or, (why) is it more bad than two million people each guaranteed to lose < $1?

[15:30:00.0000] <jgraham>
I guess the total possible effect on your life scales more than linearly with the amount of money lost (beyond a certian point)

[15:35:00.0000] <Philip`>
jgraham: Only up to a certain point

[15:35:01.0000] <Philip`>
with that point being when you are bankrupt

[15:35:02.0000] <Philip`>
and then you don't care any more

[15:35:03.0000] <jgraham>
(the other problem with this typ of calculation is that the asumption of rational behaviour is totally flawed. In particular people are probably totally incapable of estimating the probability of a given attack, so if they happen to make "rational" decisions it is probably happenstance)

[15:37:00.0000] <Philip`>
(Incidentally, would you suggest it is rational to play the lottery, because super-linear scaling means a 10^-7 chance of winning £1M outweighs a 10^0 chance of losing £1?)

[15:38:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Philip`: No, the value of the million is subject to decreasing value since it's so big

[15:38:01.0000] <Philip`>
The abstract sounds ambiguous about the suggested behaviour

[15:38:02.0000] <roc>
you can argue that due to various kinds of poverty traps, playing the lottery is rational in some cases

[15:39:00.0000] <Philip`>
i.e. whether it means user behaviour (driven by ignorance and laziness) happens to coincide with rational behaviour, or whether it's actually suggesting users are making rational evaluations themselves

[15:39:01.0000] <Dashiva>
I think the paper should also be read as implementor-facing: "These behaviors are bad for users, so don't make your security depend on them"

[15:40:00.0000] <jgraham>
Dashiva: That was the interesting point of view for me

[15:40:01.0000] <othermaciej>
is risk-aversion natural?

[15:40:02.0000] <othermaciej>
er rational?

[15:40:03.0000] <othermaciej>
most people dislike losing what they have more than they like gaining something

[15:40:04.0000] <Dashiva>
only if they understand the risk, though

[15:40:05.0000] <roc>
it depends

[15:41:00.0000] <roc>
I think the main point of the paper is that we tend to not rationally consider the costs of security measures

[15:41:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it's a well-known result in behavioral economics: http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Endowment_effect

[15:41:02.0000] <roc>
we == vendors and researchers

[15:42:00.0000] <roc>
asking everyone in the world to do something that takes only a few seconds is actually a tremendous cost

[15:42:01.0000] <roc>
that's a humbling thought for browser developers :-)

[15:42:02.0000] <othermaciej>
otoh I don't think endowment effect applies in the case of a very low probability of a large loss

[15:42:03.0000] <othermaciej>
this is why I hate conformation dialogs as a security measure

[15:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
even if everyone read it and carefully considered the implications, the cost would likely still exceed the benefit

[15:43:01.0000] <roc>
people are irrationally fearful of certain kinds of losses, like shark attacks

[15:43:02.0000] <Philip`>
When there was a 2 minute silence in America for some people who had died, I wondered how many lifetime's worth of productivity was being lost because of that

[15:43:03.0000] <Philip`>
But it was only about 20 years of productivity, so it wasn't even a whole person

[15:43:04.0000] <othermaciej>
people are scared of low-probability risk of death or serious injury, if the scenario is particularly vivid

[15:44:00.0000] <othermaciej>
that's another well-known cognitive bias

[15:44:01.0000] <roc>
so there's the answer

[15:44:02.0000] <roc>
"if you don't look at this site's certificate, you will be eaten by a shark"

[15:44:03.0000] <Dashiva>
Philip`: Sort of like that rant about emails sent to large lists

[15:44:04.0000] <othermaciej>
however it doesn't tend to apply to risks where the consequences seem commonplace

[15:44:05.0000] <othermaciej>
especially where costs of avoiding the risk would require ongoing active effort

[15:45:00.0000] <Dashiva>
(For certificates, pretending it's http seems like a great solution to me)

[15:47:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think the paper ignores the fact that certain security measures have a very high false positive rate only because they exist

[15:47:01.0000] <othermaciej>
for example, if there was no error for invalid certs, a lot more phishing sites would use them

[15:47:02.0000] <jgraham>
I was going to point out the same thing

[15:47:03.0000] <othermaciej>
they only avoid using them because there is a scary warning

[15:48:00.0000] <Dashiva>
But as long as the sites weren't flagged as valid certs, it would be no different from now in effeciency

[15:48:01.0000] <roc>
othermaciej: is that actually true

[15:48:02.0000] <roc>
?

[15:49:00.0000] <othermaciej>
roc: I haven't seen the full counter-factual world of high degree of phishing/pharming but no warning whatsoever on invalid certs

[15:49:01.0000] <othermaciej>
but it may mean the level of scariness of the warning is nearly irrelevant

[15:49:02.0000] <roc>
right

[15:50:00.0000] <othermaciej>
roc: I do know that at least some malware modifies your local DNS settings and system root certs

[15:50:01.0000] <Philip`>
http://news.netcraft.com/archives/2010/03/05/new_browser_reports_over_half_of_ssl_sites_may_be_unsafe.html

[15:50:02.0000] <Philip`>
"A new internet browser, Comodo Dragon, reports that more than half of the world's valid SSL certificates are unsafe."

[15:50:03.0000] <othermaciej>
whence I conclude that it is at least somewhat valuable to attackers to be able to appear 100% like the real site, if they were able to do so

[15:50:04.0000] <Philip`>
Also: "Although Comodo states that many websites connected to cyber-crimes use domain-validated certificates, Netcraft's phishing site feed shows that only 0.3% of reported phishing sites use HTTPS, including those running on compromised servers with SSL certificates already in place."

[15:51:00.0000] <othermaciej>
phishing from a non-SSL server is extremely effective

[15:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it's hard to tell how much marginal impact there is on the success rate of phishing from measures that make it harder to look exactly like the real site in all ways

[15:52:01.0000] <roc>
right

[15:53:00.0000] <othermaciej>
the people aware enough to benefit from the protection were already at much lower risk of phishing in the first place

[15:54:00.0000] <roc>
you might be right that phishers would be more likely to use invalid certs if there was no warning, but I haven't seen any evidence that that would actually make a difference to users

[15:58:00.0000] <Dashiva>
<a href="www.evil.com">www.PayPal.com</a>

[15:58:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Nice example :)

[16:00:00.0000] <Philip`>
It'd be a nicer example if they hadn't forgotten the http://

[16:05:00.0000] <Dashiva>
You could draw a connection from cost-vs-benefit of security to the otherwise normal practice of insurance

[16:05:01.0000] <Dashiva>
It's not irrational to pay more than expected average risk if it lets you avoid large worst case risks

[16:17:00.0000] <othermaciej>
indeed, but it depends on the magnitude and likelihood of the risk

[16:20:00.0000] <Dashiva>
The paper also ignores non-monetary costs borne by users

[16:21:00.0000] <Dashiva>
If you get phished, the bank doesn't just give you the money right away, there's probably many hours of calling and talking and writing to recover it.

[16:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, for an example of the Windows team doing stuff for the IE team, look at Vista's Low Integrity mode.  I've seen a lot of stuff that implies that was intended mainly for IE -- official MS sources tend to mention low-integrity mode and protected IE in the same breath.

[16:28:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
jgraham, the usual assumption of economists is that rational agents should attempt to maximize expected utility.  Of course, utility doesn't map linearly to money, but the actual distributions don't matter, only the expectation (of utility).  There are pretty good theoretical reasons for this; if you don't do this, you can be money-pumped (at least sometimes).

[16:30:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also, people often do tend to act rationally, and not just by chance.  Your average person hasn't been hit by online fraud, no one they knows has, and they notice that no one else they know seems to be very concerned, so they (correctly) conclude that it's not a big problem for them.

[16:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Any way you slice it, it's clear that things like raising a big scary warning for cert errors are just stupid.

[16:32:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's security charade.

[11:29:01.0000] <mpilgrim>

[11:30:02.0000] <erlehmann>
and no flash cookies etc.

[11:31:00.0000] <mpilgrim>

[11:33:01.0000] <mpilgrim>
dunno if that's true, but it certainly seems plausible

[11:34:00.0000] <mpilgrim>

[11:35:00.0000] <mpilgrim>

[17:08:00.0000] <JoePeck>
Reading up on <input type=range> at http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/number-state.html#range-state

[17:08:01.0000] <JoePeck>
[[ When the element is http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/association-of-controls-and-forms.html#suffering-from-an-underflow, the user agent must set the element's http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/association-of-controls-and-forms.html#concept-fe-value to a http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/common-microsyntaxes.html#valid-floating-point-number that represents 

[17:08:02.0000] <JoePeck>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/common-input-element-attributes.html#concept-input-min. ]]

[17:08:03.0000] <JoePeck>
eek, sorry!

[17:08:04.0000] <JoePeck>
[[ When the element is suffering from an underflow, the user agent must set the element's value to a valid floating point number that represents the minimum. ]]

[17:08:05.0000] <JoePeck>
I read that and I see, "if the element is suffering from an under, set its value so its no longer underflows"

[17:09:00.0000] <JoePeck>
Am I reading that correctly? Can a range input ever underflow?

[17:09:01.0000] <JoePeck>
/me goes to test what browsers do

[17:11:00.0000] <mpilgrim_>
jgraham: i have little sympathy for companies that get all faint-y about H.264 licensing fees but continue to ship browsers that support NPAPI

[17:12:00.0000] <mpilgrim_>
we have over 10 years of experience with NPAPI, and it's pretty clear that its only purpose is to serve as a backdoor for all manner of proprietary crap to sneak into browsers, shit all over the web, and then complain about the smell

[17:12:01.0000] <Hixie>
JoePeck: it can momentarily suffer from an underflow if you use script to set it to a value below the minimum

[17:12:02.0000] <Hixie>
JoePeck: but that sentence means the steady state can't suffer from an underflow

[17:13:00.0000] <Hixie>
JoePeck: if that makes sense

[17:13:01.0000] <JoePeck>
Hixie: okay, but correct behavior should then immediately set the value to be the minimum, and its overflow validity state would then be false?

[17:13:02.0000] <mpilgrim_>
if you really want to support an open web, drop support for NPAPI plugins

[17:13:03.0000] <mpilgrim_>
otherwise, STFU

[17:17:00.0000] <Philip`>

[17:17:01.0000] <Philip`>

[17:18:00.0000] <Hixie>
JoePeck: yeah

[17:18:01.0000] <JoePeck>
Hixie: ahh, I just changed my mind

[17:18:02.0000] <JoePeck>
Hixie: The "value sanitization algorithm" which modifies the value is only run [[ When an input element's type attribute changes state, and when the element is first created ]].

[17:19:00.0000] <JoePeck>
Hixie: so if the input element is already a range, and a script sets its value to an underflowing value, "what then"

[17:19:01.0000] <Hixie>
setting .value also invokes the value sanitization algorithm

[17:20:00.0000] <JoePeck>

Hixie: can I run a very simple example past you to see if you think its correct or not?

[18:25:00.0000] <Hixie>
sure

[18:25:01.0000] <JoePeck>
var x = document.createElement('input'); x.type='range'; // range input

[18:25:02.0000] <JoePeck>
x.max = 2; x.value = 3; // this causes overFlow, value gets changed to 

[18:25:03.0000] <JoePeck>
x.validationMessage; // shouldn't be any, because value is now stable

[18:26:00.0000] <Hixie>
sounds right, but i could be mistaken

[18:26:01.0000] <JoePeck>
okay. I feel like that removes the usefulness of element.validity.rangeOverflow and rangeUnderflow for type=range

[18:27:00.0000] <JoePeck>
but I do feel like this should be correct behavior

[18:30:00.0000] <Hixie>
well there is no usefulness of element.validity.rangeOverflow and rangeUnderflow for type=range, so i don't think removing it is a problem :-)

[18:31:00.0000] <JoePeck>
I was just going to try to get some implementor feedback, maybe send a question to the mailing list

[18:31:01.0000] <JoePeck>
I haven't checked the other input types affected rangeUnderflows/rangeOverflows

[10:11:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:11:02.0000] <no_mind>

[10:12:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:12:01.0000] <no_mind>

[10:13:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:13:01.0000] <no_mind>

[10:13:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:14:00.0000] <no_mind>
Well in India they wont have managed to force the judgement. Anti software patents lobby is pretty strong here

[10:14:01.0000] <no_mind>
but it was enough to scare other hosts

[10:14:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
For obvious reasons.  :)

[10:15:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Poorer countries are going to be in favor of lax IP rights, because Western IP is usually priced for Westerners.  Whereas rich countries will be in favor of strong international IP for the same reason.

[10:16:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Poorer countries also often have the advantage of not having any legacy laws that snuck in before anyone realized what a stupid idea software patents was

[10:16:01.0000] <no_mind>
well India favors IP but not software patents

[10:17:00.0000] <no_mind>
copyright laws and trademark laws are pretty strong here, in terms of enforcement

[10:17:01.0000] <no_mind>
even patents

[10:17:02.0000] <no_mind>
but software patents and business patents are a strict no-no

[10:18:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:19:00.0000] <no_mind>

[10:19:01.0000] <no_mind>

[10:20:01.0000] <no_mind>

[10:20:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:20:03.0000] <no_mind>

[10:21:00.0000] <no_mind>

[10:22:00.0000] <no_mind>
Adobe follows stricter policies

[10:22:01.0000] <no_mind>
while Microsoft is very laxed here. They wait for 2-4 years before filing a case

[10:22:02.0000] <no_mind>
when the person is totally dependent on windows

[10:23:00.0000] <no_mind>

[10:24:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:25:00.0000] <no_mind>

[10:25:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:25:02.0000] <no_mind>

[11:39:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
AFAICT, "distributed extensibility" is defined as "whatever HTML5 doesn't have yet"

[11:39:01.0000] <Dashiva>
And "whatever HTML5 doesn't have anymore" :)

[11:39:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, that's why it's distributed.

[11:39:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
If HTML5 had it, it would be centralized, right?

[11:39:04.0000] <mpilgrim>
the contrapositive is also true -- if it is determined that a use case can be solved with something already in HTML5 (like "data-*" attributes), then the use case is automatically NOT "distributed extensibility"

[11:40:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
once i realized this, the ongoing discussions about ISSUE-41 made much more sense to me

[09:39:00.0000] <adactio>
Can I just quickly check with you guys that I'm understanding the script element correctly: if you're linking off to a file using the src attribute, you don't need to use the type attribute but if you are putting code between the opening and closing script tags insetad, you *must* use the type attribute?

[09:40:00.0000] <gsnedders>
No, that's wrong

[09:40:01.0000] <gsnedders>
You never need the type attribute

[09:40:02.0000] <gsnedders>
Except if the script isn't JS

[09:41:00.0000] <adactio>
This bit of the spec: "When used to include data blocks, the data must be embedded inline, the format of the data must be given using the type attribute, and the src attribute must not be specified." makes it sound like type is mandatory when not using src.

[09:42:00.0000] <adactio>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/scripting-1.html#script

[09:42:01.0000] <Dashiva>
The sentence before it explicitly says it isn't

[09:42:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
"When used to include data blocks"

[09:42:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
JavaScript isn't data blocks.

[09:43:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I was never sure what that section of the spec was meant to refer to.

[09:43:01.0000] <adactio>
The sentence before it refers only to scripts referenced with the src attribute, not inline scripts.

[09:43:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Some hypothetical usage, or do people actually do that?

[09:43:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
"When used to include dynamic scripts, the scripts may either be embedded inline or may be imported from an external file using the src attribute. If the language is not that described by "text/javascript", then the type attribute must be present, as described below."

[09:43:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
That covers all usage of JavaScript, since you're including dynamic scripts, not data blocks.

[09:43:05.0000] <Dashiva>
adactio: "either embedded inline or..."

[09:44:00.0000] <adactio>

[09:45:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:45:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't know why the distinction is drawn.

[09:45:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I suggest you file a bug or post to whatwg.

[09:45:03.0000] <Dashiva>

[09:45:04.0000] <adactio>

[09:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
Data blocks are things like <script type="text/glsl-vs">here's some text that other scripts can extract, and it can say x < y etc safely</script>

[09:48:00.0000] <Philip`>
You could do something like put JSON data in there too

[09:48:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Or XML...

[09:48:02.0000] <jgraham>
Or HTML

[09:48:03.0000] <Philip`>
or even put JS code which should be accessible to the rest of the page and should not be executed

[09:48:04.0000] <Philip`>
though then you'd have to come up with a new content-type for it

[09:49:00.0000] <Dashiva>
text/not-javascript-I-promise

[09:49:01.0000] <Philip`>

[09:50:00.0000] <Philip`>

[09:51:00.0000] <Philip`>

[09:58:00.0000] <Philip`>

[09:59:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[10:00:00.0000] <Philip`>

[10:00:01.0000] <Philip`>

[14:22:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
But I'm finally done.

[14:37:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Question about writing out Element Attributes; should they always be arranged alphabetically?  href="@page-url@" title="@go-to@ @page-title@",  content="@site-author@" name="author", or do they have an arrangement written somewhere?

[14:39:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
What?

[14:39:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
AryehGregor, what to me?

[14:39:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Element attributes are logically unordered.  Use whatever order you like.

[14:40:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'm not sure what your question is, exactly.

[14:40:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Okay, you answered my  question, I didn't know if I'm supposed to write id="myId" class="myclassname" or if class="myclassname" id="myId" was just as correct, sorting alphabetically.

[14:43:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Thanks, I was wondering if there was a logical order.

[14:43:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Because if element attributes are logically unordered, we could order them alphabetically, like we do with CSS properties.

[14:43:02.0000] <Philip`>
That doesn't sound logical

[14:43:03.0000] <Philip`>

[14:44:00.0000] <Philip`>

[14:48:00.0000] <Philip`>

[14:49:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[14:49:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[14:49:04.0000] <AryehGregor>

[14:50:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[14:51:04.0000] <AryehGregor>

[14:53:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
So, writing <body><div id="document" role="document"></div></body> is the worst idea ever and standards-breaking, or valid and at my descretion?

[14:57:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It seems to be technically valid as far as HTML5 is concerned, unless I missed the part that bans it.

[14:57:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It seems pointless, though.

[14:57:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
<body> has implicit document semantics.

[14:59:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Right, but I think this could be useful when you're in a modx, Facebook, or another portal based page where you have a dock or a chat application that sits aside the div#document.

[14:59:01.0000] <Philip`>
JonathanNeal: If you use x-ua-compatible, you should use "IE=edge" so that it always uses the latest version

[15:00:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Are you testing the effect that role is having here in an actual UA that supports role, or just speculatively adding markup in case maybe for someone it would be better than not having the markup?

[15:00:01.0000] <Philip`>
(so that you benefit from improved performance and standardiness in future versions)

[15:01:00.0000] <paul_irish>
Philip`: yah i was thinking the same.

[15:02:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Philip`, good call.

[15:02:01.0000] <Dashiva>
Or so you contribute to IE=edge becoming frozen as IE8 because too many people use it and depend on quirks~

[15:02:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
AryehGregor, both.

[15:03:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
JonathanNeal, don't do the latter, ever.  Do not add features you can't test.  They'll probably make things worse.  UAs can deal with you ignoring their existence, they can't deal with you giving them explicit instructions that turn out to make no sense because you didn't test them.

[15:03:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I've learned this the hard way.

[15:03:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Dashiva, I have corrected this.

[15:03:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
AryehGregor, what tools do you recommend I use to test these?

[15:05:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
JonathanNeal, I don't know.  But if you aren't testing, don't use the feature, period.  You *will* do it wrong and your site *will* break when someone finally does implement the feature.  Guaranteed.

[15:05:01.0000] <Philip`>
Dashiva: He should use IE=edge and not depend on quirks

[15:05:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I take the red pill, AryehGregor.

[15:05:03.0000] <Philip`>
and should test in various browsers and in IE betas

[15:06:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
JonathanNeal, what?

[15:06:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
AryehGregor, http://izanbardprince.files.wordpress.com/2008/08/red-pill-or-blue-pill.jpg

[15:06:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Philip`: Yeah. The problem is that if enough other people don't, his site will still be affected.

[15:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
Dashiva: He'll be affected less than if he uses IE=8

[15:07:01.0000] <Dashiva>
That's true

[15:08:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
JonathanNeal, I've seen The Matrix.  I have no idea what you mean in context.

[15:09:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
AryehGregor, I mean that I'm risky and I wanna see what happens --- but really if no tool exists to evaluate this then I can theorize.

[15:10:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
The spec says I can, and it makes sense to me this way, so the only reason I could provide against it would be that someone implements it differently.

[15:10:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, that is an absolutely terrible idea.  Drop it immediately.  You're doing a disservice to yourself and your users and the web as a whole.  Deploying a feature that hasn't yet been implemented is almost guaranteed to break, and that either 1) hurts your users if their site breaks, or (worse) 2) hurts browsers because they get complaints from users that the site breaks in the new version, since the new version implements the feature you're u

[15:10:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
sing brokenly.

[15:11:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
What will happen is that either you will misunderstand the spec somehow, or else the implementation will have some quirk you weren't expecting.  I have had this happen to me *multiple* times.

[15:11:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
When I learned that Opera supposed datalist, I added support to MediaWiki and tested in Opera -- only to find out that actually there was a slight quirk I never would have predicted that made it behave worse than the non-datalist functionality.

[15:12:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
When I learned that Opera supported attributes like pattern on inputs, I added pattern to lots of inputs, and tested.  It turned out that if a password field fails a constraint, it will print the value of the password field in plaintext.

[15:13:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
In both cases, if I had blindly added the feature without testing it in any actual user-agent, it would have caused significant *harm* to users when Opera added the feature.

[15:13:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
You could test, what do I have to test?  JAWS?

[15:14:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
In another case, when I was young and stupid and didn't yet realize the absolute necessity of testing, I added a handheld stylesheet to MediaWiki without having any mobile UA handy, figuring something was better than nothing.  This actually broke Opera Mobile (or Mini or something), to the point that they went to the effort to dig up wikitech-l and ask there for us to remove our handheld stylesheet because it was broken.

[15:14:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
If you care about blind users, then yes, absolutely test in JAWS.

[15:14:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Just because I'm pushing back doesn't mean I'm disregarding what you're saying, just developing with you.

[15:14:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Add whatever features demonstrably make your users' experience better.

[15:15:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Do not add features that don't do anything and might or might not do something in the future just because you can.

[15:16:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Right, change for change sake.  I'm trying to take advantage of meaning to enforce existing standards.  For instance, most folks need a <div id="wrapper" /> or something like that on their site.  Something that wraps all the pages content and separates it from another application on the page.

[15:16:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
And that lead me to look into the role document and application, which seemed to fit perfectly in this paradigm, and describes itself as such.

[15:16:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
And goes as far as to say this scope doesn't apply to the whole page, but part of the page.

[15:17:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
So I thought, let's take this great thing and mix it in with the existing need for a wrapper, consolidating the two.

[15:17:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Semantics for semantics' sake is just as bad.

[15:18:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Keep this in mind: if you use role nowhere at all, your page will be like 99.9% of pages out there.  Screen readers for the blind will be able to handle that.

[15:18:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
So it will work fine.

[15:18:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
What about consolidation by means of semantics?

[15:18:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
If you use role *incorrectly*, your site will work *worse*.  It might become unusable, even.

[15:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
The gains are not worth the risk from any kind of practical standpoint.

[15:19:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
JonathanNeal, that's a string of buzzwords, not an actual reason.

[15:19:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
An example of a reason to use role="something or other" would be "so JAWS does X instead of Y".

[15:19:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Where X is better than Y.

[15:19:04.0000] <JonathanNeal>
As we get to know each other more, you'll learn I'm not a buzzword guy.

[15:22:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I think there's a balance, and sometimes you have to edge past the 99.9% paradigm, get the test results, learn, and develop.  Then progress is made.  And it looks like I have good counsel in this room to remind me how dangerous it can be to force users to adopt my suggestions :)

[15:25:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I've added a whole lot of HTML5 features to MediaWiki (thus to eventually be deployed on Wikipedia), and I have always followed this maxim: only add something if I can clearly spell out a user-visible benefit.

[15:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me remembers he needs to work out something about validation of HTML5 with non-HTML5 doctype, ugh

[22:42:00.0000] <othermaciej>
btw if you click on the yes/no links you can see my methodology

[22:42:01.0000] <othermaciej>
which I guess I should document

[22:42:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I am using validator.nu to check for HTML5 and XHTML5 conformance

[22:42:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I am using validator.w3.org to check for conformance to declared doctype, if it is something other than HTML5

[22:42:04.0000] <othermaciej>
I am counting only errors, not warnings, in both cases

[22:42:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
My methodology for bulk testing was: for domain in `cat top-domains-201003`; do echo -en "$domain:\t"; curl -Ss "http://validator.w3.org/check?uri=http://$domain" | grep -o 'This document was successfully checked\|Errors found while checking this document\|This document can not be checked'; done

[22:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
