[23:18:00.0000] <othermaciej>
Should validators (and notions of document conformance) be changed so they are helpful more often than they are annoying?

[23:18:01.0000] <othermaciej>
C compiler warnings are often annoying but if you just blindly fix them all you will fix some real bugs

[23:18:02.0000] <othermaciej>
probably more than if you tried to review them one at a time

[23:18:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
If that's the goal, presentational attributes definitely need to be allowed, for starters.

[23:18:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Many of the errors I'm seeing here are reasonable, though.

[23:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
But if that's the only goal of a validator, then there's no need for the spec to say what's valid.

[23:19:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
You can have competition between different error-checkers.

[23:19:02.0000] <othermaciej>
people have indeed raised that proposition

[23:20:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen says that it's useful for there to be at least a reasonable common base of errors reported, so you can switch validators without breaking your whole workflow

[23:20:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It would also still be useful to retain a way of checking whether you're only using standard, interoperable functionality.

[23:20:02.0000] <othermaciej>
the one error that seems clearly bogus to me based on info so far is unescaped & in an attribute

[23:21:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me agrees with that

[23:21:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it seems like a huge waste of time to escape all those

[23:21:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I am also dubious about the value of banning presentational elements/attributes

[23:21:03.0000] <othermaciej>
but that seems less clearcut

[23:21:04.0000] <othermaciej>
most of these sites show only a tiny handful of uses which may well be an oversight, not a deliberate strategy

[23:21:05.0000] <othermaciej>
the main exception being google.com, which is clearly using presentational markup very deliberately

[23:22:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
If you leave the top 100 sites, you'll find a lot more deliberate presentational markup.

[23:22:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or just look at a random Wikipedia page's content (not the skin).

[23:23:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it does seem to me that presentational markup is a matter of taste, not unambiguously an "error"

[23:23:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I am ok with saying <i>foo <b> bar </i> baz </b> is an error

[23:24:00.0000] <othermaciej>
because it's almost certainly not going to give quite the result you intended, so it is probably a mistake

[23:24:01.0000] <othermaciej>
likewise with duplicate ids

[23:24:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but I don't see how use of the <u> element is in that same category

[23:24:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's in the same category as omitting alt from <img>.

[23:25:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I.e., the spec bans it because of political pressure, not because it's not a rational thing for some authors to do.

[23:25:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyone who thinks it's usually in authors' interest to give good alt text is smoking something.  Good for blind users, yes; but most authors have a negligible number of blind users relative to the effort it would take to use alt text properly.

[23:25:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
But this is politically unacceptable to acknowledge in a spec, it seems to me.

[23:26:00.0000] <othermaciej>
some authors have legal or policy reasons to care about blind users disproportionate to their share of the audience

[23:27:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Not most, though.

[23:27:01.0000] <othermaciej>
others (e.g. random using uploading Flickr photo or writing a GMail message to grandma) do not

[23:27:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The requirement is unreasonable for the large majority of authors, from a rational/economic standpoint.

[23:27:03.0000] <othermaciej>
it's plausible as a legal requirement for governments and large corporations or charities

[23:28:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes, but that's not most authors.

[23:28:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's a small minority.

[23:28:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
But the requirement in the spec is absolute.

[23:28:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Banning presentational markup is similar.

[23:28:04.0000] <othermaciej>
by visit count it probably affects most content, by page count, no

[23:28:05.0000] <othermaciej>
see also: power law distribution

[23:29:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm not sure that banning presentational markup even has an accessibility benefit

[23:29:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Your hypothesis suggests that major sites would reliably have good alt text.

[23:29:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or at least major competently-run sites would.

[23:29:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Is this the case?  I doubt it.

[23:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>
my hypothesis is that they have a legal/policy requirement, not that they are always attentive to it

[23:30:01.0000] <othermaciej>
for better or for worse, it's probably something they see as a cost of doing business, not an opportunity

[23:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Nevertheless, it's not useful advice to the large majority of authors.  Maybe if you weight by page views, but I doubt authors use validators proportional to their page views.

[23:32:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's not useful advice to the large majority of authors who are trying to check their work in a validator.

[23:32:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
So it's not useful if your goal is a lint-like tool.

[23:33:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I see two major purposes in a validator: 1) Informing authors of possible mistakes.  2) Informing concerned users about how standards-compliant a site is (e.g., for clients who are interested in having a standards-based site for policy reasons).

[23:34:00.0000] <othermaciej>
are duplicate IDs a useful error to report?

[23:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>
it seems like (2) is circular as a reason to have more conformance requirements

[23:34:02.0000] <othermaciej>
if the only reason to have a standards conformance requirement is to report to concerned users that a site fails that requirement, then that in itself is not a very good reason

[23:35:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
(2) would suggest reporting things that suggest the page is using non-standard functionality, such as unrecognized elements or attributes, or <object>s containing Flash, etc.

[23:35:01.0000] <othermaciej>
37 errors left to classify on YouTube...

[23:35:02.0000] <othermaciej>
<object>s containing Flash is something that no current validator will complain about

[23:35:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
By "standards-compliant" I meant "following de facto or de jure standards so as to behave interoperably in different clients".

[23:35:04.0000] <othermaciej>
I suspect making it a conformance error would mae lots of people mad

[23:35:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
I think they should.

[23:36:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
(complain, not be mad :) )

[23:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>
as for unrecognized elements, it still seems circular to me to say that they should be nonstandard so that the validator can report that they are nonstandard

[23:36:02.0000] <othermaciej>
if the spec allowed arbitrary custom elements and attributes, then they wouldn't be nonstandard

[23:36:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Then the spec would not be doing its job of specifying behavior that can be implemented interoperably.

[23:37:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't care about standards for standards' sake, I care about ensuring interoperability.

[23:37:01.0000] <othermaciej>
saying that they should be nonstandard so a valid document doesn't accidentally rely on uninteroperable behavior seems reasonable

[23:37:02.0000] <othermaciej>
though that is an aid to the author too, not just vigilant users

[23:37:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes.

[08:38:01.0000] <othermaciej>
that error only shows up if you force HTML5 mode

[08:38:02.0000] <Philip`>
(and preventing confusion is a common part of the rationale for conformance requirements)

[08:39:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
the fact that it's not reported as an error by the qa-dev v.nu instance appears to be that I have a bug in my workspace code 

[08:39:01.0000] <Philip`>
MikeSmith: "XHTML 1.0 Transitional doctype seen. [...] Using the schema for HTML 4.01 Transitional + IRI / XHTML 1.0 Transitional + IRI."

[08:39:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
oh, OK

[08:40:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
http://qa-dev.w3.org:8888/?doc=http%3A%2F%2Fwordpress.com%2F&schema=http%3A%2F%2Fs.validator.nu%2Fhtml5%2Fhtml5full-aria.rnc+http%3A%2F%2Fs.validator.nu%2Fhtml5%2Fassertions.sch+http%3A%2F%2Fc.validator.nu%2Fall%2F&parser=html5

[08:40:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Error: Element script is missing required attribute src.

[08:40:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
I really need to get that fix committed

[08:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
That's still a far less helpful error than saying it's required because of the charset

[08:41:01.0000] <Philip`>
People will think they have to add a src, they won't think they have to remove the charset

[08:42:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I agree

[08:42:01.0000] <Philip`>
I'm only saying that because I don't have to implement it, of course

[08:42:02.0000] <Dashiva>
It should say something like "charset attribute only applies to external scripts" or something.

[08:43:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
well, this is fundamental problem with grammar-based constraint checking

[08:43:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
we could move the constraint check for this case to the assertions-checking code, where we have precise control over the error message

[08:43:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Can't you... invert the constraint or something?

[08:43:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
but if we do this check using the RelaxNG schema, we have no real control over the error that's reported

[08:43:04.0000] <annevk>
it should prolly say "remove the charset attribute"

[08:43:05.0000] <Dashiva>
Instead of saying charset requires src, say !src requires !charset

[08:44:00.0000] <Dashiva>
(Disclaimer: I don't know relaxng)

[08:44:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Dashiva: if we move this out of the schema, then anybody using the schema only (without also at least using the associated Schematron assertions) is not going to see any error message at all for this

[08:45:00.0000] <Dashiva>
So the schema doesn't allow negative assertions like that one?

[08:45:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Dashiva: no, we can't really invert the constraint in the scheam

[08:45:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
Dashiva: no, it doesn't

[08:46:00.0000] <Dashiva>
I don't think optimizing for solutions that are known to be fundamentally lacking is a good idea, though

[08:46:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
this is not just a case for charset, it's the same case for defer and async

[08:46:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
Dashiva: you are preaching to the choir on that

[08:47:00.0000] <Philip`>

[08:47:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[08:47:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
Philip`: the availability of the schema risks people actually using it alone

[08:47:03.0000] <Philip`>

[08:47:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
people will use it alone

[08:47:05.0000] <MikeSmith>

[08:48:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
people can grab the schema and use it with Jing or whatever other RelaxNG validation tool they want

[08:48:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[08:48:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
use it from the command line

[08:48:03.0000] <Dashiva>

[08:49:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Dashiva: no a particularly helpful way to describe it

[08:49:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
the schema is useful on its own as a way to guide context-sensitive editing

[08:49:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
that is, integrated into editing apps

[08:50:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
someone can right now take that schema and use it to edit HTML5 documents in Emacs, for example

[08:50:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
in nxml-mode

[08:50:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
that is not a case of anybody aiming for mediocrity

[08:50:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
ask hober 

[08:50:04.0000] <Dashiva>

[08:51:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Dashiva: because nxml-mode does not do Schematron checking

[08:52:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
that does not mean it's useless 

[08:52:01.0000] <Dashiva>
I didn't say it was useless, I said it was mediocre

[08:52:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
whatever

[08:52:03.0000] <Philip`>
I imagine RNG makes it possible to determine what is the next permitted token given an incomplete document, whereas Schematron doesn't

[08:52:04.0000] <Philip`>
so the latter isn't much good for auto-complete

[08:53:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
right

[08:53:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
all that Schematron does is test XPath expressions

[08:53:02.0000] <Philip`>
Can they be Turing-complete expressions?

[08:53:03.0000] <othermaciej>
so there's really no way to say an attribute is conditionally allowed based on presence of another?

[08:54:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: that is in fact what the schema currently says

[08:54:01.0000] <Dashiva>
I also don't see how _absense_ of src is going to lead to a benefit in autocomplete

[08:54:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
it says, charset is allowed if the src attribute is specific

[08:54:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
Dashiva: true

[08:54:04.0000] <othermaciej>
I see, so it's just the error message that is bad

[08:54:05.0000] <MikeSmith>
s/specific/specified/

[08:54:06.0000] <othermaciej>
it should say that charset is disallowed rather than src is missing

[08:55:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it seems like that would be the more natural way to express the constraint

[08:55:01.0000] <Philip`>
/me wonders if there's a subset of Schematron that allows the permitted next characters to be computable, while still being more expressive than RNG grammars

[08:55:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: as I said, I don't think we can have it report that with just the schema. we need to have it reported in the assertions code

[08:56:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
and if we keep it in the schema, then we get two errors reported

[08:56:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Dashiva: this may indeed by a case where we can remove it from the schema with causing harm

[08:56:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Philip`: Surely it should be possible to expand RNG to handle absense of attributes too

[08:56:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess it is a problem of the schema engine sucking

[08:56:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
I hope we can remove it, personally

[08:57:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
this is a general deficiency in all grammar-based validation mechanisms that I am aware of

[08:57:01.0000] <othermaciej>
if it doesn't get fixed, then it's probably better to prioritize quality of error messages over usability of the schema for alternate purposes

[08:57:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: agreed

[08:58:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: again, see my comments about this that I posted in replies to DanC on the TAG mailing list

[08:58:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
this is one of the main reasons I don't want to have the HTML WG publish that schema

[08:58:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
me and others

[08:59:00.0000] <Philip`>
Dashiva: I expect negation is fundamentally incompatible with the theoretical model used by RNG

[08:59:01.0000] <Philip`>
(I don't know that's true, but it would explain why they don't have negation)

[09:01:00.0000] <Philip`>
In any case, if the grammar allows <script> and <script src charset> and the input is <script src> then it's easy to tell the input doesn't match the grammar, but there's no general correct way to decide which specific part of the grammar it's not matching

[09:02:00.0000] <Philip`>
so implementations have to make some arbitrary choice of which error to report, and in some cases that won't be ideal

[09:02:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Microsoft's homepage seems to return different content to http://validator.w3.org/ and http://validator.nu/ , even when forcing HTML5 mode in both

[09:03:00.0000] <othermaciej>
hmm, it seems to have stopped doing so

[09:03:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
Philip`: the choice that Jing makes (and likely any other RelaxNG implementation makes) is to report anything that is required but missing

[09:05:00.0000] <Philip`>

[09:06:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
it depends on the implementation

[09:06:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
the trunk of jing reports "required attributes missing"

[09:06:02.0000] <Philip`>

[09:06:03.0000] <MikeSmith>

[09:33:05.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:34:00.0000] <Dashiva>

[09:34:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[09:34:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:34:03.0000] <Dashiva>

[09:35:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:35:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:38:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:38:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:38:02.0000] <othermaciej>
one is requiring a large diff to the spec, even though it can be stated relatively succinctly

[09:39:00.0000] <othermaciej>
that seems fine as a bug, though if it gets rejected, writing the Change Proposal will be potentially a lot of work

[09:39:01.0000] <othermaciej>
another is that it has many subproblems

[09:39:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:41:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:41:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:47:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[09:47:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
MikeSmith, I'm currently thinking that perhaps it could be validated as HTML5 if 1) it has an XHTML 1.1 doctype, and 2) it has no xmlns attribute on the <html> element.  Kind of a hack, but unlikely to be disruptive.  Such documents cannot be valid XHTML 1.1.  In case it *was* meant to be an XHTML 1.1 document, a note can be output explaining the situation and saying to add a correct xmlns if you really want XHTML 1.1.

[09:47:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
(I assume XHTML 1.1 still requires xmlns, like XHTML 1.0.)

[09:47:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
othermaciej: yeah, it would mean that every invalid HTML4 doc would get checked twice as many times as it is now

[09:48:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
which would not seem like a particularly good idea

[09:48:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
AryehGregor: doing some kind of heuristic checks like that might be acceptable

[09:48:02.0000] <Dashiva>

[09:49:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:49:02.0000] <Dashiva>

[09:49:03.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:49:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Because it can't use <!DOCTYPE html> because it wants to be well-formed XML and needs to have entity declarations.

[09:50:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's either that or try to get rid of every single &nbsp; and whatever, which is horribly error-prone.

[09:50:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[09:50:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[09:50:03.0000] <Dashiva>

[09:51:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

I don't think it's the W3C's job to make it as easy as possible for you to impress people

[10:05:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's not about impressing people, it's about evangelism.  It's kind of hard for an organization to advocate web standards if it's perceived as not complying with them.

[10:06:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Anyway, regardless of us, it's misleading to validator users to say that the document is non-standard XHTML 1.0 Strict when it's actually valid HTML5.  You could also say it's non-standard HTML 3.2, but that would be silly.

[10:06:01.0000] <othermaciej>
is there a place where I can find information on the standards Wikipedia (and/or MediaWiki) claims to conform to?

[10:07:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Nowhere official.  Everything I've said here is my own opinion as a volunteer.  Historically, MediaWiki has attempted to conform to XHTML 1.0 Transitional, and now I'm trying to get it to conform as HTML5.

[10:08:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It also tries to conform to CSS and so on, where practical.

[10:09:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess what I'm saying is, if it's important for Wikipedia to know about your standards compliance, it seems like one obvious first step would be for Wikipedia to document its own standards compliance efforts in a publicly visible way

[10:09:01.0000] <othermaciej>
but anyway I guess I have said enough on this topic

[10:09:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Validators are what people use to judge standards compliance.

[10:10:00.0000] <Philip`>
Maybe MediaWiki should try to evangelise better ways of judging standards compliance

[10:10:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's the problem.  Few people understand anything about the standards, they rely on validators to tell them whether something is conforming.

[10:12:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Wikimedia seems to mostly be focusing its evangelism efforts right now on Theora, although by now it's unfortunately turned out to be a lost cause (IMO).

[10:13:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Although standards evangelism is far from a primary goal of Wikimedia, anyway.

[10:13:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't think wikipedia is the proper organization to evangelize standards

[10:14:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm thinking of a page that says things like "Wikipedia strives to be compliant to web standards including HTTP 1.1, HTML5 and CSS 2.1. Here are some ways in which we don't always meet that goal. Here is how to check for yourself." etc

[10:15:00.0000] <othermaciej>
writing is hard though and if the list grows to be more than a shortlist it can spawn excess debate

[10:15:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess some form of SVG should also be in that list

[10:16:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
That seems superfluous.  Isn't just saying "we try to be standards-compliant" enough?  It's pretty clear what HTML standard we use (currently XHTML 1.0 Transitional), and there are really no major conflicts between the versions of other standards (CSS, HTTP, etc.).  You can just assume the latest.

[10:16:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
(not that we find it necessary to officially say we try to be standards-compliant, we just do it, where it's reasonable)

[10:16:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Does WebKit have an official list of standards that it tries to implement correctly?

[10:22:00.0000] <othermaciej>
we have tried to make such a list for WebKit but it started getting pretty long and hard to maintain

[10:22:01.0000] <othermaciej>
http://trac.webkit.org/wiki/SpecSupport

[10:22:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Opera and IE have such lists, I think.

[10:22:03.0000] <othermaciej>
extremely incomplete list

[10:22:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
It doesn't seem like a worthwhile use of time to me.

[10:23:00.0000] <othermaciej>
and out of date

[10:23:01.0000] <othermaciej>
there's probably at least 50 things that could be added to that list

[10:24:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think we need to have a more complete and up-to-date list though, if only for our own purposes

[10:24:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, implementers tend to refer to actual specs a lot more than authors.  If anything, authors mostly just get it to validate and leave it at that.

[10:25:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Maybe it's more useful to implementers to keep tabs on exactly what specs they need to refer to.

[10:25:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
It doesn't seem useful to me as an author.

[10:26:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it's useful for us so that we can keep track of whether patches are part of a standard we approve of, or whether they need closer examination

[10:26:01.0000] <othermaciej>
also to document the state of things for content authors, because they seem interested in what standards we support

[06:17:01.0000] <virtuelv>
if everyone ceased from creating new documents on the web, HTML5 UAs should eventually become more compatible with that content

[06:18:00.0000] <virtuelv>

[07:34:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me continues to think that HTML5 shouldn't defer to RFC2119 for definitions of "must" etc, because RFC2119 doesn't make sense in the context of authoring requirements

[07:35:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hmm, yeah, true

[07:36:00.0000] <Philip`>
(It's written about vendors implementing behaviours)

[07:37:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
Philip`: is it really, though?

[07:37:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
I'm reading it now and I don't immediately see anything that makes it bound so closely to implementations

[07:38:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
to being about requirements for implementors

[07:38:01.0000] <Philip`>
"the full implications should be understood and the case carefully weighed before implementing any behavior described with this label"

[07:38:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
ohg

[07:38:03.0000] <Philip`>
That's about implementing behaviours

[07:38:04.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah, and "enhances the product while another vendor may omit the same item"

[07:39:00.0000] <Philip`>
The "MAY" definition is all about vendors and implementations

[07:39:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
right

[07:39:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
I see that now

[07:39:03.0000] <MikeSmith>
the Security Considerations section also

[07:40:00.0000] <Philip`>
Some of the definitions are more generic, but if the goal was for RFC2119 to apply to non-implementations requirements too then presumably the whole thing would have been written in a more generic way

[07:40:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
yes

[07:40:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
though perhaps it doesn't really matter what the original intent was

[07:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
It matters if people start trying to selectively interpret the intent of the original phrasing

[07:42:00.0000] <jgraham>
FWIW I agree with Philip` to the extent that RFC 2119 is clearly not intended to deal with authoring requirments when the client is liberal

[07:42:01.0000] <jgraham>
(or perhaps in general)

[07:42:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
Philip`: it is a mistake for them to do that

[07:42:03.0000] <jgraham>
I don't think this is a big problem except insofaras people try to spac lawyer as if it was

[07:42:04.0000] <Philip`>
I think the use of must/should/etc for authoring requirements is useful and sensible and good, but specs should be clear that it's a wilful violation of RFC2119

[07:43:00.0000] <Philip`>
so that people can't validly claim that the spec is silently inconsistent with the other specs it normatively references

[07:45:00.0000] <jgraham>
/me would prefer people just stopped that because it is obviously a trivial inconsistency, hasn't been a problem for other specs, and only matters to spec lawyers anyway

[08:04:00.0000] <Philip`>
/me wonders if 'it should be feasible to explain to authors exactly how to write valid HTML' is one of the criteria that Sam is missing

[08:06:00.0000] <Philip`>
(where 'to write an attribute value containing a '&', you can write it escaped or you can write '&' unless it's followed by one of these 106 strings of characters in unescaped form' is not considered a feasible explanation)

[08:07:00.0000] <Philip`>
(...'unless those strings are themselves followed by an alphanumeric character' or whatever the rules are now)

[09:31:00.0000] <Philip`>
If you want some kind of scrolling within the content of the <canvas> (rather than having it be like a large <img> where the whole page can scroll to reveal parts of it), then you'll just have to write code to detect user input and to offset all your drawing functions

[09:31:01.0000] <Wolfman2000>

[09:33:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[09:34:00.0000] <Wolfman2000>

[09:35:00.0000] <Wolfman2000>

[09:35:01.0000] <Wolfman2000>
Still...I could have thought plain <svg> files couldn't have a <script> or <title> tag.

[09:35:02.0000] <Wolfman2000>
How exactly can I combine SVG and Javascript?

[09:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
Wolfman2000: You can use <script>s in SVG files, and also you can embed SVG inside an XHTML page (sent as application/xhtml+xml, not text/html yet) in order to use normal HTML form inputs and scripts and so on

[09:39:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
You can embed SVG in text/html in Firefox with html5.enable and in IE9, and probably in other browsers at some point.

[09:39:01.0000] <Wolfman2000>
html5.enable is at true right now

[09:40:00.0000] <Philip`>
Wolfman2000: Not by default

[09:40:01.0000] <Wolfman2000>
...wonder how I turned it on then

[09:40:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Then you can stick <svg><circle r=100 full=red></circle></svg> in your HTML documents and get SVG as part of the DOM.  (Except I don't know SVG, so that might not work.)

[09:40:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
(Do void elements auto-close in SVG-in-text/html?)

[09:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
Restricting yourself to IE9 + Firefox-with-non-standard-options is probably a bit excessively anti-user

[09:41:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Maybe.

[09:41:02.0000] <Wolfman2000>
Then please suggest a good alternative

[09:42:00.0000] <Philip`>
Doing it in application/xhtml+xml will work in every browser except IE8 (and older IEs)

[09:42:01.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: You have to say <circle></circle> or <circle/>

[09:42:02.0000] <Philip`>
The parser doesn't know the details of all SVG elements

[09:43:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Ah, so <circle /> does work.

[09:43:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
This works in Firefox with html5.enable: data:text/html,<!doctype html><svg width=200 height=200><circle cx=100 cy=100 r=100 fill=red /></svg>

[09:43:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hurrah.

[09:43:03.0000] <Wolfman2000>
Philip`: since I'm using HTML5 on my website primarily, what requires changing for it to work as application/xhtml+xml?

[09:43:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Wolfman2000, IE < 9 doesn't work with application/xhtml+xml.

[09:43:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
Nor does it support SVG at all, in fact.

[09:43:06.0000] <Wolfman2000>
AryehGregor: besides IE

[09:43:07.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: and circle isn't an empty element in SVG anyway

[09:43:08.0000] <AryehGregor>
Oh, then you just have to make sure it's well-formed, or else it will die with a fatal error.

[09:44:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
So it's kind of inconvenient.

[09:44:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Probably easier to use <object> for now.  You can still have <script> inside the SVG file itself, as I understand it.

[09:45:00.0000] <Wolfman2000>
so HTML5 and XHTML use the same thing?

[09:46:00.0000] <Wolfman2000>
...I'll rephrase better. All I have to do is make sure my HTML5 is well formed and pass the right mime type, and it magically works?

[09:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
Yes, except it's not magic because you're following all the steps needed to make it work :-)

[09:48:00.0000] <Wolfman2000>
I wasn't expecting magic

[09:48:01.0000] <Wolfman2000>
I think most of my code is well formed as is at least.

[09:48:02.0000] <Philip`>
It's generally very difficult to guarantee well-formedness, so you should probably avoid it as much as possible

[09:48:03.0000] <Philip`>
and only use XHTML for pages that really require it

[09:49:00.0000] <Philip`>
(There's also quite a few subtle behavioural differences, which can break things)

[09:49:01.0000] <Wolfman2000>
Philip`: the only pages that require XML are the generated charts...and hopefully the new javascript chart editor I want to get working.

[09:49:02.0000] <Wolfman2000>
so...what's the best validator to use in this case? W3 doesn't offer XHTML5

[09:50:00.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor might be sensible in suggesting using <object> instead, so most of your page is plain old HTML and it just embeds a minimal amount of SVG XML in the <object>

[09:50:01.0000] <Philip`>
and you can put scripts in the outer HTML page, and have them manipulate the inner SVG page's DOM

[09:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
http://html5.validator.nu/ should work

[09:54:00.0000] <lazni>

[07:07:00.0000] <asmodai>
Heard about the EDPS suggestion for webbrowser builders?

[07:08:00.0000] <Dashiva>
No, what is it?

[07:08:01.0000] <asmodai>
EDPS is the European privacy watchdog

[07:08:02.0000] <asmodai>
they want that browser vendors by default refuse cookies from advertising networks

[07:08:03.0000] <asmodai>
http://www.edps.europa.eu/EDPSWEB/webdav/site/mySite/shared/Documents/Consultation/Opinions/2010/10-03-19_Trust_Information_Society_EN.pdf

[07:09:00.0000] <asmodai>
See page 17 onward

[07:09:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
"Validation can then be used as a quick check to determine whether the code is the clean work of a seasoned HTML author, or quickly hacked-together tag soup."

[07:10:00.0000] <asmodai>
The steps that users must take to opt-out seem not only complicated but also excessive (first he must set his browser to accept cookies, then exercise the opt-out option).

[07:11:00.0000] <asmodai>
Therefore, while legally speaking, Article 5(3) of the ePrivacy Directive provides for effective legal protection, in practice, Internet users are deemed to consent to be monitored for the purposes of sending behavioural advertisement when in fact, in many, if not most cases, they are fully unaware that the monitoring takes place.

[07:11:01.0000] <asmodai>
As described above, web browsers commonly allow a level of control over certain kinds of cookies. Currently, the default settings of most web browsers are accepting all cookies. In other words, by default, the browsers are set to accept all cookies, independently of the purpose of the cookie.

[07:12:00.0000] <asmodai>
[...] Furthermore, there is no privacy wizard on the first install or update of browser applications.

[07:12:01.0000] <asmodai>
Looks like they're urging on legislation as well.

[07:13:00.0000] <asmodai>
Which would mean that browsers in the EU would have to refuse 3rd party cookies by default

[07:13:01.0000] <asmodai>
and implement a privacy wizard

[07:13:02.0000] <Dashiva>
I wonder if they know about SharedObjects

"Currently, the default settings of most web browsers are accepting all cookies."

[11:33:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Say I have a collection of 10 blog previews, each with a title and part of the first paragraph of the blog; would all of these pieces belong to a section or an article?

[11:33:01.0000] <hober>
each piece in <article>

[11:35:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Okay, so now say I have a rotating banner of various slogans pointing to articles, similar to the previews, but now in <img /> form, would you still recommend several <article>s?  I feel like the entire group is either an article or a section.

[11:36:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I may be changing our rotating banner @ http://www.liferay.com/ in response to http://html5gallery.com/2010/03/liferay/ since I'm on the fence about whether or not I agree with their assertion.

[11:37:00.0000] <hober>
see http://edward.oconnor.cx/2009/09/using-the-html5-sectioning-elements#archive-pages for more

[11:38:00.0000] <hober>
I would still recommend several <article>s, yeah

[11:38:01.0000] <hober>
<div class="fancy-banner-thingy"><article>...</article><article>...</article>...</div>

[11:39:00.0000] <hober>
(<article>s with <a rel="bookmark" ...><img ...></a> inside)

[11:39:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Well, in that case, wouldn't they belong to a banner section?

[11:40:00.0000] <hober>
Only use <section> if it a) has its own heading and b) should affect the document outline

[11:40:01.0000] <hober>
I don't see a heading that refers to the collection of those blurbs

[11:41:00.0000] <hober>
<section> doesn't just mean "<div> 2: <div> harder"

[11:41:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Well, in this case, since they are part of the larger page and not on a page of their own, they would have a heading.

[11:42:00.0000] <hober>
yes, each <article> has an obvious heading. I'm talking about the parent element.

[11:42:01.0000] <hober>
the parent element doesn't have its own heading, so far as I can see

[11:43:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Yes, I'm refering to the parent element which wraps all of the articles.  At Liferay.com, we do have a heading to label the banners.

[11:43:01.0000] <hober>
I don't see one

[11:43:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
View the page without styling.

[11:43:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Our presentational style is to remove the heading.

[11:44:00.0000] <hober>
OK

[11:44:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
As a group of previews of articles or an archive of articles, I think a heading is fitting, especially when there are other areas on the site which are not.

[11:44:02.0000] <hober>
in that case, yeah, I'd use <section><h1>banners</h1><article>...</article>...</section>

[11:44:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
on the site = on the page

[11:45:00.0000] <asmodai>
mmm, that sputnik site is interesting

[11:46:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
hober, I'm compelled to feel that way too, except that http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/sections.html#the-article-element does note <article> content is "intended to be independently distributable or reusable"

[11:47:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Whereas an archive may be such, previews of blog posts or a rotating banner may not.

[11:47:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[19:20:00.0000] <wolf2k_ubuntu>
Evening. So far my XHTML5 SVG web app is coming along. I've run into an issue, however. Due to the nature of the app, I have to be able to insert SVG elements dynamically. Without some sort of z-index, all new elements are overlayed on top: that's not what I'm after. Based on my own testing, I don't think SVG elements respect HTML's z-index CSS attribute. Is there an alternative?

[19:24:00.0000] <wolf2k_ubuntu>
...nevermind. I got the answer. Painters model.

[19:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>
wolf2k_ubuntu: I am surprised that SVG elements don't respect z-index - I believe they should

[19:53:00.0000] <wolf2k_ubuntu>
othermaciej: Try talking to them for version 1.2, whenever that comes

[19:53:01.0000] <wolf2k_ubuntu>
Either way, you've got a new FAQ now. Even if it's not so F

[19:54:00.0000] <othermaciej>
by "should" I mean I expect that to work now - do you have a test case to show that it doesn't work?

[19:54:01.0000] <wolf2k_ubuntu>
othermaciej: Unless you plan on visiting my house and seeing my development area this instant, don't think I can easily show it

[19:54:02.0000] <wolf2k_ubuntu>
It's a combination of XHTML, SVG, and JS

[19:56:00.0000] <wolf2k_ubuntu>
This app will be adding and removing elements dynamically. Now we've hit the point where I basically have to keep track of the nodes.

[19:56:01.0000] <roc>
according to the spec, z-index should not work on SVG elements (except possibly a positioned <svg> element with non-SVG parent)

[19:56:02.0000] <roc>
everyone agrees we need to change SVG to support some form of z-index

[19:57:00.0000] <wolf2k_ubuntu>
I can work around it. jQuery will be a big help.

[19:57:01.0000] <roc>
jwatt and I have argued pretty hard that we should support CSS z-index directly, with stacking contexts etc

[19:57:02.0000] <wolf2k_ubuntu>
But if you need someone else to sign your petition, you've got me

[19:58:00.0000] <wolf2k_ubuntu>
I had a ball of a time getting a mouseover/mousemove shadow rectangle to display over the SVG due to lack of z-index

[19:58:01.0000] <roc>
other people have argued that CSS z-index stacking contexts are not necessary for SVG

[19:58:02.0000] <wolf2k_ubuntu>
I personally think it should be available.

[20:01:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it looks like WebKit ignores z-index on SVG elements

[20:01:01.0000] <othermaciej>
seems bogus to me

[20:01:02.0000] <wolf2k_ubuntu>
othermaciej: Firefox does it too

[20:01:03.0000] <othermaciej>
roc: you could just say that nothing besides the SVG root element creates a stacking context

[20:02:00.0000] <othermaciej>
roc: that's assuming CSS position does not apply to SVG elements

[20:02:01.0000] <roc>
Then SVG elements with z-index not 'auto' would be positioned but not create a stacking context for their descendants

[20:02:02.0000] <roc>
which would be weird

[20:02:03.0000] <roc>
I mean positioned in z-order

[20:03:00.0000] <roc>
Webkit and Firefox are just following the current spec

[20:03:01.0000] <othermaciej>
is there any way to escape your ancestor's stacking context in CSS?

[20:03:02.0000] <roc>
one reason to want stacking contexts for SVG is that you want 'opacity' and 'filter' and other effects to induce a stacking context

[20:03:03.0000] <roc>
no

[20:04:00.0000] <roc>
otherwise you get weirdness like a blur filter applied to an element subtree, but the element's children are not all part of the same rendering group because there's another non-blurred element in between

[20:05:00.0000] <roc>
and then it becomes really unclear what the rendered results should be, or how to produce them

[20:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I see

[20:06:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think most SVG elements either have their own rendering, or contain other elements that may have rendering, but not both

[20:08:00.0000] <roc>
that's true, but doesn't help us here, I think

[20:45:00.0000] <othermaciej>
roc: the reason I mention it is that this may seem like a reason to not support stacking contexts, although you could argue the opposite on the same basis I think

[20:46:00.0000] <roc>
it may *seem* like a reason but I don't think it actually is :-)

[00:27:00.0000] <hsivonen>
does anyone have data on what maximum values different browser engines place on attribute value length?

[00:29:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it looks like WebKit will accept arbitrarily long attribute names (until you run out of RAM or characters in your stream)

[00:29:01.0000] <othermaciej>
checking values now

[00:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>
wait, I'm wrong

[00:30:01.0000] <othermaciej>
1024 is the limit for attribute names

[00:30:02.0000] <othermaciej>
now checking vlues

[00:31:00.0000] <othermaciej>
attribute values can be as long as you can fit in the source file

[00:31:01.0000] <othermaciej>
at least as far as parsing goes

[00:31:02.0000] <hsivonen>
ouch

[00:32:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if added via the DOM, either name or value can be as long as you can fit in a String

[00:32:01.0000] <hsivonen>
so you can OOM with <a a="aaaaaa.....

[00:32:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it won't crash, but it can use up a lot of memory before an allocation fails

[00:32:03.0000] <othermaciej>
that's assuming your source was long enough for that in the first place

[00:33:00.0000] <hsivonen>
well, the HTML5 specs is probably larger than any page Schwab's banking UI

[00:33:01.0000] <othermaciej>
and did not itself get too big to fit in RAM as UTF-16

[00:33:02.0000] <hsivonen>
so if I made the DoS limit the size of the HTML5 spec, banking sites probably wouldn't break...

[00:34:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Gecko is getting an infallible malloc, so it might be a problem to have the parser thread request so much memory that infallible malloc has to scramble for more memory on the main thread

[00:35:00.0000] <hsivonen>
not sure how exactly these things are supposed to work

[00:35:01.0000] <othermaciej>
in fallible?

[00:35:02.0000] <hsivonen>
never returns null

[00:35:03.0000] <othermaciej>
what happens if you exhaust the address space?

[00:35:04.0000] <Hixie>
does it buy more ram for you?

[00:35:05.0000] <hsivonen>
I believe it kills the app

[00:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
we have a version of malloc that will crash if it runs out of memory but we have a few places that are safe against allocation failure

[00:36:01.0000] <othermaciej>
and thus do not use that variant

[00:36:02.0000] <hsivonen>
though IIRC, some design doc says that it's going to ask things to stop when there's little RAM left

[00:36:03.0000] <othermaciej>
(theory being that clean crash beats a buffer overrun)

[00:37:00.0000] <hsivonen>
I wonder if IE has a hard limit on attribute value length.

[00:37:01.0000] <hsivonen>
maybe I should just bite the bullet and test

[00:37:02.0000] <othermaciej>
we did find that for attribute *names*, 1024 is a sufficient practical limit

[00:37:03.0000] <othermaciej>
not sure it would fly for values

[00:38:00.0000] <Philip`>
Does it say in the IE interoperability reports that were released recently?

[00:38:01.0000] <Philip`>
/me vaguely remembers them mentioning limits, compared to the limits HTML4 mentions, or something

[00:38:02.0000] <othermaciej>
tag names also have a 1024 limit

[00:38:03.0000] <othermaciej>
(in the HTML parser only)

[00:39:00.0000] <hsivonen>
my plan is to change the tokenizer to use the same buffer for both names and values

[00:39:01.0000] <Philip`>
I've seen pages with tens of kilobytes of text in an <img alt> attribute

[00:39:02.0000] <hsivonen>
because you can't be tokenizing an attribute name and value at the same time

[00:39:03.0000] <Hixie>
meta content (with name=keywords) also often has huge values

[00:39:04.0000] <Hixie>
sometimes it is missing quotes and you end up with bazillions of attributes

[00:39:05.0000] <hsivonen>
the only case where the tokenizer needs two accumulation buffers is when a character reference is being tokenized inside an attribute value

[00:39:06.0000] <othermaciej>
we use a variable-size buffer with a small inline capacity for attribute values

[00:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
i.e. in the common case it doesn't malloc, just uses a fixed-size buffer, but will malloc on overflow

[00:40:01.0000] <hsivonen>
but in that case, the other buffer can't grow longer that the longest named character name

[00:40:02.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: truncating keywords isn't fatal

[00:41:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: truncating huge attributes on Schwab's netbank apparently is

[00:41:01.0000] <Hixie>
<input type=hidden value="">?

[00:42:00.0000] <hsivonen>
Hixie: not sure. I don't have login credentials.

[04:13:00.0000] <Philip`>

[04:16:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[04:16:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[04:19:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[04:20:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[04:27:00.0000] <Philip`>

[04:27:01.0000] <Philip`>
http://www.copyright.gov/title17/92chap2.html#204 - "A transfer of copyright ownership, other than by operation of law, is not valid unless an instrument of conveyance, or a note or memorandum of the transfer, is in writing and signed by the owner of the rights conveyed or such owner's duly authorized agent." etc

[04:28:00.0000] <Philip`>
("A “transfer of copyright ownership” is an assignment, mortgage, exclusive license, [...] but not including a nonexclusive license.")

[04:29:00.0000] <Philip`>

[04:30:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[06:26:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
<roc> the comment about "better browser" is slightly annoying given http://weblogs.mozillazine.org/bz/archives/020267.html <-- Incorrect but fast can legitimately be called "better" than correct but slow.  Browsers are meant to create a good user experience, not conform to standards at all costs.  Realistically, IMO, refraining from fully implementing features until you can do so with no performance regression does make for a better browser f

[06:26:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
rom a user standpoint.  As Dave Hyatt points out on that post, it's just not fully implemented -- should they have not implemented it at all until they could get all corner cases right?

[06:29:00.0000] <annevk>

[06:29:01.0000] <annevk>

[06:30:01.0000] <AryehGregor>

[06:40:00.0000] <ment>
AryehGregor: the problem with css and js is, that you have to maintain correct styling during execution of the script

[06:42:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
What do you mean?  You don't have to rerender styles synchronously during script execution, right?  If I do foo.width = 100; foo.height = 100; then foo is never actually rendered with width 100 but not height 100, AFAIK.

[06:42:01.0000] <gsnedders>
AryehGregor: No, but if you reflow during script execution perf can be bad (as is the case with HTML5 and Opera, which reflows on a timeout during script execution)

[06:43:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Mm.

[06:43:01.0000] <ment>

[10:33:05.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[10:34:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[10:34:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[10:35:00.0000] <erlehmann>

[10:36:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[10:37:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[10:37:01.0000] <zcorpan>
or 7 heading levels

[10:37:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[10:38:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[10:39:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
I would label them ".sectioning-content" vs ".sectioning-element" to describe what it contains rather than what it is (like how roles work, example being main the container isn't itself the main content but contains the main content) ... which (tangent) is also why I do not like naming things "container".

[11:12:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
href is not a required attribute of base?

[11:13:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
It is ... but html5.validator.nu and validator.w3.org let it slide.

[11:14:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>
It took IE6 for me to find that out.

[11:14:01.0000] <annevk>
is it?

[11:14:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
I don't think href is required on base

[11:14:03.0000] <annevk>
it's not required

[11:14:04.0000] <JonathanNeal>
"A base element must have either an href attribute, a target attribute, or both."

[11:14:05.0000] <JonathanNeal>
http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/#the-base-element

[11:14:06.0000] <annevk>
right, so href is not required if target is there

[11:15:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[11:15:01.0000] <MikeSmith>
hmm, this is probably a bug in the validator

[11:15:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
in the schema

[11:16:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
yeah

[11:16:01.0000] <MikeSmith>

[11:18:00.0000] <MikeSmith>

[11:18:01.0000] <paul_irishhhh>

[11:42:00.0000] <annevk>

[11:45:01.0000] <annevk>

[11:46:00.0000] <annevk>

[11:48:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[11:49:00.0000] <zcorpan>
while opera lies and fires them early because we haven't implemented it properly yet

[11:51:00.0000] <zcorpan>

[10:18:00.0000] <CrazyFoam>
Hello, I have a question regarding XML Namespaces

[10:18:01.0000] <CrazyFoam>
say I have <a xmlns="urn:a" xmlns:b="urn:b"> <b:b> <c/> </b:b> </a>

[10:18:02.0000] <CrazyFoam>
element <c/> is assumed to be in namespace urn:a

[10:19:00.0000] <CrazyFoam>
but if I have <a:a xmlns:a="urn:a" xmlns:b="urn:b"> <b:b> <c/> </b:b> </a:a>

[10:19:01.0000] <CrazyFoam>
is element <c/> invalid or assumed to be in namespace urn:b?

[10:20:00.0000] <Philip`>
In the second case, the <c/> is in no namespace

[10:20:01.0000] <Philip`>
(which is a perfectly legitimate thing to do)

[10:20:02.0000] <CrazyFoam>
ah that's what I thought, but how is it legitimate

[10:20:03.0000] <CrazyFoam>
say the doc has no default namespace

[10:20:04.0000] <Philip`>
XML doesn't require namespaces

[10:20:05.0000] <CrazyFoam>
whatever processing the doc may not be able to understand <c/>

[10:21:00.0000] <Philip`>
You could write <a><b><c/></b></a> and the <c/> would be in no namespace, just as in your example

[10:21:01.0000] <Philip`>
Namespaces don't cause understanding

[10:22:00.0000] <annevk>
they just cause confusion

[10:22:01.0000] <CrazyFoam>
haha

[10:22:02.0000] <Philip`>
I could write <a:axghrlktxjhlkj xmlns:a="urn:a"/> and whatever's processing the document would have just as much chance of understanding it as of understanding <c/>

[10:22:03.0000] <Dashiva>
You could use the namespace URI as input to a RDF-based knowledge network that would provide all the data you need!

[10:23:00.0000] <Philip`>
You'd want some kind of schema if you want to restrict the document to known elements

[10:23:01.0000] <CrazyFoam>
knowledge network haha

[10:24:00.0000] <CrazyFoam>
okay well thanks for the info, really what i was looking for is that <c/> in the last case defeintiely shouldn't get interptreted as belonging to either urn:a or urn:b

[10:25:00.0000] <Philip`>
Yep - if it has no prefix then it's in the default namespace, and the default namespace is only affected by xmlns="..."

[10:27:00.0000] <CrazyFoam>
on that note, what do you call it when a doc changes default namespace all over the place, e.g. <doc xmlns="urn:doc"> <a xmlns="urn:a"/> <b xmlns="urn:b"/> </doc>, still valid right? can't think of a term to search for specifications - "default namespace switching"?

[10:36:00.0000] <Philip`>
CrazyFoam: You mean when it changes the default namespace in non-root elements?

[10:37:00.0000] <Philip`>
I guess it's neurotic by the definitions in http://lists.xml.org/archives/xml-dev/200204/msg00170.html

[10:40:00.0000] <CrazyFoam>
hmmm... is that post discussing maintaining prefix names through serialization?

[10:41:00.0000] <Philip`>
That's part of it

[10:41:01.0000] <CrazyFoam>
ah got to the neruotic part

[10:41:02.0000] <CrazyFoam>
what is a GI?

[10:43:00.0000] <Philip`>
Tag name

[10:43:01.0000] <Philip`>
('Generic identifier')

[06:15:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
hsivonen: btw, when I run jing from the command line in Terminal on OSX, I get "?" characters instead of curly quotes

[06:15:01.0000] <hsivonen>
MikeSmith: you need to set the terminal to UTF-8

[06:15:02.0000] <MikeSmith>
e.g., rror: Element ?base? from namespace ?http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml? is missing one or more of the following attributes: [href, target]

[06:15:03.0000] <hsivonen>
MikeSmith: or if your terminal is in UTF-8, you need to set the System.out to UTF-8

[06:16:00.0000] <MikeSmith>
ah, OK

[06:16:01.0000] <hsivonen>
there's a magic java system property for that

[06:16:02.0000] <hsivonen>
it's very sad if Apple still keeps Java defaulting to MacRoman

[06:17:00.0000] <hsivonen>
the system property is file.encoding

[06:17:01.0000] <hsivonen>
-Dfile.encoding=UTF-8 should do the trick

[06:17:02.0000] <MikeSmith>

[20:53:00.0000] <Traveler1>
What are your thoughts on multiple H1 tags on a page?

[20:54:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Multiple top-level headings, or just using multiple <h1>s and letting them take implicit levels based on sectioning elements?

[20:54:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
(That is, doing <h1>foo</h1><section><h1>bar</h1></section> rather than <h1>foo</h1><h2>bar</h2>.)

[20:54:02.0000] <Traveler1>
Well if you're site calls for it

[20:55:00.0000] <Traveler1>
A lot of people say that one should use only once the h1 tag. 

[20:55:01.0000] <Traveler1>
Hm no

[20:56:00.0000] <Traveler1>
For example on the homepage of a blog. You will find a few posts(3,4) 

[20:56:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Most of the time you'll have a single definite "top level" heading, and so a single <h1> is appropriate to mark that up, with <h2> or lower for other stuff.

[20:56:02.0000] <Traveler1>
The titles are h1's.

[20:56:03.0000] <Traveler1>
The subtitles(if any) are h2. and so on so forth.

[20:56:04.0000] <Traveler1>
Would you say that's a bad practice?

[20:57:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
No, I think that's just fine.  However, those <h1>s likely aren't actually the top-level heading of the page (probably the blog title is), so make sure that they are wrapped in something that properly scopes them, like <article> or <section>.

[20:57:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
That way they won't be registered as being the same level of heading as the blog title is.

[20:58:00.0000] <Traveler1>
so <article><h1>title</h1></article> ?

[20:59:00.0000] <Traveler1>
The blog title is just the title. I don't get why people wrap it in h1. 

[20:59:01.0000] <Traveler1>
It has it's freaggin tag <title> 

[20:59:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
Well, like <body><h1>My blog!</h1><article><h1>Post about my cat</h1><p>My cat rocks.</p></article><article><h1>More cat info!</h1><p>Really.</p></article></body>

[20:59:03.0000] <Traveler1>
not like that.

[21:00:00.0000] <Traveler1>
what's that lonely h1 doing after the body tag?

[21:00:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
...? People wrap the title in an <h1> because it's the top-level heading, and because it's difficult to display the <title>.

[21:00:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
That's the blog title.

[21:00:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
(Thus the words inside of it.)

[21:02:00.0000] <Traveler1>
A heading element briefly describes the topic of the section it introduces. 

[21:02:01.0000] <Traveler1>
Wouldn't it be logically correct to use it as I described it above? 

[21:03:00.0000] <Traveler1>
and just skip the h1 tag for the title

[21:04:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
You could, sure, but then the page as a whole doesn't have a heading.

[21:04:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>
Wow

[21:04:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>
That was a long 15 minutes.

[21:04:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Because the <h1> is the heading for the article.

[21:04:04.0000] <TabAtkins>

[21:04:05.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[17:43:00.0000] <othermaciej>
/me would appreciate input on his recent bugs from people who know more about document conformance

[17:51:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
othermaciej, they all look good to me.

[18:52:00.0000] <othermaciej>
like I don't know the deep reason <nobr> and <wbr> are nonconforming

[18:52:01.0000] <othermaciej>
maybe just because they never were conforming before?

[18:52:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I would guess it's because, unlike <pre> and <br>, they were not in any previous spec.

[18:52:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yeah.

[18:53:00.0000] <Dashiva>
They don't feel entirely semantic to me. Line breaking (or not) is fairly deep into CSS territory.

[18:53:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Then why doesn't that apply to <pre>?

[18:53:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or <br>?

[18:53:03.0000] <Dashiva>
Of course, <wbr> can't really be emulated

[18:53:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also, as Maciej points out, <wbr> can't be emulated -- yeah.

[18:54:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'm also planning to file a bug requesting that most or all presentational attributes/elements be made conforming (possibly obsolete but conforming so they throw an error).  Something like <table cellpadding=5> is difficult to reproduce exactly in inline CSS, and even more difficult to convert automatically.  And some, like cellspacing, have no direct CSS equivalent that works in (for example) IE6.

[18:54:01.0000] <Dashiva>
<pre> is different, because it says the whitespace is significant

[18:54:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
s/so they throw an error/so they raise a warning/

[18:54:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Dashiva, <nobr> says line breaks are significant.

[18:55:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Er.

[18:55:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or, no.

[18:55:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
What does it do?

[18:55:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
/me has never used it

[18:55:04.0000] <Dashiva>
It prevents line breaking

[18:55:05.0000] <Dashiva>
<pre> gives meaning to the whitespace within it. <nobr> is just a formatting guideline.

[18:55:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
Then what does Maciej mean by "<nobr> should be considered just as semantic as <pre> or <br>, with a semantic of 'a block of text with preformatted line breaks.'"?

[18:55:07.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's not preformatted line breaks, it just doesn't have any line breaks.

[18:56:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
That does seem like CSS territory to me.

[18:56:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
<wbr> less so, because it's hard to see how you'd even implement such a feature in CSS -- it inherently requires a particular point to be flagged in the markup itself.

[18:57:00.0000] <Dashiva>
It's surely angels and pins territory, but to me <pre> is a clear step away from <br>, <wbr>, <nobr>

[18:58:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Really?  <br> and <wbr> seem like they have to be in HTML to me.  <nobr> I agree with you on, more or less.

[18:58:01.0000] <Dashiva>
They have to be, but only because we can't express it any other way

[18:58:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, eh.

[18:58:03.0000] <othermaciej>
AryehGregor: Sam Ruby has a bug open specifically about some particular examples of presentational table markup

[18:59:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
<nobr> really means "there are no line breaks here".

[18:59:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
othermaciej, oh, really?

[18:59:02.0000] <Dashiva>
<wbr> is sort of like &shy;

[18:59:03.0000] <othermaciej>
let me see if I can find it

[18:59:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=7468

[18:59:05.0000] <Dashiva>
(only there's no hyphen involved, obviously)

[19:00:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess I described <nobr> incorrectly in my bug

[19:00:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
"This use case is handled by <style scoped> in HTML5."

[19:00:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's actually a good point.

[19:00:03.0000] <othermaciej>
AryehGregor: that's the one

[19:00:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Once that's supported, the table markup could be easily replaced.

[19:00:05.0000] <Dashiva>
Well, zzz time, *poof*

[19:01:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I'm not sure I buy that argument

[19:01:01.0000] <othermaciej>
about <style scoped>

[19:01:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess it is more compact than putting a style= attribute on every cell, but it's probably still less compact than the presentational attributes

[19:01:03.0000] <othermaciej>
and it's not clear to me that the accessibility / media independence argument applies in this particular case

[19:03:00.0000] <mpilgrim>
ooh, if we added <nobr> and <wbr> to html5, ppk's compatibility tables could finally validate

[19:03:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I think the real argument in favor of pushing for the use of CSS is consistency.  There's never any actual difference between using presentational markup and equivalent inline CSS, but CSS is a much more powerful and general mechanism, and is the only styling mechanism to be supported going forward.  A language that didn't include presentational markup beyond inline style would be much simpler.

[19:03:02.0000] <othermaciej>
mpilgrim: he uses those?

[19:03:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't know whether that's a good enough reason to make them invalid, though, rather than obsolete but conforming.

[19:04:00.0000] <daedb>
http://www.quirksmode.org/oddsandends/wbr.html

[19:04:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think whitespace treatment is something that is on the fine edge between semantics and presentation

[19:05:00.0000] <othermaciej>
sometimes, a particular whitespace treatment is really part of the information in the document, not just a matter of how you present it

[19:11:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Poetry and computer code are standard examples of that.

[19:11:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Although <pre> usually suffices for both, if you suppress the monotype font for poetry.

[20:08:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
othermaciej et al.: I just filed a bug "Many, most, or all obsolete features should be conforming".  http://www.w3.org/Bugs/Public/show_bug.cgi?id=9355

[20:10:00.0000] <othermaciej>
AryehGregor: I would recommend filing bugs that are narrower in scope than that

[20:10:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Really?  Why?

[20:10:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
I give clear reasoning that applies to *all* obsolete features.

[20:10:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
I.e., I argue that features should not be non-conforming merely because they're obsolete.  The same logic applies to nearly all features that are non-conforming because they're obsolete.

[20:10:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't see how I would be able to narrow the bug.

[20:11:00.0000] <othermaciej>
None of the features that are non-conforming "merely because they're obsolete"

[20:11:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Really?

[20:11:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
It looks like they are to me.

[20:11:03.0000] <othermaciej>
obsolete is a specific subcategory of "non-conforming"

[20:11:04.0000] <othermaciej>
it is not a justification, it is a label

[20:11:05.0000] <othermaciej>
the rationale for things being noncomforming is in the new section Hixie just added

[20:12:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[20:12:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Maybe I missed it.

[20:12:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The various features are listed as being obsolete, and the only hint as to why is that alternative markup is suggested.

[20:12:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
I mean, as non-conforming.

[20:12:04.0000] <othermaciej>
hang on, waiting for spec to load

[20:13:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it used to be there was no in-sepc rationale that said why those things are nonconforming

[20:13:01.0000] <othermaciej>
*in-spec

[20:13:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The implication (to me) is that the only reason they're non-conforming is because these other features exist, which are in most cases exactly equivalent but are considered better for various reasons.

[20:13:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
They can't actually be very much better if they're functionally identical, of course.

[20:30:00.0000] <AryehGregor>

[20:30:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[20:30:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[20:30:03.0000] <othermaciej>

[20:30:04.0000] <othermaciej>
AryehGregor: ^

[20:31:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Aha.

[20:31:01.0000] <othermaciej>
that states many individual reasons for particular author conformance requirements

[20:31:02.0000] <othermaciej>
none of the justifications amounts to "is obsolete"

[20:31:03.0000] <othermaciej>
you may disagree with some of them, or you may feel some things marked obsolete and nonconforming when none of those criteria apply

[20:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I didn't know about that.

[20:32:01.0000] <othermaciej>
yeah, it's new

[20:32:02.0000] <AryehGregor>

[20:32:03.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie added that in response to bug 7034

[20:32:04.0000] <othermaciej>
I think your bug is arguably just a duplicate of bug 7034

[20:32:05.0000] <othermaciej>
(which is titled "remove or replace author conformance requirements")

[20:33:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess it is slightly less narrow in that it's limited to the obsolete section

[20:33:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
No, I only argue for removing a subset of them.

[20:33:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but that's kind of arbitrary

[20:33:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
There are lots of author conformance requirements that I think are a good idea.

[20:33:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
For instance, they can help to catch authoring mistakes.

[20:33:05.0000] <othermaciej>
note that not everything in the obsolete section is even presentational, though much of your argument is about presentational markups pecifically

[20:33:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or inform authors of areas where they might be running into interoperability problems, or pressure authors to do something that we have good reason to want them to do (e.g., alt="").

[20:34:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Thus the many/most/all in the bug summary.

[20:34:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Much of it applies to all of them, I think.

[20:35:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
It looks like the justification for presentational markup offers no arguments that couldn't equally apply to style="".

[20:35:01.0000] <othermaciej>
that's why it gives a specific reason for exempting style=""

[20:35:02.0000] <othermaciej>
which you may or may not agree with

[20:35:03.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway

[20:35:04.0000] <othermaciej>
I think a bug about just presentational markup might make sense

[20:35:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
Maybe I'll repurpose it.

[20:35:06.0000] <othermaciej>
I don't see how your argument applies to, say, <bgsound>

[20:35:07.0000] <othermaciej>
or <applet>

[20:36:00.0000] <othermaciej>
or <frameset>

[20:36:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I don't know what the first two do, really.

[20:36:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but if you make the bug be about that, then I suggest you should address Ian's argument in the rationale

[20:36:03.0000] <othermaciej>
well if you don't know what they do, you probably don't have enough info to suggest they should be conforming :-)

[20:36:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
<frameset> is something that's banned because it's considered to be something authors should almost never do, because it has serious problems, although they might be tempted to do it.

[20:36:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
Which is why I didn't say all obsolete features should be conforming.

[20:37:00.0000] <othermaciej>
if you say many/most/all, then you are asking someone else to guess what you mean

[20:38:00.0000] <othermaciej>
all I'm saying is, make it clear enough that no one has to guess which ones you have in mind

[20:38:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
I guess I can present a narrow argument, and he can extend it to everything else it applies to if he likes.

[20:39:00.0000] <othermaciej>
well, even "presentational" is a fairly clear category, though there may be edge cases that are hard to judge

[20:40:00.0000] <othermaciej>
most obsolete nonconforming features are that way for reason of being presentational it seems, but there are quite a few exceptions which generally have an independent and plausible reason to be banned

[20:41:00.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway, this is mainly my advice on how to make a good bug report - if you choose to do nothing, then the project won't blow up or anything, but 

[20:41:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think some revision would be wise

[20:41:02.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway, I won't keep you up any longer

[03:55:00.0000] <jgraham>
AFAICT there is no difference between "obsolete but conforming" and "transitional"

[03:59:00.0000] <othermaciej>
jgraham: in plain english meaning - perhaps not

[03:59:01.0000] <othermaciej>
jgraham: operationally - seems like a fair bit of difference between "mandatory non-error warning" and "you can choose to make all of them errors or all of them silent with a flag inside the document"

[04:00:00.0000] <othermaciej>
from the developer perspective, I like the warning better, if validators have the UI in non-default mode to selectively silence them or force them into errors based on category

[04:03:00.0000] <jgraham>
The difference between "Your document is valid but uses some obsolete features" and "Tour document is validates as HTML transitional" seems rather subtle to me. Presumably the majority of authors using transitional doctypes know that they are using obsolete features

[04:03:01.0000] <jgraham>
*Your

[04:08:00.0000] <othermaciej>
jgraham: the difference in overall wording is subtle, but getting the specific list of uses of obsolete features is a big practical difference

[04:09:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(whether for good or ill, I don't know, though I tend to think for good)

[04:11:00.0000] <jgraham>
Yes, having the list presented is, I guess better

[04:13:00.0000] <othermaciej>
but hey, maybe calling them "transitional features" instead of "obsolete but conforming features" might be better branding

[04:14:00.0000] <jgraham>
If we really must have a list of "features you are allowed to use but validators must warn about", could be get rid of the oxymornic-sounding name, present them with a special obsolete marking, and just say "authors should not use obsolete features. Validators must warn when obsolete features are used"

[04:15:00.0000] <jgraham>
Although I think my preferred solution is still not to have that list

[04:15:01.0000] <othermaciej>
well, there's also obsolete features that are nonconforming and must result in an error

[04:15:02.0000] <othermaciej>
so you can't just use the unqualified term "obsolete"

[04:16:00.0000] <jgraham>
Yeah true

[04:16:01.0000] <jgraham>
They should be called this-is-a-bad-idea-and-you-don't-want-to-do-this-but-hey-experience-suggests-that-you-will-do-anyway features

[04:16:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I think that list and its status is on some level a compromise between Henri, who did not want to spam people with useless errors for markup that is in fact harmless, and Ian, who wanted to alert authors of new documents that there are certain effectively useless constructs which they should not bother with

[04:17:00.0000] <jgraham>
I thought it was mainly a result of the great accessibility wars

[04:17:01.0000] <jgraham>
But I could be misremembering

[04:17:02.0000] <othermaciej>
there is only one item in there on the basis of accessibility

[04:18:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess before that it was a list of "downplayed errors"

[04:18:01.0000] <jgraham>
Yes, that's what I recall

[04:18:02.0000] <othermaciej>
but the concept of "downplayed error" is silly

[04:18:03.0000] <jgraham>
Well so is "obsolete but conforming"

[04:18:04.0000] <othermaciej>
that too

[04:19:00.0000] <othermaciej>
my own suggestion was to just describe them in terms of the effect ('"validators must issue a warning when X") instead of as a conceptual category

[04:21:00.0000] <othermaciej>
yeah, other than summary, all the others seem to be more in the "waste of electrons" category

[04:22:00.0000] <othermaciej>
but there's only 6 things total in the "obsolete but conforming" category

[04:23:00.0000] <othermaciej>
which makes it seem like a waste to name it, especially when the name is confusing to so many peple

[04:23:01.0000] <othermaciej>
*people

[04:23:02.0000] <jgraham>
It seems like one possible future is that a lot more things end up as obsolete but conforming

[04:24:00.0000] <othermaciej>
could be

[04:24:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I think so far only Aryeh has outright advocated that path, but his particular proposal would indeed turn the category into "transitional"

[04:25:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it's kind of a lie to call it "transitional" if it's been over 10 years and the transition still hasn't happened...

[04:25:01.0000] <jgraham>
Indeed

[04:25:02.0000] <othermaciej>
anyway I am almost finished breaking down all the errors in the conformance error study

[04:26:00.0000] <othermaciej>
http://www.w3.org/html/wg/wiki/index.php?title=HTML5_Authoring_Conformance_Study

[04:26:01.0000] <othermaciej>
only ebay and nytimes remain to be typed in

[04:27:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it seems like unescaped & is the most common single error, by far

[04:28:00.0000] <othermaciej>
and after that I guess presentational markup

[04:28:01.0000] <othermaciej>
X-UA-Compatible is surprisingly common, but since it is anti-interoperability by design, it seems silly to make it conforming

[04:29:00.0000] <othermaciej>
there are surprisingly many sites with a stray close tag, also

[04:36:00.0000] <jgraham>
Not that surprising; it's almost always totally harmless, an easy error to make, and hard to spot

[04:39:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think the main reason for stray close tag to be an error is that there are a lot of authoring mistakes that would show up that way (forgetting to close a tag at all near some that may implicitly close, wrong close tag, misnested tags, etc)

[05:16:00.0000] <Philip`>
Why is x-ua-compatible anti-interoperability, when including it makes pages work in *more* browsers than if it was not included?

[05:22:00.0000] <Philip`>
(It would be a problem if people used x-ua-compatible as a way to avoid having to write code that works in browsers that follow standards better, but in practice it seems more commonly used on sites that already have a standards-browser codepath plus an IE7 codepath and don't want to add an extra codepath for IE8 since it's too different from the existing ones)

[05:23:00.0000] <Philip`>
(so it's not causing any disadvantage to browsers that implement standards better than IE does)

[08:23:00.0000] <Dashiva>
"The absence of Theora (or Dirac) as baseline codec means that a good portion of user agents will likely omit Theora support"

[08:23:01.0000] <Dashiva>
If you accept that people will be wrong on the internet, is it preferale that they be wrong the same way even after being corrected, or that they come up with new ways to be wrong every time?

[10:09:00.0000] <divya>
I have a question regarding the flow content as defined in HTML5 spec: http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/dom.html#flow-content

[10:11:00.0000] <divya>
the spec says "Most elements that are used in the body of documents and applications are categorized as flow content." but the pictorial representation seems to indicate the only way an element wont be a flow content is if it is meta data content (and somehow not be flow content). http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/images/content-venn.svg Is this right? 

[10:12:00.0000] <divya>
or are there hard rules that can be used to define if an element is flow content or not (spec does not define one)? 

[10:14:00.0000] <Dashiva>
Each element specifies which categories it is in

[10:16:00.0000] <divya>
Dashiva: can you elaborate? How does it specify? Is it because it belongs to the list of elements specified in the doc?

[10:16:01.0000] <Dashiva>
http://www.w3.org/TR/html5/semantics.html#the-hgroup-element

[10:16:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Categories: Flow content. Heading content. formatBlock candidate.

[10:17:00.0000] <divya>
Dashiva: got it. so there is no rule, except to refer to the doc to find out if an element is a flow element or not. 

[10:18:00.0000] <paul_irish>
<source> probably isnt flow content

[10:19:00.0000] <divya>
neither is <legend>

[16:10:01.0000] <Dashiva>

[16:19:00.0000] <webben>
Hixie: Seems to me that bug resolves around the question of text /equivalence/ versus identification and that Laura is asking for caption ("descriptive identification") in alt.

[16:22:00.0000] <webben>
Hixie: In particular, the bit quoted from the spec treats "alternative text" as equivalent, whereas the bit quoted from WCAG2 distinguishes "text alternative[s] that serve.. the equivalent purpose" from some superset of text alternatives.

[16:23:00.0000] <webben>
In WCAG2 "text alternative" pretty much just means "programmatically associated text": http://www.w3.org/TR/WCAG/#text-altdef

[16:24:00.0000] <webben>
I think the question needs to be whether inserting "descriptive identification" in @alt versus the other methods the spec mentions is useful or not.

[16:27:00.0000] <webben>
the bug's confused by the fact the webcam image actually contains textual information.

[16:31:00.0000] <Hixie>
webben: yeah i certainly agree that we should provide captions for these images, and that's what the spec suggests -- but it seems obvious that mixing captions and replacements is suboptimal

[16:32:00.0000] <Hixie>
webben: currently i'm just trying to get an accessibility expert to tell me what the alt="" text should be so that i can determine if it is a caption or not

[16:33:00.0000] <Dashiva>
othermaciej: The bugs you changed with "moved back to verified" comment seem to be only at resolved.

[16:33:01.0000] <webben>
Yep I get that. I think there's agreement in that ticket that providing programmatically associated captions is good, and the disagreement is about how to do so.

[16:35:00.0000] <webben>
From a WCAG1/2 Techniques perspective (and common practice I guess), @alt is already overloaded to mix caption and replacement.

[16:37:00.0000] <Hixie>
well wcag1/2 were written in a world where alt="" was required, so it makes sense they'd use that hammer for all their problems

[16:37:01.0000] <Hixie>
but we have the opportunity to think this out better now

[16:46:00.0000] <zcorpan>
wait why doesn't embed fire 'load'?

[18:53:01.0000] <othermaciej>
Hixie: maybe the pragmatic thing to do is to loosen the definition of alt, rather than have complicated rules about what goes where

[18:53:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
A text replacement can be simply read as normal text, while a description can be denoted as such (rather than a seemingly-random bit of description in the middle of content).

[18:55:00.0000] <othermaciej>
I think screen readers typically distinguish both (there's no way typically to get it not to identify an image as such, even if it has alt text)

[18:55:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I suppose text-only UAs might treat them differently, though I am not sure they actually do anything with, for example, the title attribute

[18:55:02.0000] <othermaciej>
so it's hard to predict what they would do if they did

[21:54:03.0000] <othermaciej>
I think Simon is correct that <wbr> does something essentially equivalent to a ZWSP, but I am not sure if it is equivalent in all details or all browsers

[21:55:00.0000] <othermaciej>
however, what the spec says now is definitely wrong:

[21:55:01.0000] <othermaciej>
"The wbr element is expected to override the 'white-space' property and always provide a line-breaking opportunity."

[21:55:02.0000] <othermaciej>
it provides a line-breaking opportunity but it does *not* (as far as I can tell) override the 'white-space' property

[21:55:03.0000] <othermaciej>
at least not in WebKit or Gecko

[21:55:04.0000] <Hixie>
well it definitely overrides <nobr> iirc

[21:55:05.0000] <Hixie>
no?

[21:56:00.0000] <othermaciej>
it doesn't override white-space: pre

[21:56:01.0000] <othermaciej>
let me try nowrap

[21:56:02.0000] <Hixie>
<wbr> and <nobr> are such a huge pain in the neck, i wish we could just get rid of them altogether (like <spacer>), rather than just obsolete them

[21:56:03.0000] <othermaciej>
ah, it does override nowrap

[21:56:04.0000] <othermaciej>
but not pre

[21:56:05.0000] <othermaciej>
so it's not the same as ZWSP

[21:57:00.0000] <othermaciej>
ZWSP doesn't override white-space nowrap

[21:57:01.0000] <othermaciej>
I proposed going the other way, since popular sites actually use them, and at least in the case of <wbr> there is apparently no other way to get the same effect

[21:57:02.0000] <Hixie>
popular sites use all kinds of crap

[21:57:03.0000] <Hixie>
doesn't make it a good idea

[21:58:00.0000] <Hixie>

[21:59:02.0000] <othermaciej>

[22:03:00.0000] <Hixie>

[22:03:02.0000] <miketaylr>
