[22:04:00.0000] <Hixie>
if you're strictly defining line-breaking opportunities without a particular style in mind, then sure, ZWSP is fine

[22:04:01.0000] <Hixie>
if you're actually trying to make headlines flow in various ways depending on the width of the page, or whatnot, then it's CSS

[22:04:02.0000] <Hixie>
sometimes it might be a mixture

[22:04:03.0000] <othermaciej>
at least one use case for <wbr> seems to be a very long run of text containing no whitespace; in many cases ZWSP will work just as well, is just more painful to type

[22:05:00.0000] <Hixie>
often though, <wbr> is used where you would have to move it if you had an alternative style sheet, and that indicates to me that it's not semantic

[22:05:01.0000] <Hixie>
and should be done in CSS instead

[22:05:02.0000] <othermaciej>
in the case of a run of text where you need to inhibit normal line breaking but want explicit break opportunities, then you probably need <wbr> (though I suppose you could replace all your normal whitespace with non-breaking space)

[22:06:00.0000] <othermaciej>
(an example I can imagine like that is pairs of words where you don't want to break in the middle of a pair, only between pairs)

[22:07:00.0000] <Hixie>
&nbsp; and &zwsp; seem like the right way to handle that. It'd even survive transferring to other mediums that use text but don't use HTML.

[22:08:00.0000] <Hixie>
(&zwsp; isn't valid though)

[22:08:01.0000] <Hixie>
(so you'd have to use the entity if you didn't have the unicode character inline)

[02:22:03.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: named character references currently tokenize the same way in attribute values and in element content

[02:22:04.0000] <othermaciej>
(just trying to guess things that would take down the Chrome UI process)

[02:22:05.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:23:01.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:23:02.0000] <othermaciej>
(what with the "NCR" abbreviation)

[02:24:00.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: the thingies formerly known as entities are now named character references

[02:24:01.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: entity tokenization is the one thing that is very slightly different in quoted attribute values: http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html#attribute-value-double-quoted-state

[02:24:02.0000] <othermaciej>
(vs http://dev.w3.org/html5/spec/Overview.html#data-state )

[02:24:03.0000] <peol>

[02:31:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:32:03.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: the actually interesting bit is this: "If the character reference is being consumed as part of an attribute, and the last character matched is not a U+003B SEMICOLON character (;), and the next character is in the range U+0030 DIGIT ZERO (0) to U+0039 DIGIT NINE (9), U+0041 LATIN CAPITAL LETTER A to U+005A LATIN CAPITAL LETTER Z, or U+0061 LATIN SMALL LETTER A to U+007A LATIN SMALL LETTER Z, then, for historical reasons, all the characte

[02:33:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[02:33:01.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: got cut off

[02:33:02.0000] <hsivonen>
If the character reference is being consumed as part of an attribute, and the last character matched is not a U+003B SEMICOLON character (;), and the next character is in the range U+0030 DIGIT ZERO (0) to U+0039 DIGIT NINE (9), U+0041 LATIN CAPITAL LETTER A to U+005A LATIN CAPITAL LETTER Z

[02:34:00.0000] <hsivonen>
, or U+0061 LATIN SMALL LETTER A to U+007A LATIN SMALL LETTER Z, then, for historical reasons, all the characters that were matched after the U+0026 AMPERSAND character (&) must be unconsumed, and nothing is returned.

[02:34:01.0000] <othermaciej>
hsivonen: I guess it's still true that there is already a difference, I was just wrong that the additional allowed character isthe key one

[02:34:02.0000] <othermaciej>
I found it in the spec, no worries

[02:34:03.0000] <hsivonen>
othermaciej: yeah

[02:34:04.0000] <othermaciej>
I guess that is the list to add = to, as previously identified by zcorpan on the old thread on this I believe

[02:35:00.0000] <hsivonen>
putting = on that list would certainly remove a sharp edge from the language

[02:36:00.0000] <hsivonen>
do we have data gathered by intrumenting that particular point in the tokenizer?

[02:36:01.0000] <hsivonen>
instrumenting

[02:36:02.0000] <othermaciej>
not as far as I know

[02:37:00.0000] <othermaciej>

[02:46:00.0000] <hsivonen>

[13:15:00.0000] <qFox>
hi

[13:16:00.0000] <qFox>
video has no getImageData, does it?

[13:16:01.0000] <qFox>
like canvas does...

[13:16:02.0000] <gsnedders>
qFox: No, but you can write a video to a canvas

[13:16:03.0000] <Philip`>
qFox: No, but you can do canvas.drawImage(video) and then canvas.getImageData

[13:16:04.0000] <qFox>
yeah

[13:16:05.0000] <qFox>
my question was just, why doesn't video have or get it too?

[13:16:06.0000] <Philip`>
/me curses gsnedders

[13:16:07.0000] <qFox>
because now you have to paint it to a canvas first

[13:16:08.0000] <gsnedders>
/me beat Philip`!

[13:17:00.0000] <qFox>
unneccessary overhead for an action that'll probably done more than one cares for

[13:17:01.0000] <qFox>
+be

[13:17:02.0000] <qFox>
for any kind of frame processing, this overhead can add up. especially when ticks count

[13:18:00.0000] <qFox>
so i'm just wondering whether this has been brought up at all, and if so, what hte reasoning was behind it

[13:19:00.0000] <Philip`>
qFox: It seems likely that any processing you perform on the image data would be much more expensive than an extra blit onto a canvas, so it's probably not worth the specification/implementation complexity of adding API directly to <video> to optimise that step

[13:19:01.0000] <qFox>
ah well, but is it? i imagine that a blit is costly

[13:20:00.0000] <qFox>
and if the browser can easily blit video, i imagine that a simple getImageData on the video element shouldnt be much of a problem, at that stage

[13:20:01.0000] <qFox>
(or for any element, for that matter ;)

[13:21:00.0000] <qFox>
it just seems silly to have to create bogus canvas elements just to copy the video to get its pixels

[13:21:01.0000] <Philip`>
If you want to convince people that it's worthwhile on the basis of performance, you'd probably have to provide some profiling data that shows it's a real problem (and that it can't be fixed simply by optimising the implementation of drawImage(video))

[13:22:00.0000] <qFox>
i guess this is where i lack the knowledge of implementation details of browsers. but is it really such a giant step to implement?

[13:22:01.0000] <Philip`>
(Maybe the data will indicate that it is worthwhile - I don't really have any idea)

[13:22:02.0000] <Philip`>
It's probably just a little step, but there's a million equally little steps that could be implemented too

[13:22:03.0000] <qFox>
(or rather, my lack of that knowledge comes into play..)

[13:22:04.0000] <gsnedders>
It's not the implementation difficulty that's the concern

[13:23:00.0000] <Philip`>
e.g. someone might want getImageData on <img>, and on <svg>, and might want toDataURL on all those things, and maybe they'll want to be able to draw a bit onto it too

[13:23:01.0000] <qFox>
ah, well, if you're offering.. :p

[13:23:02.0000] <qFox>
yeah i guess i understand

[13:24:00.0000] <qFox>
i'll have to create some tests then

[13:24:01.0000] <Philip`>
The current approach seems to be to try to minimise the API surface by having all the pixel-related operations exposed by <canvas>, which keeps everything relatively straightforward

[13:24:02.0000] <qFox>
luckily it was an area i wanted to focus on anyways (benchmarking)

[13:24:03.0000] <qFox>
okay

[13:24:04.0000] <qFox>
that's the explanation i was kind of expecting

[13:27:00.0000] <Philip`>
Maybe the best way to optimise video processing is to use WebGL fragment shaders

[13:27:01.0000] <Philip`>
rather than trying to get the data into JS faster

[13:28:00.0000] <qFox>

[16:11:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
jgraham, <strong style="color: red"> is preferable to <strong><font color=red>.  However, it is only aesthetically and pedagogically preferable, and I don't think that's good enough reason to say the latter is non-conforming.  A warning that there's a better way to do it would be appropriate, as I say.

[16:15:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Of course, you can always debate what should be author conformance requirements and what should be up to validator authors.  But that doesn't excuse inconsistency in the spec -- and IMO, the treatment of style="" vs. other inline presentational markup is grossly inconsistent.

[16:16:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
style="" is clearly not *that* superior to other presentational markup -- empirical evidence strongly suggests that authors believe some other elements/attributes are better (or at least as good) in some cases.

[16:16:01.0000] <Hixie>
style="" is only in the spec because of the ridiculous amount of complains we got when we removed it

[16:17:00.0000] <Hixie>
complaints, even

[16:17:01.0000] <Hixie>
and <font> is out because people complained when it was in

[16:17:02.0000] <Hixie>
originally i wanted to have just <font style=""> and only allow it for wysiwyg editors

[16:18:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Well, now I'm complaining that it's out!  Maybe if you make it obsolete but conforming you'll generate the fewest complaints.  :)

[16:18:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Realistically, inline style is useful sometimes.  Sometimes you only want to use a style once.

[16:18:02.0000] <Hixie>
right, that's why we have style=""

[16:18:03.0000] <paul_irish>
or animation.

[16:18:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Also, depending on your workflow it might just make more sense -- e.g., if you use a template-based HTML processor, then it might be just as easy to maintain, and more convenient in other ways.

[16:18:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
So I don't get all the hate.

[16:19:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
At worst, it hurts the author who uses it.  The thing to object to is non-semantic markup, not inline style.

[16:19:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
The two issues seem to be conflated.  You can use semantic and presentational markup together.  External CSS is no less presentational than inline CSS.

[16:19:02.0000] <Hixie>
the hate is because while there are a few authors who are competent enough to use it, the overwhelming majority take it as a sign that html is a presentation language

[16:20:00.0000] <Hixie>
same reason that we disallow <b><i></b></i> -- sure, some experts can use it correctly

[16:20:01.0000] <Hixie>
most can't

[16:20:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Any HTML author these days knows that CSS is necessary for presentation.  You can't do even basic layouts without it, unless you use tables, in which case you are freaking insane.

[16:21:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I'm pretty sure that almost no sites made in the last ten years don't use CSS.

[16:21:01.0000] <Hixie>
"any" dramatically overstates your case

[16:21:02.0000] <Hixie>
imho

[16:22:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
I usually try to be very careful not to overestimate the savviness of normal authors, but I'm pretty sure that even authors with extremely basic HTML knowledge understand that most styling is only possible with CSS.

[16:22:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
HTML styling is extremely limited, because no new features are being added to it.

[16:22:02.0000] <Hixie>
well if it's limited, why bother keeping any of it?

[16:22:03.0000] <Hixie>
i don't understand the use case for <font>, <big>, bgcolor="", etc

[16:23:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Because existing pages use them, and it's annoying to say that to be valid the author has to exert significant effort that has no user-visible effect.

[16:23:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Like xmlns="" or <img /> or whatever.

[16:24:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Doesn't hurt anything much, compared to equivalent inline style.  Except pedagogically, so a warning is appropriate for those who care, but an error will just make people not want to validate.

[16:27:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
This can be solved equally well by just having validators separate errors into importance groups.

[16:27:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's exactly those existing uses whose authors are clearly not already using css

[16:28:00.0000] <Hixie>
and those pages are typically an accessibility nightmare

[16:28:01.0000] <Hixie>
i really see no value in supporting those pages as is

[16:28:02.0000] <Hixie>
afk bbiab

[16:28:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, that's what warning vs. error *is*.

[16:28:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
Sure.  So what change is needed?

[16:29:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, making legacy presentational stuff a warning instead of an error.

[16:29:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Hixie, you seem to be arguing that the markup itself isn't bad, it's just correlated strongly with bad stuff, so we should ban the detectable bad stuff so that the undetectable bad stuff is probably flagged too.  But that seems like a weak argument.  Correlations like this tend to disappear when you push at them; the best we could hope for from banning presentational HTML is pages switching to CSS but still being inaccessible.

[16:30:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
There's no reason to think people will make their pages accessible if they switch to CSS, they'll just resort to divitis.

[16:30:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Do you think that, were an inaccessible presentational-using site to upgrade, they'll just use only <div style> and <span style>?

[16:30:02.0000] <roc>
that's probably the cheapest option, so yes

[16:31:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Either that, or they'll switch to divs and spans with classes.

[16:31:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Which still doesn't help.

[16:31:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
Or they'll use tags like <strong> but misuse them.

[16:31:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
That last one is standard wysiwyg practice, anyway.

[16:31:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
Like they'll just replace <strike> by <del> everywhere.

[16:31:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
Also misusing <strong>.

[16:31:06.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yep.

[16:32:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
You're not going to fix accessibility problems by mandating a logically unrelated thing, even if presently that happens to be correlated.

[16:32:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
Most authors will do accessibility when either it's effortless, or there's immediate benefit to them.

[16:32:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
The latter is unlikely, and the former is very hard to engineer.

[16:33:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
I think that @style has an intrinsic benefit over the equivalent presentational markup, which I brought up on the list.

[16:33:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
Namely, that it uses CSS, which at least *exposed* that level of authors to CSS.

[16:33:02.0000] <TabAtkins>
s/exposed/exposes/

[16:33:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
Yes, that's absolutely a benefit.  A warning is enough to give that benefit, provided authors actually validate at all.

[16:34:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Do you think that that level of author validates?

[16:34:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
No.  So it doesn't matter what the spec says at all.

[16:34:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
They'll ignore all author conformance requirements.

[16:34:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Sure, so let's do what we want and strike them for fun!

[16:34:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
(And profit, if possible.)

[16:34:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
. . .

[16:35:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
What about authors who know about validation and might validate if it were useful, but not if it's spammed with noise about things that they know aren't actually a problem?

[16:35:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
I challenge you to find a significant set of authors that match what you just described.

[16:35:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
What about authors who care about validation, but not enough to rewrite entire bodies of legacy content?

[16:36:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Wait, so for that last one, are you recommending we let their legacy content validate just to make them happy?

[16:36:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
That's what we do in lots of cases, isn't it?

[16:36:02.0000] <AryehGregor>
xmlns="", <img />, etc.

[16:36:03.0000] <AryehGregor>
It's basically harmless.

[16:36:04.0000] <annevk>
it's different from misuse though

[16:36:05.0000] <TabAtkins>
That really is harmless, though.  <img /> doesn't point to likely accessibility problems as well.

[16:37:00.0000] <Philip`>
It seems more useful to focus on improving the creation of new content, not the upgrading of legacy content, because there's a finite amount of legacy content and an infinite amount of future content

[16:37:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, so are you really arguing we should ban markup because it's *correlated* with bad practices?

[16:37:02.0000] <Philip`>
(and most legacy content never gets upgraded anyway)

[16:37:03.0000] <TabAtkins>
Not by itself, no.  But that's a contributing reason, yes.

[16:37:04.0000] <AryehGregor>
annevk, <font> isn't misuse, it was allowed by a decade of HTML standards.

[16:37:05.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, that argues for validators not complaining too loudly about legacy markup, or what?

[16:38:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
TabAtkins, why is it even a contributing reason?

[16:38:01.0000] <TabAtkins>
AryehGregor: The latter.  We should gear complaints toward encouraging better markup for new content.

[16:38:02.0000] <Philip`>
AryehGregor: It argues for designing validators to help authors who are writing new content, not to help authors who are checking or upgrading old content

[16:38:03.0000] <JonathanNeal>
TabAtkins, http://sandbox.thewikies.com/html5-browser-stylesheets/table.php

[16:38:04.0000] <TabAtkins>
TabAtkins: Because it correlates with bad practices?  I'm not sure how I can explain that further.

[16:39:00.0000] <AryehGregor>
Philip`, it's not always so easy to separate.  Content is often partly new and partly old.

[16:39:01.0000] <AryehGregor>
In MediaWiki's case, for instance, we can't ban presentational stuff in new pages.  That breaks copy-paste, etc.

[16:39:02.0000] <Philip`>

[19:52:02.0000] <til>
Hixie: what about a multiple choice survey question (check all that apply)

[19:52:03.0000] <til>
that's the situation i'm interested in

[19:53:00.0000] <Hixie>
what if none apply?

[19:53:01.0000] <Hixie>
seems very dodgy to me to use checkboxes in that way

[19:55:00.0000] <til>
hixie: i'm a supplier of survey systems for restaurants

[19:55:01.0000] <til>
there are times when there's a multiple choice non-exclusive question that is required

[19:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
like what?

[19:56:01.0000] <til>
i.e. what keeps you coming back? after someone has already said they dine frequently

[19:56:02.0000] <Hixie>
that's exactly the kind of question where i'd hate for hte browser to force me to pick at least one

[19:56:03.0000] <til>
if the client insists that a question be required, i have to make it required

[19:56:04.0000] <til>
i can tell them why it's not worth requiring

[19:56:05.0000] <til>
but they pay for me

[19:57:00.0000] <Hixie>
so much so that for similar questions in the past i've gone in with a DOM inspector and killed the JS that forces me to do it, and submitted it that way

[19:57:01.0000] <til>
i can force you to select one if it's mutually-exclusive

[19:57:02.0000] <til>
i should be able to do the same for multiple-select

[19:57:03.0000] <til>
Hixie: this isn't about form UI - it's about the API

[19:58:00.0000] <til>
i'm not saying that i like required survey questions

[19:58:01.0000] <Hixie>
the API is about form UI

[19:58:02.0000] <Hixie>
i don't think we should support this kind of UI

[19:58:03.0000] <til>
but there's a situation where you can require an input and it needs to be defined

[19:58:04.0000] <til>
e.g. what is a required checkbox

[19:58:05.0000] <Hixie>
right now it is defined as "the checkbox has to be checked"

[19:58:06.0000] <til>
i don't understand how my proposal endangers yours

[19:58:07.0000] <Hixie>
it doesn't

[19:58:08.0000] <til>
why would there be an input group if they weren't related?

[19:59:00.0000] <til>
so why should checkValidity only apply to that control

[19:59:01.0000] <til>
not the group, like with other grouped controls

[19:59:02.0000] <Hixie>
because what you're proposing is bad ui

[19:59:03.0000] <til>
applying it to the group seems more consistent - easier to grok

[19:59:04.0000] <til>
it's no less bad than requiring a radio group to be checked

[19:59:05.0000] <Hixie>
it would encourage people to make such interfaces

[20:00:00.0000] <Hixie>
i agree, with radio buttons the mistake is allowing any to not be checked in the first place

[20:00:01.0000] <Hixie>
unfortunately that boat has sailed

[20:00:02.0000] <til>
but required is essentially meaningless without applying it to the group

[20:00:03.0000] <Hixie>
no?

[20:00:04.0000] <Hixie>
it has a very well-defined meaning

[20:00:05.0000] <Hixie>
thereis no "group" with check boxes

[20:01:00.0000] <Hixie>
just checkboxes that happen to share a name

[20:01:01.0000] <Hixie>
just like you can have many text input fields with the same name -- doesn't make them into a group

[20:01:02.0000] <Hixie>
if you have <input type=text name=a required> <input type=text name=a required> you aren't required to type something into one or the other

[20:02:00.0000] <til>
in my mind, a checkbox is a type of radio that is mutually inexclusive

[20:02:01.0000] <Hixie>
you're required to type something into both

[20:02:02.0000] <til>
which is why this is distinct from a text input

[20:02:03.0000] <Hixie>
checkboxes and radio buttons are separate just like checkboxes and text fields

[20:02:04.0000] <til>
checkboxes are closer to radio than to text fields

[20:04:00.0000] <Hixie>
i think thinking of them as similar is misleading and leads one to designing poor UIs

[20:19:00.0000] <Hixie>
i really don't think that extending the wacky radio button required="" model to text fields makes any sense at all

[20:19:01.0000] <til>
anyway, is there even a concept of order in query parameters?

[20:20:00.0000] <til>
couldn't you have either Apt#B 123 Fake St and 123 Fake St Apt#B

[20:20:01.0000] <til>
depending on how the vendor parses it?

[20:20:02.0000] <Hixie>
it's always sent in form order

[20:20:03.0000] <til>
or does A before B in the HTML mean A is before B in the query?

[20:20:04.0000] <til>
ok

[20:21:00.0000] <til>
so your counterpoint is that someone could have address as the name for both fields, and only want to require the first line?

[20:21:01.0000] <til>
and want the second line filled to not fulfill the first line's requirement?

[20:22:00.0000] <til>
since there's no way to know on the server side which was filled, i don't see why the requirement should affect text fields any differently than radios or checkboxes

[20:25:00.0000] <til>
if you have text boxes A B and C called address, and get two values for address on the server side

[20:25:01.0000] <til>
you don't know which two you got

[20:25:02.0000] <Hixie>
you always know which one was filled in since you always get both, in the order they were in the form

[20:25:03.0000] <til>
but if B is empty, you don't get a key with no value

[20:25:04.0000] <Hixie>
whether or not they were filled in

[20:25:05.0000] <Hixie>
yes you do

[20:25:06.0000] <til>
really?

[20:25:07.0000] <til>
ok

[20:26:00.0000] <til>
my mistake

[20:32:00.0000] <til>

[20:32:01.0000] <til>

[17:13:00.0000] <annevk>
"The audio element, when it is exposing a user interface, is expected to be treated as a replaced element about one line high, as wide as is necessary to expose the user agent's user interface features. When an audio element is not exposing a user interface, the user agent is expected to hide it, irrespective of CSS rules."

[17:14:00.0000] <annevk>
so in effect you should not be able to display it even if you use display:block

[17:14:01.0000] <annevk>
that seems kind of contrary to <head> and <title> and all...

[18:44:00.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: I have a question about the hr element and 3.2.5.2 paragraphs. Apart from the p element what other elements can hr be between? flow minus heading and sectioning elements?

[18:45:00.0000] <Hixie>
?

[18:49:00.0000] <boblet>
“The hr element represents a paragraph-level thematic break”, with paragraph linking to 3.2.5.2

[18:50:00.0000] <boblet>
but I’d like to confirm if that means hr only between p elements or eg between lists too

[18:53:00.0000] <boblet>
hr is used a lot as a section break in Japan, mainly because it translated well on mobile browsers. Am I right in thinking this would be incorrect now?

[18:55:00.0000] <Hixie>
3.2.5.2 in which version of the spec? :-)

[18:56:00.0000] <Hixie>
oh 3.2.5.3 Paragraphs in the complete.html spec, ok

[18:56:01.0000] <Hixie>
it's just paragraph-level

[18:56:02.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: curses! transcribing error; 3.2.5.3 (http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/multipage/content-models.html#paragraphs)

[18:56:03.0000] <Hixie>
lists are paragraph-level

[18:56:04.0000] <Hixie>
pretty much everything is paragraph-level :-)

[18:57:00.0000] <Hixie>
the spec is pretty explicit when something isn't allowed or if there are restrictions

[18:57:01.0000] <boblet>
Hixie: ohrly? hmm… sectioning and heading content too?

[18:57:02.0000] <Hixie>
what it means is that <hr> can be used anywhere <p> can, basically

[18:58:00.0000] <Hixie>
though the real way to work out where you can put <hr> is to look at the content models

[18:58:01.0000] <Hixie>
not try to decode mostly informative text :-)

[18:58:02.0000] <boblet>
aha! well, I completely misread #paragraphs then

[18:58:03.0000] <Hixie>
the word "represents" is the key word that means "this element means..." e.g. for rendering or analysis purposes

[18:58:04.0000] <Hixie>
so "paragraph-level" here just means that <hr> can be treated like a paragraph for the purposes of rendering

[18:59:00.0000] <Hixie>
/me tries to work out why his browser isn't showing him what the server is returning

[18:59:01.0000] <boblet>
so hr between section elements or after h1 would be fine then?

[19:02:00.0000] <Hixie>
after <h1> would be pretty silly but sure

[19:02:01.0000] <Hixie>
between section elements is pretty much redundant

[19:03:00.0000] <boblet>
…because sections convey the semantics & style can be applied via borders or background images right?

[19:04:00.0000] <Hixie>
yeah

[19:04:01.0000] <Hixie>
<hr> basically says "end of one section, start of another"

[19:04:02.0000] <Hixie>
which is the same semantic as </section> <section>

[19:05:00.0000] <Hixie>
(though in the case of <hr> the sections are generally more thematic rather than explicit -- e.g. in a novel think <section> being like a chapter and <hr> being like a bigger space between paragraphs)

[19:08:00.0000] <boblet>
hixie: I misread this as basically hr only between paragraphs of text (eg theme change in novel), which is a lot more restrictive than you’ve explained

[19:09:00.0000] <Hixie>
ah, ok

[19:09:01.0000] <boblet>
I’ve submitted a comment about this (#9371). Thanks for your explanation!

[19:09:02.0000] <Hixie>
np, thanks for the bug!

[19:09:03.0000] <boblet>
I better go update my html5doctor article :)

[08:43:00.0000] <divya>
@TabAtkins you mentioned (w.r.t to my query on legend elm's content model) < "Content model" describes what the element is allowed to *contain*.

[08:43:01.0000] <divya>
"Categories" describe what the element *is*.  (And then "Context"...describes where it can be used.) > Am I right in assuming HTML4 did not explicitly declare category/context and only HTML5 does so? 

[08:44:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
divya: I'd have to check HTML4 to be sure.  Been a while since I've read it.

[08:44:01.0000] <Dashiva>
It declared context, surely

[08:44:02.0000] <Dashiva>
Isn't that what the DTD is all about?

[08:45:00.0000] <divya>
@Dashiva  e.g. http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/struct/global.html#h-7.5.1 for Body element there is explicit content model associated (%block; | SCRIPT)+ +(INS | DEL)

[08:46:00.0000] <divya>
@Dashiva Nothing explicit about context. 

[08:46:01.0000] <Philip`>
The "%block" definitions are sort of about context

[08:47:00.0000] <Philip`>
but in general the child->parent relationships aren't explicit, you have to derive them from te parent->child data in the DTD

[08:47:01.0000] <divya>
@Philip` %block defines what can go WITHIN body element and not what content model the element ITSELF is. 

[08:48:00.0000] <Philip`>
divya: But some other part of the DTD says that <div> etc *is* a %block, i.e. saying it can be used in all contexts that accept blocks

[08:49:00.0000] <divya>
@Philip` is there a ref here: http://www.w3.org/TR/REC-html40/sgml/dtd.html

[08:50:00.0000] <Philip`>
<!ENTITY % block "P | %heading; | %list; | %preformatted; | DL | DIV | NOSCRIPT | BLOCKQUOTE | FORM | HR | TABLE | FIELDSET | ADDRESS">

[08:51:00.0000] <Philip`>
That's kind of the explicit declaration of category

[08:52:00.0000] <divya>
@Philip` so any element in that list has a category of Block? 

[08:53:00.0000] <Philip`>
Yes, and can be used in any element whose content model includes "%block;"

[08:54:00.0000] <divya>
@Philip` ah k. but contexts are not specified though I think. They are assumed. E.g. ins and del. 

[08:55:00.0000] <jgraham>
divya: (this is not twitter, no need for the @ sign)

[08:56:00.0000] <divya>
jgraham: sorry :) too used to it.

[08:56:01.0000] <jgraham>
np :)

[10:12:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[12:35:01.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[12:35:02.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[12:35:03.0000] <annevk>

[12:35:04.0000] <annevk>

[12:36:00.0000] <annevk>

[12:37:00.0000] <annevk>

[12:37:01.0000] <annevk>

[12:43:01.0000] <annevk>

[14:20:00.0000] <TabAtkins>
Hixie: Dropped <dialog> because it was insufficient for the common use-cases.

[14:21:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[14:55:00.0000] <TabAtkins>

[14:58:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[15:11:00.0000] <jgraham>

[15:12:00.0000] <jgraham>

[15:13:00.0000] <jgraham>

[15:48:01.0000] <jgraham>

[15:50:00.0000] <jgraham>

[15:51:00.0000] <JonathanNeal>

[15:55:00.0000] <jgraham>
